questions.text: Identify the airway maneuver being demonstrated in the given image.
questions.solution:
This maneuver opens the airway by tilting the head back and lifting the chin, commonly used in unconscious patients without suspected cervical spine injury.

  • The head tilt, chin lift maneuver involves tilting the patient's head backward while simultaneously lifting the chin.
  • This action lifts the tongue away from the posterior pharyngeal wall, preventing airway obstruction.
  • It is the standard airway-opening technique in unconscious patients without suspected spinal injury.

Explanation of other options:

Jaw thrust (Option B): Performed by lifting the mandible forward without moving the cervical spine; used when spinal injury is suspected.

Head extension (Option C): Only involves tilting the head back without lifting the chin; less effective in clearing airway obstruction.

In-line manual stabilization (Option D): Used to stabilize the cervical spine during airway management in trauma cases; not an airway-opening maneuver.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman is diagnosed with advanced carcinoma of the cervix. She has a 14-year-old daughter who is currently asymptomatic and has no history of any illness. What is the most appropriate preventive advice you would give for the daughter?
questions.solution:
HPV vaccine is the most effective primary preventive strategy against cervical cancer and should be advised for the daughter of a cervical cancer patient.

  • Cervical cancer is strongly linked to infection by high-risk types of Human Papillomavirus (HPV), especially types 16 and 18, which together cause over 95% of cervical cancer cases.
  • The HPV vaccine targets the L1 capsid protein of the virus and is most effective when administered before the onset of sexual activity, ideally between 9 to 14 years of age.
  • Since the patient;s daughter is 14 years old, HPV vaccination is the most appropriate and timely preventive measure to reduce her future risk of developing cervical cancer.
  • HPV Virology Summary:
    • HPV is a double-stranded DNA virus.
    • It infects squamous epithelial or metaplastic cells.
    • E1 and E2 proteins are involved in viral replication.
    • Low-risk HPV (types 6, 11): Genital warts, rarely oncogenic.
    • High-risk HPV (types 16, 18): Strongly associated with cervical intraepithelial neoplasia and cervical carcinoma.

Explanation of other options:

Screen for BRCA mutation (Option A): BRCA mutations are associated with breast and ovarian cancers, not cervical cancer. There is no role for BRCA testing in the daughter of a cervical cancer patient.

Screen for PTEN mutation (Option C): PTEN mutations are associated with Cowden syndrome, which increases the risk of breast, thyroid, and endometrial cancers, not cervical cancer.

Perform cervical biopsy (Option D): A cervical biopsy is a diagnostic tool, not a screening method. It is not warranted in an asymptomatic 14-year-old girl with no risk factors or abnormal findings. Preventive vaccination is the priority.

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant is brought to the OPD with a parietal swelling that has been present since birth. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The X-ray image shows a localized, well-defined swelling over the parietal region not crossing suture lines. Cephalohematoma is a subperiosteal hemorrhage confined by suture lines, presenting as a firm, well-circumscribed swelling over the parietal bone.

  • Cephalohematoma is a subperiosteal collection of blood that occurs due to rupture of blood vessels between the skull and periosteum.
  • It typically presents within the first few hours of life, grows over 12-24 hours, and is limited by suture lines, as the periosteum is tightly adherent at these borders.
  • The swelling is firm, well-circumscribed, and located most commonly over the parietal bones.
  • It may take weeks to resolve, and in some cases, may lead to hyperbilirubinemia or be associated with linear skull fractures.

Explanation of other options:

Subgaleal hematoma (Option A): A more diffuse hemorrhage in the subaponeurotic space that crosses suture lines and is often associated with significant blood loss and hemodynamic instability.

Encephalocele (Option D): A neural tube defect presenting as a sac-like protrusion of brain tissue through a skull defect, typically requiring neurosurgical intervention.

questions.text: A woman presents 4 days postpartum with tearfulness, mood swings, irritability, and occasional insomnia. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Postpartum blues typically begin 3-5 days postpartum and are characterized by mood lability, tearfulness, and transient emotional symptoms.

  • Postpartum blues, or "baby blues," are the most common postpartum mood disturbance, seen in up to 80% of women.
  • Symptoms begin within 3-5 days after delivery and include emotional lability, tearfulness, irritability, anxiety, insomnia, and fatigue.
  • These symptoms are transient and usually resolve within 2 weeks without any medical treatment.
  • The condition is self-limiting and often related to hormonal fluctuations and adjustment to new motherhood.

Explanation of other options:

Postpartum anxiety (Option D): Characterized by excessive worry, panic attacks, and restlessness. Can affect maternal bonding and infant development, but symptoms are more severe than described here.

questions.text: A woman with multiple sexual partners presents with painless irregular genital ulcers and inguinal swelling. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Painless ulcer with inguinal lymphadenopathy is characteristic of primary syphilis caused by Treponema pallidum.

  • Syphilis is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the spirochete Treponema pallidum.
  • Primary syphilis presents with a painless, indurated ulcer (chancre) at the site of inoculation, typically 10-90 days post-exposure.
  • Associated non-tender, rubbery inguinal lymphadenopathy is common.
  • The diagnosis is confirmed via dark-field microscopy, which directly visualizes the spirochetes.
  • Treatment: Single dose of Benzathine penicillin G 2.4 million IU is the standard therapy.

Explanation of other options:

Chancroid (Option B): Caused by Haemophilusducreyi; presents with painful ulcers and suppurative lymphadenopathy.

Lymphogranuloma inguinale (Option C): Caused by Chlamydia trachomatis (L1-L3); may start as a painless ulcer but progresses to painful buboes, not indurated chancres.

Granuloma inguinale (Option D): Caused by Klebsiella granulomatis; features painless, beefy-red ulcers without significant inguinal lymphadenopathy.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presents with foul-smelling, bloody, mucous-mixed vaginal discharge. On pelvic examination, a necrotizing cervical growth with lateral parametrium involvement is noted. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Parametrial involvement classifies the disease as FIGO stage IIB cervical carcinoma, which is best managed with concurrent chemoradiation.

  • This clinical picture is characteristic of locally advanced cervical cancer (FIGO stage IIB), indicated by the lateral parametrium involvement.
  • The standard of care in such cases is concurrent chemoradiation, which combines external beam radiation therapy (EBRT) and cisplatin-based chemotherapy, often followed by brachytherapy boost.
  • Chemoradiation offers superior local control and survival outcomes compared to surgery alone in stage IIB or higher.
  • Management summary by stage:
  • In young women, ovaries are usually preserved to prevent premature menopause and associated complications like osteoporosis, cardiovascular disease, and cognitive decline.

Explanation of other options:

Chemotherapy (Option A): Not sufficient as standalone treatment in locally advanced cervical cancer. It is used as part of concurrent chemoradiation or for palliative care in metastatic disease.

Brachytherapy (Option B): Though crucial in cervical cancer treatment, brachytherapy alone is inadequate in stage IIB disease and is usually used as a component of chemoradiation.

Surgery (Option D): Indicated for early-stage disease (up to stage IB1/IIA1). Parametrial involvement (stage IIB) makes complete surgical resection difficult, and outcomes are inferior to chemoradiation.

Reference:

Conization

questions.text: A 5 year old child was brought with the bony deformities, as shown in the radiograph below. It could be due to the deficiency of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Bowed legs with metaphyseal changes on X-ray are classic features of rickets, which is caused by Vitamin D deficiency.

  • The radiograph showing bowed legs (Genu varum) in a 5-year-old child, accompanied by radiologic signs like cupping, splaying, and fraying of the metaphysis, is pathognomonic for Rickets, a bone disorder caused by defective mineralization of the growing bones due to Vitamin D deficiency.
  • Vitamin D is essential for calcium and phosphate metabolism and proper bone mineralization.
  • Deficiency may result from inadequate intake, malabsorption, lack of sunlight exposure, or disorders of metabolism (hepatic/renal).
  • Etiology of Rickets:
    • Vitamin D deficiency: Nutritional deficiency, malabsorption
    • Impaired metabolism: Hepatic or renal dysfunction
    • Phosphate handling defects: Fanconi syndrome, X-linked hypophosphatemia
  • Clinical features:
    • Craniotabes: Ping-pong ball sensation of skull bones
    • Rachitic rosary: Prominent costochondral junctions
    • Harrison's sulcus: Horizontal groove on lower chest
    • Pigeon chest: Protruding sternum
    • Lower limb deformities: Genu varum (bow legs), Genu valgum (knock knees), Windswept deformity
    • Muscular hypotonia, delayed dentition
  • Radiological findings:
    • Delayed epiphyseal appearance
    • Widened epiphyseal plate
    • Cupping and fraying of metaphysis
    • Splaying of metaphyseal ends
    • Bowing of long bones
  • Treatment:
    • Medical: Vitamin D (Cholecalciferol) 600,000 IU single dose IM or oral, followed by 400 IU/day
    • Supportive: Orthotic shoes, splints
    • Surgical: Corrective osteotomy if deformity persists after 6 months of therapy

Explanation of other options:

Vitamin A (Option A): Causes visual disturbances and keratinizing disorders; does not lead to bony deformities like bow legs.

Vitamin K (Option C): Deficiency causes coagulopathy due to impaired clotting factor synthesis; not related to skeletal abnormalities.

Vitamin C (Option D): Leads to scurvy, presenting with bleeding gums, petechiae, and poor wound healing. Bone pain may occur, but metaphyseal bowing or deformities like Genu varum are not typical.

questions.text: A newborn presented with chest retractions, dyspnea, and lethargy. The pediatrician diagnosed the baby with respiratory distress syndrome. This occurs due to a deficiency of:
questions.solution:
Lecithin (phosphatidylcholine) is the key surfactant component deficient in neonatal respiratory distress syndrome.

  • Neonatal Respiratory Distress Syndrome (RDS), also known as Hyaline Membrane Disease (HMD), is a condition most commonly seen in premature infants born before 34-35 weeks gestation due to a deficiency of pulmonary surfactant.
  • Surfactant is synthesized by type II pneumocytes and reduces surface tension in the alveoli, preventing their collapse during expiration.
  • The primary phospholipid component of surfactant is phosphatidylcholine, commonly known as lecithin, especially in its active form-dipalmitoylphosphatidylcholine (DPPC).
  • Surfactant production starts around 20 weeks of gestation but becomes functionally adequate only after 34-35 weeks.
  • In premature infants, low levels of lecithin lead to alveolar collapse, impaired gas exchange, tissue hypoxia, and formation of a proteinaceous hyaline membrane lining the alveoli.
  • Clinical presentation includes:
    • Tachypnea
    • Chest wall retractions
    • Grunting respiration
    • Cyanosis
    • Decreased air entry
  • Classic X-ray features:
    • Ground-glass opacities due to alveolar atelectasis
    • Air bronchograms
    • Reticulogranular pattern
  • Management involves:
    • NICU admission
    • Supportive care (e.g., IV fluids, oxygen)
    • Surfactant replacement therapy if needed
    • Respiratory support (CPAP or mechanical ventilation)

Explanation of other options:

Dipalmitoyl inositol (Option A): A phospholipid involved in cellular signaling, not a surfactant component, and not relevant to RDS pathophysiology.

Sphingomyelin (Option C): Present in cell membranes and used in the L/S ratio to assess lung maturity, but it does not directly contribute to surfactant function or alveolar stability.

Dipalmitoylphosphatidylethanolamine (Option D): Although it is a membrane phospholipid, it lacks the surface tension-reducing ability of dipalmitoylphosphatidylcholine (lecithin), which is essential for preventing alveolar collapse.

questions.text: A patient from Delhi presents with a 3-day history of high-grade fever, joint pain, retro-orbital pain, and a widespread petechial rash. Laboratory findings include haemoglobin of 9 g/dL, WBC count of 9000/mm3, platelet count of 20,000/mm3, and a positive tourniquet test. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Dengue hemorrhagic fever is characterised by high fever, thrombocytopenia (<100,000/mm3), plasma leakage (leading to hemoconcentration, pleural effusion, or ascites), and hemorrhagic manifestations (petechiae, gum bleeding, or positive tourniquet test). The patient's low platelet count (20,000/mm3) and petechiae confirm this diagnosis.

Explanation for other options:

Dengue fever (Option A): Classical dengue fever presents with fever, arthralgia, myalgia, retro-orbital pain, and rash but does not involve significant thrombocytopenia (<100,000/mm3) or plasma leakage. The presence of petechiae and a positive tourniquet test suggests progression to Dengue Hemorrhagic Fever (DHF).

Dengue shock syndrome (Option C): Dengue shock syndrome is a severe complication of DHF, with hypotension, circulatory collapse, and organ failure. The absence of shock symptoms (low BP, tachycardia, cold extremities, altered sensorium) rules out DSS.

Malaria (Option D): Malaria presents with cyclic fevers, chills, sweating, and anaemia. While severe Plasmodium falciparum infection can cause thrombocytopenia, petechial rash and a positive tourniquet test are not typical findings.

Reference:

  1. Neurological Complications of Dengue Fever | Current Neurology and Neuroscience Reports
  2. Acute liver failure in a young patient with dengue shock syndrome: a case report.
  3. Dengue Pneumonia: A Tropical Problem
  4. Myocarditis Leading to Severe Dilated Cardiomyopathy in a Patient with Dengue Fever - PMC.
  5. Dengue fever presenting as epididymo-orchitis

questions.text: Identify the condition associated with the murmur depicted in the image below.
questions.solution:
A pansystolic murmur best heard at the apex and radiating to the axilla is characteristic of mitral regurgitation.

  • The image provided shows a pansystolic murmur, also known as a holosystolic murmur, which is a hallmark of mitral regurgitation (MR).
  • MR occurs when the mitral valve fails to close properly during systole, leading to retrograde flow of blood from the left ventricle (LV) to the left atrium (LA).
  • This murmur:
    • Begins with S1 and continues through to S2, hence the term pansystolic.
    • Is best heard at the apex of the heart.
    • Characteristically radiates to the axilla.
    • May be associated with a soft or absent S1, especially in chronic MR where the mitral valve leaflets are already poorly mobile.
    • Clinical signs of MR include:
      • Dyspnea (due to pulmonary congestion)
      • Fatigue (from reduced cardiac output)
      • Orthopnea, and
      • Atrial fibrillation (due to left atrial dilation)

questions.text: What does the marked region in the given spirometry represent?
questions.solution:
The marked region in the given spirometry represents the Functional Residual Capacity (FRC).

  • Spirometry measures airflow in and out of the lungs, which is useful in diagnosing and monitoring lung diseases.
  • FRC is the lung air volume after a normal, passive exhalation. It is calculated as the sum of the Expiratory Reserve Volume (ERV) and the Residual Volume (RV) and is around 2.3 L.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a history of multiple sexual partners presents with lower abdominal pain for 1 month. She experiences minimal discharge and complains of inter-menstrual bleeding. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation is most consistent with pelvic inflammatory disease caused by Neisseria gonorrhoea.

  • The given clinical scenario-lower abdominal pain, minimal discharge, intermenstrual bleeding, and a history of multiple sexual partners-suggests a sexually transmitted infection leading to pelvic inflammatory disease (PID).
  • Among common causes of PID, Neisseria gonorrhoea is a key pathogen.
  • Morphology:

a. Neisseria gonorrhoea are gram-negative cocci with pili that help them adhere to urethral and mucosal surfaces.

b. They invade intracellular spaces and reach subepithelial tissues within 3 days of infection.

  • Clinical Features in Females:

a. Urethritis

b. Cervical discharge (thick and purulent)

c. Pruritus

d. Dysuria

e. Intermenstrual bleeding

f. Often asymptomatic (~50% of cases)

g. Main sites of infection: columnar and transitional epithelium

h. Initially affects the cervix and urethra, and may extend to Bartholin's glands, Skene's glands, endometrium, and fallopian tubes

  • Complications:

a. Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID)

b. Salpingitis leading to sterility

c. Tubo-ovarian abscess

d. Ectopic pregnancy

e. Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome (perihepatic inflammation)

f. In males:

  • Mucopurulent discharge resembling semen ("flow of seed")
  • Urethritis, prostatitis, epididymitis
  • Urethral strictures
  • Water-can perineum: spread to periurethral tissues → abscesses → discharging sinuses

Explanation of other options:

Genital TB (Option B): Presents with menstrual irregularities, infertility, and constitutional symptoms (fever, malaise, weight loss). Less likely here due to sexual history and absence of systemic signs.

Candida (Option C): Causes thick, curdy white discharge and intense pruritus. Intermenstrual bleeding and abdominal pain are not typical.

Herpes simplex (Option D): Characterized by grouped painful vesicles/ulcers. Chronic lower abdominal pain and intermenstrual bleeding are not usual features.

Reference:

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC6469382/

choices.text: Manage ABC, NS 20 mL/kg and start insulin after 1 hour
Manage ABC, NS 20 mL/kg along with insulin 0.1 IU/kg/hr
Manage ABC, NS 10 mL/kg along with insulin 0.1 IU/kg/hr
Manage ABC, NS 10 mL/kg and start insulin after 1 hour

questions.text: A 10-year-old child weighing 30 kg presents with a history of loose stools for 2 days. On examination, there is severe dehydration. Laboratory investigations are as follows. What is the initial management as per ISPAD guidelines?
questions.solution:
According to ISPAD guidelines, initial management of DKA includes airway-breathing-circulation (ABC), fluid resuscitation with 20 mL/kg NS, and delayed insulin initiation after 1 hour.

  • This patient has Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA), as evidenced by severe hyperglycemia (RBS 550 mg/dL), metabolic acidosis (pH 7.01), and ketonuria (urine glucose 3+ with history of dehydration).
  • As per the ISPAD 2022 guidelines, the initial management of DKA in children involves:
    • Airway, Breathing, Circulation (ABC) stabilization
    • Fluid resuscitation with 0.9% Normal Saline 20 mL/kg over 20-30 minutes to restore circulatory volume and begin correcting dehydration.
    • Insulin therapy should not be started immediately.
    • It is initiated after 1 hour of fluid therapy, typically as IV infusion of regular insulin at 0.05 - 0.1 IU/kg/hr.
    • Early insulin without adequate fluid replacement can worsen circulatory collapse and increase the risk of cerebral edema.
  • Other supportive steps:
    • Monitor vitals and GCS hourly.
    • Monitor electrolytes and glucose frequently.
    • Begin potassium replacement once urine output is adequate and insulin is started.
    • Gradually transition to subcutaneous insulin once acidosis resolves (pH > 7.3, HCO3- > 18, BOHB < 1 mmol/L) and oral intake is tolerated.

Reference:

ISPAD 2022: Diabetic ketoacidosis Page 840,844

Pediatric Diabetic Ketoacidosis - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4413392/

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with a verrucous carcinoma involving the glans penis. On examination, inguinal lymph nodes are not palpable. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Partial penectomy is the treatment of choice for localized penile cancer limited to the glans.

  • In cases of localized verrucous carcinoma confined to the glans without lymph node involvement, partial penectomy is the standard approach.
  • It provides adequate oncological control while preserving penile function.
  • A surgical margin of 2 cm is typically recommended for distal lesions.
  • Total penectomy is reserved for more proximal or extensive tumors, while topical therapies like 5-fluorouracil are used for carcinoma in situ or superficial lesions.

choices.text: Transverse vaginal septum above the vagina

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents with cyclical pelvic pain each month for the past several months, but she has not yet attained menarche. On abdominal examination, there is a central suprapubic bulge. On per rectal examination, a bulge is felt anteriorly. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Imperforate hymen causes cryptomenorrhea, presenting with cyclical pelvic pain, amenorrhea, and suprapubic bulging due to retained menstrual blood (hematocolpos/hematometra).

  • An imperforate hymen is a congenital anomaly where the hymen fails to perforate during fetal development, leading to complete obstruction of the vaginal outflow tract.
  • At puberty, when menstruation begins, menstrual blood accumulates behind the hymen, resulting in hematocolpos (blood in the vagina), and possibly hematometra (blood in the uterus), and even hematosalpinx.
  • The classic presentation includes:
    • Primary amenorrhea
    • Cyclical pelvic pain (due to retained menstrual blood)
    • A central suprapubic mass (due to hematocolpos/hematometra)
    • On per rectal examination, a tense bulge is felt anteriorly
    • On vulval inspection, a bluish bulging hymen may be visible
    • Management:
      • Cruciate incision of the hymen with drainage of retained blood.
      • Cervical Stenosis: Dilate the cervix to relieve the obstruction.

Explanation of other options:

Transverse vaginal septum above the vagina (Option A): May cause similar symptoms but usually does not result in a prominent central bulge or mass that is as easily palpable per abdomen or per rectum.

Vaginal atresia (Option B): This presents with absent or shortened vaginal canal, but often without a distended central bulge as the vagina may not be formed at all. It typically doesn't cause a uniform suprapubic swelling.

Cervical agenesis (Option D): A rare mullerian anomaly where the uterus is present but there is no cervix to allow outflow. This also leads to cryptomenorrhea but doesn't typically present with a tense bulging mass and requires imaging to diagnose, not clinical exam alone.

choices.text: Intraosseous route access for giving IV fluids

questions.text: Identify the procedure being performed in the image given below.
questions.solution:
The image shows intraosseous cannulation used for rapid vascular access to administer fluids or medications, especially in emergency settings.

  • Intraosseous (IO) access is used when peripheral IV access is difficult or delayed, such as in trauma, shock, cardiac arrest, or pediatric emergencies.
  • The technique involves inserting a needle into the medullary cavity of a long bone (usually proximal tibia, distal femur, or humeral head), which provides access to the rich venous plexus within the bone marrow that drains into the central circulation.
  • This allows for rapid administration of fluids, drugs, and even blood products.
  • Devices like the EZ-IO® use a battery-powered driver to insert the cannula quickly and reliably.

Explanation of other options:

Intraosseous cannula for pain relief (Option A): IO access is used for fluid and drug administration, not primarily for localized pain relief.

Bone marrow aspiration (Option B): Bone marrow aspiration typically involves the iliac crest and uses a specific aspiration needle, not a powered IO device. The technique and indication differ.

Bone marrow biopsy (Option D): A biopsy involves removing a solid core of marrow tissue, often done alongside aspiration. It requires a trephine biopsy needle, not the device shown in IO access.

questions.text: Which of the following is the drug of choice for preoperative antibiotic prophylaxis in a patient undergoing cardiac surgery?
questions.solution:
Cefazolin is the preferred antibiotic for prophylaxis in cardiac surgeries due to its effective coverage against common pathogens like Staphylococcus aureus and S. epidermidis.

  • Cefazolin, a first-generation cephalosporin, is the drug of choice for preoperative prophylaxis in cardiac surgery.
  • It is effective against gram-positive organisms, especially Staphylococcus aureus and S. epidermidis, which are the primary pathogens involved in surgical site infections following cardiac procedures.
  • It is typically given 30-60 minutes before the incision.
  • For patients with severe beta-lactam allergy or high MRSA risk, vancomycin may be used as an alternative.

Explanation of other options:

Penicillin G (Option A): Limited gram-positive spectrum; not effective against Staphylococcus aureus, hence not suitable for cardiac surgery prophylaxis.

Erythromycin (Option B): A macrolide with limited efficacy against surgical pathogens; rarely used for prophylaxis in cardiac procedures.

Azithromycin (Option C): Though better tolerated than erythromycin, it is not suitable for surgical prophylaxis due to inadequate coverage of typical pathogens.

Reference:

https://www.choc.org/userfiles/AntibioticProphylaxisForSurgeryGuideline.pdf

questions.text: A 30-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after suddenly losing consciousness while working outdoors. On examination, his body temperature is 105°F, and he shows reduced skin turgor. Which of the following findings is least likely to be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
Although present in earlier stages of heat exhaustion, sweating typically stops in heat stroke, especially non-exertional heat stroke.

Physiological Changes in Heat Stroke

Heat stroke is a life-threatening condition marked by a core temperature >40°C, leading to CNS dysfunction and multi-organ failure.

Key Physiological Changes

  • Hyperthermia:
    • Core temperature rises above 40°C; cellular necrosis occurs at 49°C-50°C, red hot skin. (Option D ruled out)
  • CNS Dysfunction:
    • Symptoms: Confusion, agitation, seizures, coma.
    • Causes: Cerebral hypoperfusion, increased intracranial pressure, and systemic inflammation.
  • Cardiovascular Changes:
    • Tachycardia, hypotension, widened pulse pressure. (Option B ruled out)
    • Distributive shock due to vasodilation and vascular permeability.
  • Metabolic Disturbances:
    • Metabolic acidosis from anaerobic metabolism.
    • Electrolyte imbalances (hyperkalemia, hyponatremia).
  • Inflammatory Response:
    • Cytokine release (e.g., IL-6) causes endothelial damage, microthrombosis, and DIC.
  • Acute Kidney Injury (AKI):
    • Causes: Rhabdomyolysis, dehydration, reduced renal perfusion.
  • Respiratory Changes:
    • Tachypnea compensates for metabolic acidosis. (Option A ruled out)
    • Kussmaul breathing reflects severe acidosis, indicating critical metabolic derangement.

Reference:

  1. Heat stroke - PMC
  2. A Systematic Review on Outcomes of Patients with Heatstroke and Heat Exhaustion - PMC

questions.text: A patient presents with abdominal pain and sterile pyuria, the x-ray showed the following features. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The X-ray reveals a dense, lobulated calcified mass in the renal region. Putty kidney is a non-functioning, calcified kidney seen in end-stage renal tuberculosis due to dystrophic calcification.

  • Putty kidney refers to a completely calcified, shrunken, non-functioning kidney seen in advanced renal tuberculosis.
  • Chronic TB infection leads to granulomatous inflammation, necrosis, fibrosis, and ultimately dystrophic calcification of the renal tissue.
  • The kidney appears lobulated and "putty-like" on X-ray or CT and does not function.
  • Patients often present with abdominal pain and sterile pyuria, classic features of renal TB.



Explanation of other options:

Psoas calcification (Option D): Seen in the psoas muscle or tendon, often due to chronic inflammation or infection; location and appearance differ from renal calcification.

Reference:

Putty Kidney

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents to the clinic with concerns of premature ejaculation occurring within a minute of vaginal penetration, causing distress in his relationship. He has no significant past medical history and does not take any medications. What is the most appropriate non-pharmacological intervention?
questions.solution:
The squeeze technique is a specific, non-pharmacological method used to delay ejaculation in patients with premature ejaculation.

  • Premature ejaculation (PME) is defined by the DSM-5 as ejaculation that occurs within approximately 1 minute of vaginal penetration, or before the individual wishes it, leading to distress or interpersonal difficulty.
  • It is often psychogenic and can be managed with behavioral techniques, especially in patients with no underlying medical conditions.
  • The squeeze technique, first described by Masters and Johnson, is a widely used behavioral therapy.
  • It involves the sexual partner manually stimulating the penis until the patient feels close to ejaculating, then applying pressure (squeezing) at the base of the glans penis for several seconds, which causes a temporary loss of erection and delays ejaculation.
  • This is repeated several times before ejaculation is allowed. Over time, this helps build control over ejaculation.

Explanation of other options:

Cognitive behavioural therapy (Option A): CBT is beneficial in treating anxiety, depression, and some sexual dysfunctions, but it is more general and less specifically effective for PME than targeted techniques like the squeeze method.

Exposure and Response Prevention Therapy (Option B): Primarily used in obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD), this therapy is not applicable in the management of PME.

Sensate focus therapy (Option D): While helpful in addressing performance anxiety and improving intimacy, this therapy is not primarily intended for delaying ejaculation and is less effective in isolation for PME.

questions.text: A young man came to the medical OPD with complaints of early morning backache and stiffness, which improves on exercise, and persistent red eyes. On examination, lung expansion was less than 3 cm. X-ray is shown in the image given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The classic triad of inflammatory back pain, reduced chest expansion, and uveitis strongly suggests ankylosing spondylitis, supported by the "bamboo spine" seen on X-ray.

  • Ankylosing Spondylitis (AS) is a chronic inflammatory seronegative spondyloarthropathy that primarily affects the spine and sacroiliac joints.
  • The hallmark feature is inflammatory back pain, which is worse in the morning or after periods of inactivity, and improves with exercise.
  • Reduced lung expansion (<3 cm) is due to costovertebral joint involvement.
  • The patient also has persistent red eyes, suggesting anterior uveitis, the most common extra-articular manifestation of AS.
  • Characteristic radiological features of AS seen in this case:
    • Sacroiliitis: bilateral and symmetrical involvement with erosion, sclerosis, and eventual fusion.
    • Syndesmophyte formation leads to bamboo spine appearance on X-ray.
    • Dagger sign: a radiodense line due to ossification of interspinous and supraspinous ligaments.
  • Other clinical features include:
    • Enthesitis (especially at Achilles tendon, plantar fascia)
    • Peripheral large joint arthritis (hip, shoulder)
    • Postural changes: forward stooping due to thoracic kyphosis
    • Fatigue, anemia of chronic disease, and rarely cardiac/aortic involvement
  • Investigations:
    • HLA-B27 positive in >90% of patients
    • Elevated ESR, CRP
    • MRI is more sensitive than X-ray in early disease

Explanation of other options:

Paget's Disease (Option B): Characterized by abnormal bone remodeling with cortical thickening and lytic-sclerotic lesions, not vertebral fusion or syndesmophytes. Does not cause morning stiffness or uveitis.

Healed Tuberculosis (Option C): Pott's spine may cause vertebral collapse or gibbus deformity, but not the bamboo spine appearance. Uveitis and reduced lung expansion are uncommon.

Osteopetrosis (Option D): A genetic disorder with diffuse bone sclerosis due to defective osteoclast function. X-rays show dense bones, but there is no inflammatory back pain, uveitis, or vertebral fusion.

questions.text: A malnourished man presents with photosensitive dermatitis over sun-exposed areas, chronic diarrhoea, and progressive memory disturbances. He also exhibits signs of apathy and glossitis. What is the most likely nutritional deficiency responsible for these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Niacin (Vitamin B3) deficiency causes pellagra.

Pellagra is characterised by the classic triad of symptoms:

  • Dermatitis
    • Bright red erythema in sun-exposed areas (face, ankles, feet)
    • Casal's necklace- ↑pigmentation around the neck
  • Diarrhoea, and
  • Dementia.

Causes of pellagra :

  • Dietary Deficiency- Maize and Sorghum-based diet
  • Impaired Tryptophan Metabolism
    • Factors Affecting Tryptophan to Niacin Conversion:
      • Vitamin B6 Deficiency
      • Medications: Isoniazid (INH), OCPs
      • Hormonal Influences: Estrogen metabolites hinder tryptophan metabolism.
      • Genetic Disorders:Inherited conditions like Hartnup disease can impede tryptophan absorption in the intestines and reabsorption in the kidneys
  • Carcinoid Syndrome
  • Other Contributing Factors:
    • Alcoholism: Interferes with nutrient absorption, including niacin and tryptophan.
    • Malabsorption Syndromes

Explanation of other options:

Riboflavin (Option B): Deficiency causes angular cheilitis, glossitis, and seborrheic dermatitis, but not the 3 Ds of pellagra.

Thiamine (Option C): Leads to beriberi (dry or wet) and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, involving cardiac and neurologic issues, not diarrhoea or dermatitis.

Biotin (Option D): Deficiency results in dermatitis, alopecia, and neurological symptoms, but not the classic triad of pellagra.

questions.text: In which of the following nerve injuries is the instrument shown below used?
questions.solution:
The image shows a dynamic cock-up wrist splint used for wrist drop due to radial nerve palsy.

  • The dynamic cock-up splint supports the wrist in extension and is typically used in radial nerve palsy, which causes wrist drop due to paralysis of the wrist and finger extensors.
  • This splint prevents flexion contractures and helps preserve hand function during recovery.

Radial Nerve Injury Management:

  • Open injuries: Immediate exploration and primary nerve repair or grafting
  • Closed injuries: Observation for 12 weeks; if no improvement, do EMG → if denervation, explore and repair
  • Associated with humeral fractures: Assess for nerve injury early; post-manipulation injury requires urgent repair
  • Recovery care: Passive hand movements, splinting (dynamic cock-up splint)
  • Long-term sequelae: Tendon transfers (e.g., pronator teres to extensor carpi radialis brevis, FCR/FCU to finger extensors, palmaris longus to abductor pollicis longus)

Explanation of other options:

Median nerve (Option B): Treated with rest and analgesics, particularly in carpal tunnel syndrome; cock-up splint not indicated.

Ulnar nerve (Option C): Managed with a knuckle bender splint, not a cock-up splint.

Volkmann's ischemic contracture (Option D): Managed using Volkman or Turnbuckle splints, not cock-up splints.

choices.text: Anti-gas gangrene serum is indicated for all cases
Urinary diversion is the next step
A bilateral orchidectomy must be done

questions.text: A diabetic patient presents with sudden-onset severe perineal pain. On examination, there is foul-smelling discharge and visible necrotic tissue, as shown in the image. Which of the following is true regarding the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Fournier's gangrene is caused by a polymicrobial infection involving both aerobic and anaerobic organisms.

  • The clinical features and image are suggestive of Fournier's gangrene, a rapidly progressing necrotizing fasciitis of the perineum and genitalia.
  • It is most often seen in immunocompromised patients such as diabetics.
  • The infection is polymicrobial, commonly involving:
    • Aerobic bacteria: E. coli, Proteus, Klebsiella, Staphylococcus, Streptococcus
    • Anaerobic bacteria: Bacteroides, Clostridium, Peptostreptococcus
  • Fournier's Gangrene Overview:
    • Definition: Necrotizing infection affecting the perineum, genitalia, or perianal area.
    • Symptoms: Sudden perineal pain, foul discharge, crepitus, dusky skin, and eventual gangrene.
    • Progression Phases: From pain and erythema → crepitus → necrosis and sepsis.
    • Risk Factors: Diabetes, alcoholism, malnutrition, PVD, immunosuppression.
    • Management includes:
      • Fluid resuscitation and broad-spectrum antibiotics
      • Urgent surgical debridement
      • Urinary and fecal diversion in selected cases
      • Wound care and later skin grafting

Explanation of other options:

Anti-gas gangrene serum is indicated for all cases (Option A): Incorrect. Antitoxin is used for Clostridial gas gangrene, not all cases of Fournier's gangrene.

Urinary diversion is the next step (Option B): Incorrect. While urinary diversion may be required to prevent contamination, it is not the immediate next step-surgical debridement takes priority.

A bilateral orchidectomy must be done (Option C): Incorrect. Orchidectomy is reserved only if the testes are involved, which is not routine in all cases.

questions.text: A 35 year old obese female with hirsutism presents with lesions as shown. She is not responding to isotretinoin and antibiotics. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Hirsutism, obesity, and resistant lower face acne suggest hyperandrogenism as the underlying etiology.

  • This woman presents with acne that is not responding to isotretinoin or antibiotics, suggesting that the etiology may not be purely inflammatory or bacterial.
  • The combination of obesity, hirsutism, and acne localized to the lower face (U-zone) is highly indicative of hormonal acne, often driven by hyperandrogenism.
  • Evaluation of hyperandrogenism involves measuring serum testosterone, DHEAS, and sometimes 17-hydroxyprogesterone, to rule out conditions such as polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS), late-onset congenital adrenal hyperplasia, or rare androgen-secreting tumors.
  • Hyperandrogenism leads to increased sebaceous gland activity and comedogenesis, often resulting in treatment-resistant acne.
  • Identifying the hormonal basis allows for targeted treatment with anti-androgens like spironolactone or oral contraceptives.

Explanation of other options:

Look for antibiotic resistance (Option A): Antibiotic resistance is a concern in acne management but is unlikely here as the underlying issue is hormonal rather than infectious.

Look for triggering drugs (Option B): Drug-induced acne is typically monomorphic and not associated with hirsutism or obesity; it's less likely in this clinical context.

Look for dietary triggers (Option C): Diet may exacerbate acne but does not explain hirsutism and obesity, which point to a hormonal etiology.

questions.text: A patient with hyperkalemia and elevated urea levels underwent dialysis. Towards the end of the session, she became drowsy and developed a sudden seizure. On examination, she was found to be hypotensive. Which medication should be initiated to manage this condition?
questions.solution:
The patient is experiencing dialysis disequilibrium syndrome (DDS), managed with IV Mannitol to reduce cerebral oedema.

  • Dialysis Disequilibrium Syndrome (DDS) is an acute neurological complication typically seen during or after the first hemodialysis session, particularly in patients with severe azotemia.
  • It is caused by the rapid removal of urea from the blood, creating a reverse urea gradient between the plasma and cerebrospinal fluid.
  • This leads to osmotic movement of water into the brain, resulting in cerebral edema.
  • Clinical features include headache, nausea, vomiting, blurred vision, restlessness, confusion, tremors, muscle cramps, and in severe cases, seizures or coma.
  • Risk factors include very high BUN levels (>175 mg/dL), first dialysis session, rapid dialysis, pediatric or elderly patients, and underlying neurological disorders.
  • Management includes:
    • Administering IV Mannitol to reduce cerebral edema.
    • Modifying dialysis parameters to slow solute removal.
    • Supportive care.
  • Prevention includes:
    • Initiating dialysis slowly with shorter sessions.
    • Adjusting dialysate composition (e.g., higher sodium).
    • Avoiding rapid correction of severe uremia.

Explanation of other options:

Bumetanide (Option A): A loop diuretic used for fluid overload; does not address the osmotic cerebral oedema in DDS.

Ethacrynic acid (Option B): Another loop diuretic; not effective in treating the cerebral osmotic shifts seen in DDS.

Nesiritide (Option C): A B-type natriuretic peptide analogue used in acute heart failure, not indicated for DDS.

Reference:

NCBI Bookshelf

choices.text: Unconsciousness with pulse absent and breathing absent
Unconsciousness with pulse present and breathing absent
Unconsciousness with pulse and breathing present
Unconsciousness with pulse absent and breathing present

questions.text: When is the indicated position used during resuscitation?
questions.solution:
The recovery position is used in unconscious patients who have spontaneous breathing and circulation to maintain airway patency and prevent aspiration.

  • The recovery position involves placing an unconscious patient on their side with the lower arm extended and the upper leg flexed.
  • This posture helps keep the airway open by preventing the tongue from falling back and allows fluids (such as vomit or secretions) to drain, reducing the risk of aspiration.
  • It is particularly indicated in unconscious patients with intact breathing and pulse, especially when drug or alcohol intoxication is suspected.
  • It ensures better airway maintenance while awaiting definitive care.

Explanation of other options:

Unconsciousness with pulse absent and breathing absent (Option A): Indicates cardiac arrest; immediate CPR is required, not the recovery position.

Unconsciousness with pulse present and breathing absent (Option B): Requires rescue breathing or assisted ventilation to support oxygenation.

Unconsciousness with pulse absent and breathing present (Option D): This is physiologically improbable; if it occurs, immediate reassessment and resuscitation are warranted rather than using the recovery position.

Reference:

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC3161868/

questions.text: A 35 year old lady with a history of hair dye application presents with the following clinical picture. What is the cause ?
questions.solution:
Paraphenylenediamine (PPD) is the most common allergen causing allergic contact dermatitis from hair dyes.

  • This patient is presenting with allergic contact dermatitis, a Type IV hypersensitivity reaction, following hair dye application.
  • The most frequently implicated chemical in hair dye-induced dermatitis is paraphenylenediamine (PPD).
  • PPD is a coal-tar derivative used to achieve permanent black or dark-colored dyes.
  • When applied to the scalp, it can penetrate the skin and elicit an immune-mediated reaction in sensitized individuals.
  • Clinical features include:
    • Itching, erythema, and vesiculation at the site of application.
    • Involvement of face, ears, neck, and scalp margins (regions exposed to the dye).
    • Repeated exposure worsens symptoms.
  • Diagnosis is primarily clinical, but patch testing can confirm sensitivity.
  • Management involves discontinuing the offending agent, topical corticosteroids, and avoidance of future exposure.

Explanation of other options:

Balsam of Peru (Option A): This is a plant-derived substance used in perfumes and some topical products, which can cause contact dermatitis, but it is not commonly associated with hair dye reactions.

Pollen (Option C): Pollen causes respiratory allergies (e.g., allergic rhinitis), not contact dermatitis, and is unrelated to hair dye exposure.

Drug intake (Option D): Systemic drugs can lead to drug eruptions, but the localized nature of the lesions after direct exposure to hair dye supports contact dermatitis rather than a drug-related cause.

choices.text: Intensity is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the source
Small blood vessels are most radioresistant
Rapidly proliferating cells are most radioresistant
Small intestinal mucosa is most radioresistant

questions.text: A woman undergoing radiotherapy for endometrial carcinoma is being evaluated for radiation safety and tissue response. Which of the following statements is true?
questions.solution:
Radiation intensity follows the inverse square law, decreasing rapidly with increased distance from the source.

  • The inverse square law defines that the intensity is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the source.
  • It is a principle of physics that states that the intensity of an effect such as illumination or gravitational force changes in inverse proportion to the square of the distance from the source.

Radiotherapy:

  • Radiation is a 'Double-edged sword' - it kills cancerous cells; it may also damage normal cells.
  • It kills cells by damaging DNA which produces free radicals.
  • Types: It depends on the source of radiation.
  • Two types:
    • Teletherapy: EBRT (External Beam Radiotherapy), source is at a distance,
    • Brachytherapy: source is nearer to the patient.
      • Brachytherapy is divided into 3 types:
        • Interstitial (into the tissue): Ca Prostate, Ca Breast
        • Intracavitatory (accessible cavity): Accessible tumors like Ca Cervix
        • Mold (Superficial cancers): Penis, Eye cancers

Explanation of other options:

Small blood vessels are most radioresistant (Option B): Small blood vessels are not the most radioresistant. In fact, the vascular endothelium is relatively radiosensitive, and radiation can cause vascular damage leading to ischemia and necrosis.

Rapidly proliferating cells are most radioresistant (Option C): Rapidly proliferating cells are not the most radioresistant; in fact, they are more radiosensitive. The reason is that these cells are often in the process of dividing, and radiation damages DNA, disrupting the cell cycle and leading to cell death.

Small intestinal mucosa is most radio-resistant (Option D): Small intestinal mucosa is not the most radio-resistant. The cells of the small intestinal mucosa are rapidly dividing, making them more susceptible to radiation.

Reference:

Inverse-square law - Wikipedia

Are cancer stem cells radioresistant? - PMC

choices.text: Parasympathetic - bladder dysfunction and retrograde ejaculation
Sympathetic - retrograde ejaculation and bladder dysfunction
Sympathetic - impotence and loss of cutaneous sensation in the perineal region

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common complication following ligation of the first vessel during abdominoperineal resection (APR) for rectal carcinoma?
questions.solution:
High ligation of the inferior mesenteric artery during APR may injure sympathetic nerves, causing bladder dysfunction and retrograde ejaculation.

  • In abdominoperineal resection (APR), the first vessel ligated is typically the inferior mesenteric artery (IMA).
  • High ligation of the IMA risks damage to the superior hypogastric plexus, which carries sympathetic fibers.
  • Injury to these nerves leads to loss of sympathetic control over bladder neck closure and ejaculation, resulting in retrograde ejaculation and bladder dysfunction.
  • APR (Miles procedure) is done when rectal tumors involve the sphincter complex.
  • It involves two phases:
    • Abdominal phase: Ligation of IMA, mobilization of descending colon, dissection of rectum to levator ani.
    • Perineal phase: Excision of anus, sphincters, and rectum en bloc with perineal closure. A permanent colostomy is formed.
  • APR has higher recurrence rates compared to low anterior resection due to frequent positive circumferential margins.
  • Complications include:
    • Sympathetic nerve injury (most commonly affecting ejaculation and bladder function)
    • Anastomotic leaks, bleeding, strictures, necrosis of colon
    • Sexual dysfunction and recurrence risks (up to 33%)

Explanation of other options:

Parasympathetic - bladder dysfunction and retrograde ejaculation (Option A): Parasympathetic injury causes erectile dysfunction, not retrograde ejaculation.

Sympathetic - bladder dysfunction and impotence (Option B): Sympathetic injury causes bladder dysfunction and retrograde ejaculation, not impotence.

Sympathetic - impotence and loss of cutaneous sensation in the perineal region (Option D): Impotence is more linked to parasympathetic injury; sensory loss implies pudendal nerve damage, not sympathetic.

choices.text: A - Glucose, B - PAH, C - Bicarbonate and D - Inulin
A - Glucose, B - Bicarbonate, C - Inulin and D - PAH
A - PAH, B - Inulin, C - Glucose and D - Bicarbonate
A - Inulin, B - Glucose, C - Bicarbonate and D - PAH

questions.text: From the given graph, which pair of substances is correctly matched with their respective renal clearance?
questions.solution:
The given graph shows renal clearance of different substances.

Clearance measures the volume of plasma completely cleared of a substance by the kidneys per minute (mL/min), reflecting renal excretory efficiency. It is essential for evaluating kidney function, including filtration, reabsorption, and secretion processes.

To calculate the clearance rate (Cs) of the substance, use the formula:

Clearance Formula: (Cs) = (Us x V) / Ps

Us: Urine concentration of the substance

V: Urine flow rate

Ps: Plasma concentration of the substance

Plugging in the values:

Cs = (10×2)/5 = 4 ml /min

So, the clearance rate of the substance is 4 mL/min.

Key Takeaway:

Renal Clearance

CPAH>>CCr>>CInsulin [125ml/min (GFR)]>>Curea>>CNa+>>CGlucose/AA

questions.text: A female patient presents with severe restlessness, palpitations, and tremors to the emergency department. She is a known case of bronchial asthma. On examination, the neck looks swollen. Blood pressure is elevated, and tachycardia is noted. ECG shows atrial fibrillation. Which of the following drugs is used for immediate management in this patient?
questions.solution:
Diltiazem is preferred for rate control in atrial fibrillation in thyroid storm when beta-blockers are contraindicated, such as in bronchial asthma.

  • The patient's presentation-restlessness, palpitations, tremors, tachycardia, atrial fibrillation, and a swollen neck-suggests thyroid storm, a life-threatening complication of hyperthyroidism.
  • Clinical features:
    • Fever
    • Delirium, seizures, coma
    • Vomiting, diarrhea
    • Jaundice
    • Hyperthermia
    • Cardiac failure
    • Arrhythmias
  • Precipitating factors:
    • Stress:
      • Acute illnesses like stroke, trauma, diabetic ketoacidosis
      • Surgery, commonly of the thyroid
      • Infections
    • Acute iodine load:
      • Radioiodine treatment of a patient with partially or untreated hyperthyroidism
      • Iodinated contrast agents
      • Amiodarone administration
  • In thyroid storm, immediate management involves controlling the heart rate, especially in cases of atrial fibrillation.
  • Beta-blockers like propranolol and esmolol are commonly used to manage symptoms and block peripheral conversion of T4 to T3.
  • However, they are contraindicated in bronchial asthma due to their bronchoconstrictive potential.
  • In asthmatic patients, diltiazem, a non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker, is used instead for rate control as it avoids bronchospasm.
  • After initial stabilization and rate control, antithyroid drugs like propylthiouracil are administered to block thyroid hormone synthesis.

Explanation of other options:

Propranolol (Option B): Beta-blocker used in thyroid storm, but contraindicated in asthma due to risk of bronchospasm.

Esmolol (Option C): Short-acting beta-blocker also used in thyroid storm; however, not preferred in asthmatics.

Propylthiouracil (Option D): Drug of choice to inhibit thyroid hormone synthesis in thyroid storm, but not used first in unstable patients with atrial fibrillation-rate control is the immediate priority.

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1681414/

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK448095/

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl presents with primary amenorrhea. Her height is 155 cm and weight is 48 kg. She has no development of breasts or axillary and pubic hair. On examination, bilateral inguinal masses are palpable. Ultrasound reveals absent uterus, fallopian tubes, and ovaries.
questions.solution:
Complete androgen insensitivity syndrome (CAIS) presents with primary amenorrhea, absent uterus and fallopian tubes, inguinal testes, sparse/absent pubic hair, and well-developed breasts due to aromatization of testosterone to estrogen.

  • The most likely diagnosis is Complete Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome (CAIS), a condition affecting individuals with a 46, XY karyotype and nonfunctional androgen receptors.
  • Due to androgen receptor resistance, their tissues cannot respond to testosterone or DHT, leading to:
    • Phenotypically female appearance
    • Well-developed breasts due to peripheral aromatization of testosterone to estradiol
    • Absent or sparse pubic and axillary hair due to lack of androgen action
    • Absent uterus, fallopian tubes, and upper vagina due to Mullerian inhibiting substance (MIS) secreted by Sertoli cells
    • Intra-abdominal or inguinal testes (as seen in the inguinal masses in this case)
    • Primary amenorrhea is the usual presenting complaint
    • Ultrasound findings of absent uterus and ovaries, no secondary sexual hair, and the presence of inguinal masses (testes) are classic for CAIS.

Hypergonadotropic hypogonadism (Option A ruled out)

  • Aetiology:
    • Usually seen in disorders with LH or hCG receptor mutations.
  • Pathophysiology:
    • It is an autosomal recessive 46, XY disorder where there are LH receptor mutations.
    • This prevents the normal hormone binding and thus reduces the number or function of Leydig cells.
    • This decreases fetal testosterone production and leads to the failure of normal male sexual differentiation.
    • The lack of testosterone leads to impaired Wolffian duct development and failure of the development of male internal genitalia.
    • This also leads to a lack of DHT which causes masculinization of the male external genitalia giving rise to female-looking external genitalia and undescended testes.
  • Features:
    • The anti-Mullerian hormone level is normal. (in XY karyotype and hence absent ovaries)
    • Decreased testosterone leads to impaired Wolffian duct development and failure of testicular descent.
    • Appear female at birth.
    • Females at puberty present with primary amenorrhea.
    • No breast and pubic hair development.
    • Raised LH level but normal FSH levels.

Explanation of other options:

Polycystic ovarian syndrome (Option C): PCOS patients have normal internal genitalia (including uterus and ovaries) and usually develop secondary sexual characteristics. Amenorrhea is due to anovulation, not absence of internal genital organs.

Turner's syndrome (Option D): Typically presents with short stature, webbed neck, and primary amenorrhea. However, uterus is present in Turner's due to absence of Y chromosome. Also, there is no development of inguinal masses (testes), as there's no testicular tissue.

choices.text: Bipartite patella, X-ray of the opposite knee
Fracture of the upper pole of the patella, Cylindrical cast

questions.text: The radiograph below depicts a patient who is experiencing persistent knee pain without any previous injury. Identify the specific condition displayed in the image and next step in management?
questions.solution:
The image shows a non-traumatic, well-corticated fragment at the patella's superolateral pole, characteristic of bipartite patella.

  • Bipartite patella is a congenital condition due to failure of fusion of accessory ossification centers, usually at the superolateral pole of the patella (Type III, most common).
  • It is often bilateral and found in about 1-2% of the population. Although usually asymptomatic, it can present with anterior knee pain, especially after repetitive activity.
  • Radiographs reveal a well-corticated bone fragment, distinguishing it from an acute fracture, which shows irregular, sharp edges.
  • MRI is useful for assessing associated soft tissue injury or bone edema if symptomatic.
  • In this case, absence of trauma and characteristic radiographic findings suggest bipartite patella.
  • The recommended next step is to perform an X-ray of the opposite knee to check for bilateral involvement.
  • Management:
    • Asymptomatic: No treatment required.
    • Symptomatic: Rest, NSAIDs, physical therapy, or in severe cases, surgery (excision of fragment).

Explanation of other options:

Patellar avulsion fracture, TBW (Option A): Avulsion fractures follow trauma and show irregular, non-corticated edges; tension band wiring (TBW) is the treatment of choice.

Fracture of the upper pole of the patella, Cylindrical cast (Option C): Patellar fractures are post-traumatic and rarely managed conservatively unless nondisplaced.

Avulsion fracture, interfragmentary screw fixation (Option D): Involves trauma with sharp fracture lines and requires fixation, not observed in this case.

choices.text: Twitching motility is seen on a wet saline mount
Cysts are seen on a wet saline mount of vaginal secretions
The infective form is a cyst

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes Trichomonas vaginalis?
questions.solution:
The statement accurately describes that Trichomonas vaginalis has twitching motility when seen on a wet saline mount.

Trichomoniasis

  • Trichomonas vaginitis is the most common cause of vaginitis in women of reproductive age.
  • The characteristic appearance seen is 'Strawberry cervix,' an erythematous and edematous cervical mucosa with characteristic punctate red papules. It is caused by microscopic punctate haemorrhages of the cervix.
  • Symptoms include :
    • Sudden, profuse, yellowish-green, frothy, foul-smelling discharge
    • Irritation and itching in and around the vaginal opening
    • Painful urination
    • Pain during intercourse
    • Recurrent infections
    • Inflamed vulva
    • Inflamed vaginal walls with small, punctate haemorrhages ("strawberry cervix")
  • The standard treatment is Metronidazole 2g PO single dose.

Explanation for other options:

Trophozoite has 2 nuclei (Option A): Trichomonas vaginalis exists only as a trophozoite, which has a single nucleus and four anterior flagella, not two nuclei.

Cysts are seen on wet saline mount of vaginal secretions (Option C): Trichomonas vaginalis does not form cysts; it exists only as a trophozoite.

Infective form is cyst (Option D): The infective form of T. vaginalis is the trophozoite, not a cyst. It is transmitted through sexual contact, and the absence of a cyst form contributes to its reliance on direct human-to-human transmission.

Key Takeaway:

choices.text: Not knowing the extent of thermal burns

questions.text: A woman is to undergo a complete laparoscopic hysterectomy and wants to know about the disadvantages of the procedure. What are the disadvantages of laparoscopic hysterectomy over open surgery?
questions.solution:
Laparoscopic hysterectomy can cause thermal burns whose extent may not be immediately evident due to limited tactile feedback and visualization.

  • While laparoscopic hysterectomy offers multiple advantages over open surgery-such as quicker recovery, reduced blood loss, and less postoperative pain-one notable disadvantage is the potential for thermal injuries from energy devices.
  • These injuries can sometimes go unrecognized intraoperatively because of the limited field of view and absence of tactile feedback in laparoscopy.
  • The extent of tissue damage from thermal sources (like monopolar or bipolar cautery) may not be visible immediately, and delayed thermal injury can present later as complications (e.g., bowel necrosis, fistulas).
  • Types of laparoscopic hysterectomy include:
    • Diagnostic laparoscopy before vaginal hysterectomy
    • Vaginal hysterectomy assisted by laparoscopy
    • Laparoscopically assisted vaginal hysterectomy (LAVH)
    • Laparoscopic hysterectomy
    • Total laparoscopic hysterectomy (TLH)
  • Advantages of laparoscopic hysterectomy over open surgery:
    • Faster recovery (Option A ruled out)
    • Less postoperative pain (Option D ruled out)
    • Reduced blood loss (Option C ruled out)
    • Shorter hospital stays
    • Lower surgical site infection rates
    • Smaller incisions and better cosmetic outcomes
    • Less analgesic requirement
    • Better patient satisfaction
  • Disadvantages include:
    • Longer operative time
    • Higher cost
    • Steeper learning curve for surgeons
    • Potential for unrecognized thermal injury, especially to bowel or ureters

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with the following lesion over the chest that developed after a traumatic injury one year ago. The lesion has progressively enlarged and now extends beyond the original wound boundary. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Keloids are excessive scar tissue formations that extend beyond the original wound margin and do not regress spontaneously.

  • Keloids result from abnormal wound healing, characterized by uncontrolled collagen deposition that causes the scar to extend beyond the original site of trauma or surgery.
  • These scars are raised, firm, and often itchy or painful.
  • They do not regress over time and are more common in individuals with darker skin types.
  • The patient's history of trauma, followed by progressive scar growth beyond the original injury boundary, strongly supports the diagnosis of a keloid.

Explanation of other options:

Hemangioma (Option A): Benign vascular tumors present from birth or early infancy; unrelated to trauma and do not present as firm scar-like lesions.


Hypertrophic scar (Option B): Raised scar confined within the boundaries of the original wound; unlike keloids, these often regress over time and are less aggressive.

Neurofibroma (Option D): Benign nerve sheath tumor associated with neurofibromatosis; not typically linked to trauma and does not resemble a scar.

choices.text: Increase in length of 25 centimetres in the first year
Weight gain of 300 grams per month till 1 year
Anterior fontanelle closure by 6 months of age
Weight under the 75th percentile and height under the 25th percentile

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant with a birth weight of 2.8 kg is brought for routine follow-up. The pediatrician wants to assess whether the child is growing appropriately. Which of the following is the best indicator of adequate growth in this infant?
questions.solution:
An increase of 25 cm in length during the first year is a reliable indicator of normal growth in infants.

  • Length gain is a consistent and dependable marker of growth.
  • At birth, the average length is approximately 50 cm.
  • By the end of the first year, the child should gain around 25 cm, reaching approximately 75 cm.
  • This increase reflects steady skeletal growth and is less affected by short-term illnesses or feeding issues compared to weight.
  • Other important milestones in height growth include:
    • At 2 years: ~85-90 cm
    • At 4-4.5 years: 100 cm
    • Growth rate: ~6 cm/year from age 2-12 years
    • Height doubles by 4 years and triples by 12 years
  • Weech's formula can be used to estimate weight and height at different ages.

Explanation of other options:

Weight gain of 300 grams per month till 1 year (Option B): Normal weight gain is not consistent throughout infancy. It is about 20-30 grams/day initially, with weight doubling by 5 months and tripling by 12 months. A fixed monthly gain of 300g is underestimated after 3-4 months and doesn't reliably indicate appropriate growth.

Anterior fontanelle closure by 6 months of age (Option C): The anterior fontanelle typically closes between 9 and 18 months. Closure by 6 months may suggest abnormal development (e.g., craniosynostosis) rather than being a normal growth indicator.

Weight under the 75th percentile and height under the 25th percentile (Option D): Percentile values must be interpreted in the context of serial growth measurements and parental height. A single percentile value does not confirm adequate or inadequate growth unless consistent with previous centiles and trends.

Reference:

https://www.pedgen.org.in/growth.php

https://journals.lww.com/njcp/fulltext/2020/23090/comparison_of_age_based_weight_estimation_with.8.aspx

questions.text: What is the long term complication of this condition ?
questions.solution:
Giant congenital melanocytic nevi carry a long-term risk of developing into malignant melanoma.

  • Congenital melanocytic nevus (CMN) is a benign melanocytic proliferation that appears at or shortly after birth.
  • These nevi are categorized based on size:
    • Small (<1.5 cm),
    • Medium (1.5-20 cm),
    • Large/Giant (>20 cm in projected adult diameter).
  • Giant CMNs, due to their extensive proliferation of melanocytes, pose an increased lifetime risk of developing malignant melanoma, especially during early childhood.
  • The transformation may occur either within the nevus or in deeper dermal or even leptomeningeal locations.
  • Clinically, CMNs appear as brown-to-black patches or plaques with well-defined borders.
  • Larger lesions may be nodular, rugose, or hairy (hypertrichosis).
  • Monitoring for rapid changes in color, size, ulceration, or new nodule formation is crucial for early detection of malignant change.

Explanation of other options:

Cataract (Option B): Cataracts are opacifications of the lens and unrelated to cutaneous melanocytic lesions.

Glaucoma (Option C): While glaucoma can occur in some oculodermal melanocytosis syndromes (e.g., nevus of Ota), it is not a known complication of CMN.

Blindness (Option D): Blindness is not directly linked with CMN unless rare complications involving the CNS or eyes occur, which are extremely uncommon.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male is found to be positive for HBsAg and HBeAg and is diagnosed with chronic hepatitis B. The viral load of the patient was 2 × 100,000, and SGPT is found to be doubled. What is the appropriate management in this patient?
questions.solution:
Tenofovir is a first-line potent antiviral agent for chronic hepatitis B with high efficacy and low resistance, recommended for long-term therapy.

  • The patient meets the criteria for chronic hepatitis B infection, confirmed by persistent HBsAg and HBeAg positivity, elevated viral load (2 × 100,000), and raised SGPT indicating active liver inflammation.
  • The goal in managing chronic HBV is to suppress viral replication, reduce hepatic inflammation, and prevent progression to cirrhosis or hepatocellular carcinoma.
  • Tenofovir is a nucleotide analog and one of the first-line oral agents for treating chronic HBV.
  • It has high potency, a favorable resistance profile, and effectively reduces HBV DNA, normalizes ALT, and improves liver histology.
  • It is administered once daily and typically continued for more than 40 weeks (usually 48-52 weeks or longer depending on clinical response).
  • Tenofovir also has a better side effect profile compared to older drugs, although monitoring for renal dysfunction and hypophosphatemia is advised.
  • Key drugs used in chronic Hepatitis B treatment include:
    • Interferons: Peginterferon alfa-2a, interferon alfa-2b
    • Nucleoside analogs: Entecavir, lamivudine, telbivudine
    • Nucleotide analogs: Adefovir, tenofovir
    • First-line oral agents:
      • Entecavir, Tenofovir
    • Second-line agents (less preferred due to resistance):
      • Lamivudine, adefovir, telbivudine
  • Duration of therapy is generally 48-52 weeks, with long-term therapy depending on viral suppression and liver response.
  • Lifestyle modification is also critical: avoid alcohol, hepatotoxic drugs, and unregulated herbal medications.

Explanation of other options:

Lamivudine for 30+ weeks (Option A): Lamivudine is an older nucleoside analog that suppresses HBV replication but has a high risk of resistance and is considered a second-line agent. Hence, not preferred over tenofovir.

Pegylated interferon for 52 weeks (Option C): Although pegylated interferon is used for finite-duration treatment, it is less tolerated, requires subcutaneous administration, and is less effective than oral agents like tenofovir in most patients.

Combined pegylated interferon with lamivudine (Option D): Combination therapy does not offer significant advantage over monotherapy and increases the risk of side effects, making it less preferred in standard management protocols.

Reference: Hepatitis B - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf

questions.text: During the removal of a submucosal fibroid by hysteroscopy, a deficit of 2000 mL is estimated in a patient. What is the immediate complication of this?
questions.solution:
Excessive absorption of hypotonic distension media during hysteroscopy can lead to pulmonary edema due to fluid overload.

  • Hysteroscopy, both diagnostic and operative, requires the use of distension media to visualize the uterine cavity.
  • During hysteroscopic myomectomy, especially when submucosal fibroids are involved, electrolyte-free hypotonic solutions like 1.5% glycine or 3% sorbitol are often used with monopolar electrosurgery.
  • These solutions can be absorbed systemically through open venous sinuses.
  • A fluid deficit >1000 mL (for hypotonic solutions) or >2500 mL (for isotonic solutions) raises significant concern for intravascular absorption.
  • A 2000 mL deficit indicates that the patient has likely absorbed a dangerous volume of hypotonic fluid.
  • This leads to fluid overload and dilutional hyponatremia, both of which predispose to pulmonary edema, the most immediate life-threatening complication.
  • Additional complications include hyponatremia, cerebral edema, heart failure, and even death in extreme cases.

Explanation of other options:

Acute tubular necrosis (Option A): ATN is a late complication caused by ischemia or nephrotoxicity; it is not the immediate effect of fluid overload during hysteroscopy.

DIC (Option B): Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation may occur in settings of massive trauma, sepsis, or obstetric catastrophes-not as an immediate result of fluid absorption.

Thromboembolism (Option D): While thromboembolism is a risk in postoperative patients, it is not the direct or immediate outcome of excessive distension fluid absorption during hysteroscopy.


Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC6676032/

questions.text: A 3-month-old baby comes with complaints of deafness, cataract, and patent ductus arteriosus. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The classical triad of deafness, cataract, and patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) strongly suggests congenital rubella syndrome.

  • Congenital Rubella Syndrome (CRS) occurs when rubella infection is acquired by the mother during early pregnancy, particularly within the first trimester.
  • The virus causes widespread fetal damage through viremia, which is most intense from 10 to 17 days after maternal infection.
  • The risk of congenital defects is highest in the first 12 weeks and significantly decreases after 20 weeks gestation.
  • The characteristic clinical features of CRS include:
    • Sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) - the most common feature
    • Ocular defects - particularly cataracts (most common), glaucoma, and "salt and pepper" retinopathy
    • Cardiac anomalies - classically patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), followed by pulmonary artery stenosis and ventricular septal defect
    • Other features: microcephaly, intellectual disability, growth retardation, hepatitis, bone lesions, and increased risk of autoimmune conditions like diabetes and thyroid disorders.

  • Diagnosis is confirmed with Rubella-specific IgM, PCR for viral RNA, or viral culture.
  • Management is supportive, with no specific antiviral treatment.
  • Prevention is crucial and is achieved through vaccination (MMR/MMRV - live attenuated RA 27/3 strain), which is highly effective (95% after one dose, 99% after two doses).
  • Pregnant women exposed to rubella may be offered immunoglobulin, but it does not reliably prevent fetal infection.

Explanation of other options:

Congenital herpes simplex virus infection (Option A): Typically presents with skin vesicles, chorioretinitis, keratoconjunctivitis, and neurological complications like microcephaly or hydranencephaly. PDA and cataracts are not hallmark features.

Congenital toxoplasmosis (Option B): The classic triad includes chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and intracranial calcifications, not PDA or cataracts.

Congenital cytomegalovirus infection (Option C): Commonly presents with microcephaly, periventricular calcifications, chorioretinitis, and sensorineural hearing loss, but PDA and cataracts are not typical.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with pain over the right thigh following bilateral laparoscopic inguinal hernia repair done two weeks ago. He describes the pain as burning and tingling in nature, localized to the lateral aspect of the thigh. On examination, there is no motor weakness. What is the most likely nerve involved?
questions.solution:
Laparoscopic hernia repairs commonly risk injury to the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh, causing meralgia paresthetica.

  • The lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh (LCNT) is a purely sensory nerve that arises from the lumbar plexus (L2-L3) and passes under the inguinal ligament near the anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS).
  • In laparoscopic hernia surgeries, particularly when mesh fixation or electrocautery is used near the triangle of pain, this nerve can be injured or entrapped, leading to meralgia paresthetica-a condition characterised by burning pain, tingling, and numbness along the lateral aspect of the thigh.
  • This region is specifically vulnerable because the LCNT lies lateral to the gonadal vessels and is one of the nerves contained in the triangle of pain, a key anatomical landmark in laparoscopic surgery.
  • Overzealous dissection or improper tack placement in this triangle can result in chronic postoperative neuralgia.
  • Key Surgical Anatomy:
    • Triangle of Pain (in laparoscopic view):
      • Medial boundary: Gonadal vessels
      • Lateral boundary: Fold of peritoneum
      • Superior boundary: Iliopubic tract
    • Contents (medial to lateral):
      • Femoral branch of genitofemoral nerve
      • Anterior cutaneous nerve of the thigh
      • Lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh
  • Common nerves injured in hernia surgeries:
    • Open repair: Ilioinguinal > Iliohypogastric > Genital branch of genitofemoral nerve
    • Laparoscopic repair: Lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh > Genitofemoral nerve

Explanation of other options:

Ilioinguinal nerve (Option A): Injury here is more common in open hernia repairs, not laparoscopic ones. It causes sensory loss over the upper medial thigh, root of penis, and scrotum-not lateral thigh pain.

Iliohypogastric nerve (Option B): Also more likely injured in open surgery. Provides sensation to the suprapubic area; does not explain isolated lateral thigh symptoms.

Femoral nerve (Option C): A mixed motor-sensory nerve; its injury leads to quadriceps weakness and sensory loss over the anterior thigh and medial leg, not isolated lateral thigh paresthesia.

choices.text: Apical segment of right lower lobe consolidation
Posterior segment of right lower lobe consolidation

questions.text: A patient presents with fever and cough for the past 5 days. On examination, crepitations are heard, and a chest X-ray is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Chest X-ray reveals a well-defined opacity in the mid-zone of the right lung with obscuration of the right heart border. Loss of the right heart border on chest X-ray indicates consolidation of the right middle lobe.

  • The clinical symptoms-fever, cough, and crepitations-along with the chest X-ray showing obscuration of the right heart border, point toward right middle lobe (RML) consolidation, most likely due to pneumonia.
  • The silhouette sign is key in localization: when a lung pathology touches a structure of similar density (like the heart), the border between them is lost.
  • Loss of the right heart border suggests pathology in either the right middle lobe or medial segment of the right lower lobe; however, the location and distribution in this case favors RML.
  • Lung anatomy relevant for radiological localization:
    • Right lung: 3 lobes (RUL, RML, RLL); divided by horizontal and oblique fissures
    • Silhouette sign helps localize:
      • Right heart border: Right middle lobe
      • Right hemidiaphragm: Right lower lobe
      • Aortic knuckle: Left upper lobe
      • Left heart border: Lingular segments of LUL





Explanation of other options:

Apical segment of right lower lobe (Option A): Would not obscure the right heart border; more posterior and inferior.

Posterior segment of right lower lobe (Option C): Affects posterior regions and diaphragm border, not the heart silhouette.

Loculated pleural effusion (Option D): Typically causes a lenticular or curvilinear opacity along the pleural surface; does not produce silhouette sign in this distribution.

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK370/#:~

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK470197/#

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/medgen/1778950

https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/medicine-and-dentistry/silhouette-sign#
