questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with complaints of sudden episodes of intense anxiety, palpitations, sweating, breathlessness, chest pain, and a feeling of impending doom. She reports having experienced 5-6 such episodes over the past 6 months, each lasting around 20-30 minutes. She remains asymptomatic between episodes. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Recurrent, acute, self-limiting episodes of intense anxiety lasting 20-30 minutes with inter-episodic normalcy is characteristic of panic disorder.

  • Panic disorder is characterized by recurrent, unexpected panic attacks-sudden surges of intense fear or discomfort that peak within minutes.
  • These attacks are often accompanied by cardiopulmonary (palpitations, chest pain, dyspnea), neurologic (dizziness, numbness), GI (nausea), and psychiatric (fear of dying or losing control) symptoms.
  • The sense of impending doom is classic.
  • In this patient, the described symptoms-sudden onset, intense episodes lasting 20-30 minutes, recurrence over 6 months, and complete resolution between episodes-are hallmark features of panic disorder.
  • Other important features:
    • Most common in young adult females
    • Anticipatory anxiety and avoidance behavior may develop
  • Diagnosis is made when these episodes recur for more than a month
  • Neurobiology: Dysregulation in norepinephrine, serotonin, GABA, and cholecystokinin pathways is implicated.
  • Treatment: First-line treatment includes SSRIs and Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT). Benzodiazepines (e.g., lorazepam, clonazepam) are used short-term for acute relief.

Explanation of other options:

Depression (Option A): Characterized by persistent low mood, anhedonia, and fatigue-not sudden episodic anxiety.

Generalized anxiety disorder (Option C): Involves chronic, excessive, uncontrollable worry across many domains, not paroxysmal attacks.

Phobia (Option D): Anxiety is triggered by specific objects or situations; not present here since the attacks are unexpected and not situationally bound.

questions.text: In the orthopedics outpatient department, a female patient is presenting with difficulty sleeping at night due to experiencing numbness and tingling in the outer three digits of their hand. The symptoms improve when the patient hangs their arms from the bed. Which of the following choices accurately identifies the patient's condition and the test employed to evaluate it?
questions.solution:
Tingling and numbness in the radial 3 1⁄2 fingers, especially worsening at night, point to carpal tunnel syndrome; the Durkan test is the most specific diagnostic test for this condition.

  • Carpal Tunnel Syndrome (CTS) is caused by compression of the median nerve as it traverses the carpal tunnel in the wrist.
  • This leads to sensory disturbances-particularly numbness, tingling, and pain-in the thumb, index, middle finger, and the radial half of the ring finger.
  • In this case:
    • The patient reports night-time numbness and tingling in the outer three fingers (i.e., median nerve distribution).
    • Relief with hand hanging (gravity-assisted decompression) further supports the diagnosis of CTS.
  • The most specific clinical test to evaluate CTS is the Durkan test (carpal compression test), which involves direct compression over the median nerve at the wrist for about 30 seconds.
    • A positive test reproduces symptoms.
  • Carpal Tunnel Syndrome - Key Points:
    • Definition: Median nerve entrapment within the carpal tunnel at the wrist.
    • Common Symptoms:
      • Paresthesia (tingling), numbness in thumb, index, middle fingers.
      • Symptoms worse at night and may improve by shaking or hanging the hand down.
      • Weak grip, dropping objects, or hand clumsiness in advanced stages.
    • Structures Affected:
      • Median nerve: Flexor tendons (9 tendons): inflammation here can compress the nerve.
    • Structures Spared:
      • Thenar eminence sensory area (supplied by palmar cutaneous branch that bypasses the carpal tunnel).
    • Clinical Signs:
      • Weak thumb abduction and opposition
      • Thenar atrophy in chronic cases
    • Common Causes:
      • Idiopathic (most common)
      • Rheumatoid arthritis, wrist osteoarthritis
      • Post-trauma (e.g., Colles' fracture)
      • Endocrine: Myxoedema, Acromegaly
    • Diagnostic Tests:
      • Durkan test: Most specific; pressure applied over the median nerve for 30 seconds reproduces symptoms.
      • Phalen test: Wrist flexion for 60 seconds causes tingling.
      • Tinel sign: Tapping on the carpal tunnel reproduces symptoms.
      • NCS/EMG: Confirmatory
    • Treatment:
      • Conservative: Wrist splinting, NSAIDs, activity modification.
      • Steroid injections
      • Surgical decompression for refractory/severe cases.

Explanation of other options:

Guyon's canal syndrome, Froment's test (Option A): Involves ulnar nerve compression at Guyon's canal, not median nerve. Froment's test checks adductor pollicis function (ulnar nerve), irrelevant in this case.

Carpal tunnel syndrome, Froment's test (Option B): CTS is correct, but Froment's test is for ulnar nerve palsy, not median nerve compression.

Guyon's canal syndrome, Durkan's test (Option C): Guyon's canal syndrome affects the ulnar nerve, not the median nerve. Also, Durkan's test is used to evaluate median nerve compression, not ulnar.

questions.text: For which of the following diagnoses in the given OT list would hysteroscopy be the preferred procedure?
questions.solution:
Asherman syndrome involves intrauterine adhesions best visualized and treated using hysteroscopy.

  • Hysteroscopy is the procedure of choice for evaluating and managing intrauterine adhesions, which are characteristic of Asherman syndrome.
  • It allows direct visualization of the uterine cavity and enables both diagnostic and therapeutic interventions such as adhesiolysis.
  • Asherman syndrome may present with infertility, amenorrhea, or recurrent miscarriage.
  • Hysteroscopy offers the advantage of real-time imaging and treatment in such cases.
  • Indications of hysteroscopy:
    • Diagnostic: AUB, infertility, recurrent miscarriage, uterine anomalies, evaluation of intrauterine pathology (e.g. Asherman syndrome).
    • Therapeutic: Adhesiolysis, polypectomy, fibroid resection (<5 cm), septal resection, endometrial ablation, foreign body removal, and hysteroscopic sterilization.
  • Contraindications include:
    • Active genital tract infection, large uterine cavity (>10 cm), known cervical/endometrial cancer, and pregnancy.

Explanation of other options:

Tubal ligation (Option A): Performed to block fallopian tubes and does not require uterine cavity visualization; hysteroscopy is not preferred.

Cervical polyp (Option C): Arises from the cervix and typically managed via speculum examination or simple removal; hysteroscopy is not indicated.

Subserosal fibroid (Option D): Grows on the outer surface of the uterus and is not accessible via hysteroscopy, which is only useful for intracavitary fibroids.

Reference:

NIH.gov Link

Medscape Link

choices.text: The threshold point is at A
At point E, the nerve is more excitable
Point C to D is due to the opening of Na+ and closure of K+ channels
Point B to D is a refractory period

questions.text: Which statement properly defines the nerve action potential curve provided?
questions.solution:
The given graph represents an action potential curve of a nerve. Point B to D represents the refractory period, a phase during which a second action potential is impossible or difficult to trigger.

This period includes the absolute refractory period (impossible to trigger a second action potential) and the relative refractory period (a second action potential can be triggered but requires a stronger stimulus).



Propagation of Action Potential:

  • Mechanism: Action potentials travel along the nerve fibre without diminishing. Depolarisation at one site causes local current flow that triggers action potentials in adjacent regions.
  • All-or-Nothing Principle: An action potential occurs only if the threshold is reached, maintaining consistent magnitude regardless of stimulus strength.

Refractory Periods: (Option D)

  • Absolute Refractory Period: Na+ channels are inactivated, preventing the generation of another action potential.
  • Relative Refractory Period: Requires a stronger stimulus to trigger another action potential due to partial repolarisation.

Myelination and Saltatory Conduction: The Myelin Sheath insulates nerve fibres, formed by Schwann cells. Action potentials "jump" between nodes of Ranvier, speeding up transmission and saving energy.

Energy Dependence: Na+-K+ Pump restores ionic gradients after an action potential, consuming ATP.

Factors Influencing Excitability:

  • Calcium Ions (Ca2+): Low extracellular Ca2+ increases excitability by lowering the activation threshold for Na+ channels; high Ca2+ decreases excitability.
  • Local Anaesthetics: Block voltage-gated Na+ channels, reducing excitability and preventing action potentials.

questions.text: A woman from western Rajasthan presents with an ulcer on her right leg, surrounded by erythema. Microscopic examination of a biopsy taken from the ulcer edge reveals organisms with dark-staining nuclei and kinetoplasts. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Leishmania tropica causes cutaneous leishmaniasis, also known as oriental sore, which is endemic in parts of Rajasthan.

  • It presents as a chronic, non-healing ulcer with surrounding erythema.
  • The amastigote form, seen on microscopy, has a characteristic dark-staining nucleus and kinetoplast inside macrophages.
  • Leishmaniasis is a vector-borne disease caused by a protozoan species belonging to the genus Leishmania. It is transmitted by sand fly vectors.

Clinical manifestations of Leishmaniasis vary, depending on the species, from cutaneous ulcers to systemic multi-organ disease.

Mucocutaneous involvement can be seen in:

a. Cutaneous Leishmaniasis (CL)

i. Old world leishmaniasis - caused by L. major/ L. tropica

ii. New world leishmaniasis - caused by L. mexicana

CL typically begins as a pink-coloured papule that enlarges, then develops into a nodule or plaque, finally forming a painless ulceration with an indurated border.

Old World CL: The ulcer is often covered with hyperkeratotic eschar. The ulcer margins may be raised (volcano sign).


New World CL: The ulcer may be covered with thick, white-yellow fibrinous material. 'Chiclero's ulcer' - multiple, small, chronic ulcers on the ear, due to multiple sandfly bites.



b. Mucosal Leishmaniasis (ML) caused by L. braziliensis

  • Characterised by mucosal destruction. The most commonly involved tissues include the nose, mouth, and nasal septum.
  • Symptoms include nasal stuffiness and mucosal bleeding, while some experience pain and deformity. Substantial disfigurement can result.

Explanation for other options:

Babesia (Option B): Babesia is an intracellular parasite that affects red blood cells, causing malaria-like hemolytic anaemia, fever, and thrombocytopenia, not skin ulcers.

Trypanosoma cruzi (Option C): Trypanosoma cruzi causes Chagas disease, which presents with Romana's sign (unilateral periorbital swelling) and cardiomyopathy, rather than cutaneous ulcers. The trypomastigote form is seen in blood smears, not in tissue biopsies.

Histoplasma (Option D): Histoplasma capsulatum is a fungus that primarily causes pulmonary infections. Though it can cause cutaneous lesions in disseminated histoplasmosis, it lacks the kinetoplast seen in protozoan parasites like Leishmania.

Key Takeaway:



Reference:

Cutaneous leishmaniasis: Clinical manifestations and diagnosis - UpToDate

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient came with complaints of palpitations, sweating, and restlessness. He has a complaint of sweaty palms. Clinical findings are depicted in the image given below. What is the diagnostic finding seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Thyroid receptor antibodies (TRAb), especially thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulins (TSI), are diagnostic of Graves' disease, which this patient exhibits.

  • The patient's symptoms-palpitations, sweating, restlessness, and sweaty palms-are classic for hyperthyroidism.
  • The most likely diagnosis is Graves' disease, an autoimmune disorder in which thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulins (TSI) bind to and activate TSH receptors on the thyroid gland.
  • This leads to increased production of T3 and T4, causing hyperthyroid symptoms.
  • In Graves' ophthalmopathy, characteristic signs include:
    • Dalrymple's sign: Upper lid retraction due to Muller's muscle contraction (most common presenting sign)
    • Von Graefe's sign: Lid lag on downward gaze and stare due to poor blinking, often earliest sign
    • Enroth's sign: Lower eyelid fullness/edema
    • Mobius sign: Weak convergence
    • Griffith's sign: Lower lid lag on upward gaze
    • Stellwag's sign: Infrequent/incomplete blinking
    • Joffroy's sign: Absent forehead wrinkling on upward gaze
    • Gellineck's sign: Hyperpigmentation of the eyelids
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by:
    • Elevated TSI or TRAb levels
    • Thyroid function tests showing elevated T3/T4 and suppressed TSH
    • Radioactive iodine uptake (RAIU): Increased in Graves'
  • Management includes:
    • Antithyroid drugs (Methimazole or PTU)
    • Radioactive iodine ablation
    • Surgery for large goiters or resistant cases
    • Graves' ophthalmopathy: Corticosteroids, radiotherapy, or orbital decompression in severe cases

Explanation of other options:

Anti-thyroglobulin antibody (Option A): Commonly elevated in autoimmune hypothyroidism like Hashimoto's, not specific for Graves'.

Anti-thyroid peroxidase antibody (Option B): Typically seen in Hashimoto's thyroiditis.

Elevated ultrasensitive thyrotropin (TSH) levels (Option D): TSH is suppressed in hyperthyroid states like Graves' disease due to negative feedback.

Reference:

Pubmed

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK582134/table/article-142674.table0/

https://eyewiki.org/Thyroid_Eye_Disease#:~:text=Eyelid%20retraction%20(Dalrymple's%20sign)%20is,bilateral%20axial%20proptosis%20(exophthalmos)

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a chronic alcoholic who arrives at the emergency department presenting with confusion, ataxia, painful eye movements, and involvement of the 6th cranial nerve?
questions.solution:
Wernicke's encephalopathy is an acute neuropsychiatric emergency due to thiamine deficiency, presenting with confusion, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia including 6th nerve palsy.

  • Wernickes encephalopathy, also known as alcoholic encephalopathy, is a life-threatening neurological condition caused by thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency, commonly seen in chronic alcoholics.
  • It presents with a classic triad:
    • Encephalopathy (confusion),
    • Oculomotor dysfunction (ophthalmoplegia, painful eye movements, nystagmus, sluggish pupillary response, 6th cranial nerve involvement), and
    • Gait ataxia.
  • The sixth cranial nerve (abducens) involvement results in lateral rectus palsy, leading to painful restricted eye movements.
  • If untreated, it may progress to Korsakoff's psychosis, which is chronic and irreversible in many cases.
  • Prompt treatment with IV thiamine is crucial for reversal.

Differences between Wernicke's and Korsakoff's syndrome:

Explanation of other options:

Delirium tremens (Option C): Acute alcohol withdrawal syndrome marked by hallucinations, tremors, tachycardia, and confusion-does not present with painful eye movements or cranial nerve involvement.

De Clerambault syndrome (Option D): A rare delusional disorder (erotomania) unrelated to alcohol or thiamine deficiency.

questions.text: A patient is brought to the emergency department after a road traffic accident. On examination, he opens his eyes only to painful stimuli, speaks inappropriate words, and withdraws his limbs in response to pain. What is the most likely Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score?
questions.solution:
The GCS score is calculated based on the patient's responses: Eye opening to pain (E2), inappropriate verbal response (V3), and withdrawal to pain (M4).

  • The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) is used to assess the level of consciousness in trauma patients.
  • It has three components:
    • Eye opening (E): To pain = 2
    • Verbal response (V): Inappropriate words = 3
    • Motor response (M): Withdraws to pain = 4
    • Thus, the total GCS = E2 + V3 + M4 = 9
  • GCS Interpretation:
    • Minor injury: GCS 15 with no loss of consciousness
    • Mild head injury: GCS 14-15 with loss of consciousness
    • Moderate head injury: GCS 9-13
    • Severe head injury: GCS 3-8
  • GCS-P is calculated by subtracting the Pupil Reactivity Score (PRS) from GCS:
    • PRS: 0 = both pupils reactive, 1 = one pupil unreactive, 2 = both unreactive
    • GCS-P range: 1-15
    • A GCS-P ≤8 indicates severe brain injury.

Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS):

Reference:

https://www.glasgowcomascale.org/what-is-gcs-p/

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK513298/

questions.text: What type of transport across the cell membrane is given below?
questions.solution:
The image represents facilitated diffusion, a passive transport that moves substances down their concentration gradient without using cellular energy, but requires the assistance of specific carrier proteins embedded in the cell membrane.

This process is essential for transporting large or polar molecules that cannot cross the cell membrane's lipid bilayer by simple diffusion.

Types of diffusion:

Explanation for other options:

Primary active transport (Option C): This active transport uses cellular energy (ATP) to transport substances against their concentration gradient. This process often involves specific carrier proteins, such as the Na+/K+ ATPase pump.

Secondary active transport (Option D): This type of active transport uses the energy stored in the form of ion concentration gradients, established by primary active transport, to drive the transport of other substances against their concentration gradient.

questions.text: A child presents with fever and a rash. Urine microscopy reveals cells with an "owl-eye" appearance. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection is associated with "owl-eye" intranuclear inclusions in infected cells, which are enlarged and found in urine, blood, or tissue biopsy.

  • In neonates, congenital CMV can present with jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly, microcephaly, and petechial rash.
  • In immunocompromised patients, CMV can cause retinitis, pneumonitis, and colitis.

Explanation for other options:

Epstein-Barr virus (Option B): Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) causes infectious mononucleosis, which presents with fever, pharyngitis, and lymphadenopathy. It is associated with atypical lymphocytes in blood smear, but not "owl-eye" inclusions in urine.

Herpes simplex virus (Option C): Herpes simplex virus (HSV) causes painful vesicular lesions in the oral or genital region. It shows multinucleated giant cells with Cowdry type A inclusions on Tzanck smear, but not "owl-eye" inclusions.

Toxoplasma gondii (Option D): Toxoplasma gondii causes congenital toxoplasmosis, which presents with chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and intracranial calcifications. It is a protozoan, and its cysts do not show "owl-eye" inclusions.

Reference:

  1. Epstein-Barr virus and renal transplantation - PubMed
  2. Cytomegalovirus Infections - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf
  3. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK482197/
  4. Toxoplasmosis - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf

choices.text: Both surface tension and compliance decreased
Both surface tension and compliance increased

questions.text: A preterm infant born at 28 weeks develops signs of respiratory distress syndrome. Which statement accurately describes the changes in surface tension and lung compliance in this condition?
questions.solution:
Surface tension increased and compliance decreased; this statement is accurate regarding surface tension and compliance in a preterm baby with respiratory distress syndrome (RDS).

Elastic tissue recoil and surface tension are the two opposing forces to lung compliance, and are not opposing forces to each other.

Two primary factors influence lung compliance:

  • Elastic forces of the lung tissue:
    • These forces are primarily determined by the presence of elastin and collagen fibres within the lung parenchyma (the functional tissue of the lungs).
    • In a deflated lung, these fibres are contracted and kinked. As the lung expands during inspiration, these fibres stretch and unkink, generating an elastic force that opposes further expansion.
  • Surface tension:
    • A thin layer of fluid lines the inside of the alveoli. At the air-fluid interface within the alveoli, surface tension arises from the stronger attraction between water molecules compared to the attraction between water molecules and air molecules.
    • This surface tension creates an inward pull, attempting to minimise the surface area of the fluid lining the alveoli. Consequently, this inward pull contributes to the elastic recoil of the lungs, making them tend to collapse.

Reference:

  1. Pulmonary Compliance - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a child brought to the orthopedics OPD with a lower limb deformity and hyperpigmented skin lesions, based on the presented X-ray of her thigh?
questions.solution:
A ground-glass lesion with shepherd's crook deformity and hyperpigmented skin lesions strongly suggests fibrous dysplasia, particularly the polyostotic form seen in McCune-Albright syndrome.

  • Fibrous Dysplasia is a non-inherited developmental anomaly caused by a postzygotic activating mutation in the GNAS1 gene.
  • This leads to the replacement of normal bone with fibro-osseous tissue, resulting in structural weakness, deformity, and risk of fractures.
  • Age group affected: Most commonly presents in children and adolescents (typically in the 2nd decade).
  • Clinical features:
    • Progressive limb deformity
    • Bone pain
    • Skin lesions: Café-au-lait spots (especially in McCune-Albright syndrome)
    • Pathological fractures
  • X-ray findings:
    • Ground-glass appearance of the bone
    • Shepherd's crook deformity of the proximal femur (varus angulation)
  • Types:
    • Monostotic: Involving a single bone
    • Polyostotic: Multiple bones involved
    • McCune-Albright Syndrome: Polyostotic fibrous dysplasia + café-au-lait macules + endocrine abnormalities (e.g. precocious puberty)
  • Management:
    • Medical: Bisphosphonates to reduce bone pain and lesion progression
    • Surgical: Correction of deformity or fixation of pathological fractures

Explanation of other options:

Non-ossifying fibroma (Option A): Typically asymptomatic and incidentally found on X-ray as eccentric, well-demarcated lytic lesions in the metaphysis of long bones. No ground-glass appearance or associated skin lesions.

Paget's disease (Option C): Occurs in older adults, not children. Characterized by disorganized bone remodeling, cortical thickening, and bowing, but does not present with skin lesions or ground-glass appearance.

Osteogenesis imperfecta (Option D): A genetic disorder of collagen synthesis leading to brittle bones and multiple fractures. Features include blue sclerae, dentinogenesis imperfecta, and hearing loss-but not ground-glass lesions or café-au-lait spots.

choices.text: Reassure and review the couple after 6 months

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman, accompanied by her mother-in-law, visits the infertility clinic. She has been having regular unprotected intercourse for the past 6 months but has not been able to conceive. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Infertility is defined as failure to conceive after at least 1 year of unprotected intercourse; hence, reassurance is appropriate at 6 months.

  • Infertility is clinically defined as the inability to conceive after 12 months of regular, unprotected intercourse.
  • Since this couple has only been trying for 6 months, the appropriate next step is to reassure them and plan a follow-up after 6 more months of attempts.
  • Early evaluation may be considered if there are known risk factors, but none are mentioned here.
  • If the couple fails to conceive after 1 year, further evaluation is indicated and is guided by suspected causes, including:
    • Ovulatory dysfunction: AMH levels, early follicular FSH ± estradiol, ovulation kits, antral follicle count
    • Tubal/pelvic disease: Hysterosalpingography, laparoscopy with chromopertubation
    • Uterine factors: TVS, saline infusion sonography, MRI, hysteroscopy ± laparoscopy
    • Male factors: Semen analysis

Explanation of other options:

Semen analysis for husband (Option A): Important in infertility workup but premature before 1 year of trying unless risk factors are present.

Hysterolaparoscopy (Option C): Invasive diagnostic procedure reserved for suspected pelvic or tubal pathology or after a longer duration of infertility.

Diagnostic hysteroscopy (Option D): Useful to evaluate intrauterine abnormalities but not indicated this early in the infertility workup.

choices.text: Echinococcus species is involved in etiology

questions.text: A patient presents with fever, abdominal pain, and jaundice. Imaging reveals the following findings. Which of the following statements is true regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
The presence of a wavy internal membrane within a liver cyst strongly suggests hydatid disease caused by Echinococcus species.

  • Hydatid disease (echinococcosis) is a parasitic infection caused by Echinococcus granulosus, commonly transmitted via contact with infected dogs.
  • Humans are intermediate hosts, infected through oral ingestion of eggs from dogs.
  • The liver is the most frequently affected organ.
  • Typical features include abdominal pain, fever, and jaundice due to pressure effects or cyst rupture.
  • Imaging often reveals a characteristic serpentine or detached germinal membrane within the cyst.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Confirmed by serology (ELISA, immunoelectrophoresis) and imaging (USG, CT, MRCP).
    • Fine-needle aspiration is generally avoided due to risk of cyst rupture and anaphylaxis.
  • Treatment:
    • Options include the PAIR technique (Puncture, Aspiration, Injection, Reaspiration) combined with albendazole or praziquantel.
    • Surgery (pericystectomy, marsupialization) is reserved for large or complicated cysts.
    • Scolicidal agents like hypertonic saline or ethanol are used intraoperatively.
    • Cyst aspiration, followed by scolicidal agent application and sealing biliary communications.
    • Laparoscopic marsupialization (deroofing) for cysts.

Explanation of other options:

Surgery is mandatory (Option A): Surgery is not always necessary; medical and percutaneous options exist, especially for uncomplicated cysts.

Fine-needle aspiration cytology is diagnostic (Option B): FNA is contraindicated due to the risk of cyst rupture and anaphylactic shock.

Angioembolization is the treatment of choice (Option C): Angioembolization is not a standard treatment in hydatid disease and is typically unrelated to its management.

questions.text: A 50-year-old HIV patient presented with a painful lesion, as shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Kaposi sarcoma presents as violaceous lesions on the skin or mucosa, commonly seen in HIV-positive individuals due to HHV-8 infection.

  • The lesion shown in the image is a violaceous plaque located on the hard palate in an HIV-positive patient, which is highly suggestive of Kaposi sarcoma (KS).
  • KS is a vascular tumor associated with human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8) and is classified as an AIDS-defining illness.
  • It typically involves the skin, oral mucosa, and internal organs like the lungs and GI tract.
  • Clinical stages:
    • Patch stage: Flat, pink or red macules.
    • Plaque stage: Raised purple or brown lesions.
    • Nodular stage: Firm, raised nodules that may ulcerate.
  • Variants of KS:
    • Classic KS: Older Mediterranean or Eastern European males.
    • Endemic KS: Seen in younger individuals in sub-Saharan Africa.
    • Transplant-associated KS: Occurs in patients on immunosuppressants.
    • AIDS-associated KS: Occurs in HIV/AIDS, especially with low CD4 counts.
  • Pathophysiology: HHV-8 infects endothelial cells, promoting angiogenesis and spindle cell proliferation.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Biopsy showing spindle cells, angiogenesis, and extravasated RBCs.
    • PCR or serology for HHV-8 may support the diagnosis.
  • Management:
    • Antiretroviral therapy (ART) is the cornerstone, as immune reconstitution leads to regression.
    • Chemotherapy (liposomal doxorubicin, paclitaxel) for extensive disease.
    • Radiotherapy or cryotherapy for localized lesions.

Explanation of other options:

Basal cell carcinoma (Option A): Typically presents as pearly nodules on sun-exposed skin, not as violaceous mucosal lesions.

Malignant melanoma (Option C): Presents as dark, irregular pigmented lesions, not characteristic violaceous plaques.

Squamous cell carcinoma (Option D): Can occur in the oral cavity but appears as ulcerated, keratotic growths, not violaceous patches.

Reference:

PubMed - 23679875

choices.text: First becomes more positive than negative

questions.text: A patient presents following a road traffic accident with significant muscle injury. Laboratory tests reveal a serum potassium level of 6.5 mEq/L. How is the resting membrane potential expected to change in this scenario?
questions.solution:
In hyperkalemia, where serum potassium levels are higher than normal (as in this patient with muscle injury), the concentration gradient of potassium ions across the cell membrane changes. The resting membrane potential in this patient becomes more positive.

Hypocalcemia:

  • When blood calcium is normal or high, calcium remains bound to the extracellular mouth of voltage-gated Na+ channels, stabilising them.
  • Low blood Ca²+ (hypocalcemia) causes calcium to detach from the channel, leading to easier sodium entry. This detachment increases Na+ channel sensitivity, enhancing excitability and action potential generation.
  • Calcium and magnesium act as membrane stabilisers.

Hyperkalemia can eventually lead to increased activity of the Na+/K+-ATPase pump as a compensatory mechanism; this is not a direct or immediate effect on the RMP.

questions.text: What could be the likely diagnosis based on the x-ray image of a 22-year-old female?
questions.solution:
An eccentric, expansile lytic lesion in the epimetaphyseal region of a skeletally mature adult is characteristic of a Giant Cell Tumor (GCT).

  • Giant Cell Tumor (GCT), also called Osteoclastoma, is a benign but locally aggressive bone tumor that typically occurs after skeletal maturity (20-45 years) and predominantly affects females.
  • It arises in the epiphyseal region of long bones, most commonly the distal femur, proximal tibia, and distal radius.
  • Clinically, patients present with swelling, pain, and occasionally pathological fractures.
  • Radiographic features:
    • Eccentric, expansile lytic lesion in the epiphysis (may extend to metaphysis).
    • Non-sclerotic margins, "soap bubble" appearance in some cases.
    • No periosteal reaction unless fractured.
  • Histologically, the lesion is composed of multinucleated giant cells dispersed uniformly in a stromal background.
  • Management:
    • Extended intralesional curettage with bone grafting or cementing is the standard.
    • Recurrence can occur.
    • Denosumab is used in certain recurrent or inoperable cases.
    • Rarely, pulmonary metastasis can occur (benign metastasizing GCT).

Explanation of other options:

Chondroblastoma (Option A): Occurs in adolescents and children (before closure of growth plates). Appears as an epiphyseal lesion but in skeletally immature patients. Biopsy shows characteristic chicken wire calcification.

Osteochondroma (Option B): Arises from the metaphysis and presents as a painless bony outgrowth. Radiographs show a pedunculated or sessile lesion with a cartilage cap.

Aneurysmal bone cyst (Option D): Seen in younger patients (first two decades). X-ray shows a multiloculated, expansile, lytic lesion with a soap-bubble appearance. Histology reveals blood-filled spaces separated by septa containing fibroblasts and giant cells.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman undergoing infertility treatment with human menopausal gonadotropin presents with sudden-onset abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and breathlessness. Ultrasound reveals a characteristic "spoke-wheel" appearance in the ovaries.
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation following hMG stimulation and the classical "spoke-wheel" USG appearance is diagnostic of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS).

  • Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS) is a serious iatrogenic complication of ovulation induction, especially with gonadotropins like hMG.
  • It results in exaggerated ovarian response with multiple cystic enlargements and increased vascular permeability.
  • This leads to third-spacing of fluid causing ascites, pleural effusion, hemoconcentration, and even thromboembolism.
  • Ultrasound shows enlarged ovaries with multiple follicles arranged in a spoke-wheel pattern.
  • Management is supportive-paracentesis for relief of discomfort, fluid monitoring, and thromboprophylaxis.

Explanation of other options:

Polycystic ovarian syndrome (Option B): Typically presents with chronic menstrual irregularities, hirsutism, and multiple small peripheral cysts on USG-not acute symptoms or spoke-wheel appearance post-ovulation induction.

Theca lutein cysts (Option C): Usually seen with high β-hCG levels, such as in molar pregnancy or multiple gestations-not commonly in OHSS-like acute settings.

Granulosa cell tumor (Option D): A rare estrogen-secreting ovarian tumor, presents more gradually with hormonal symptoms, unrelated to ovulation induction or spoke-wheel pattern.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant presents with chronic cough, failure to thrive, and recurrent respiratory infections. On examination, there are crepitations in both lungs. A sweat chloride test is ordered. Which of the following conditions is being evaluated using this test?
questions.solution:
Sweat chloride levels are elevated in cystic fibrosis, making it a key diagnostic test for this autosomal recessive disorder.

  • Cystic fibrosis (CF) is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the CFTR gene located on chromosome 7q32.
  • The CFTR protein functions as a chloride channel in epithelial cells.
  • A defect in this channel leads to abnormal ion transport, causing thickened secretions in the lungs, pancreas, and other organs.
  • The sweat chloride test is the gold standard diagnostic tool for CF.
  • It is performed using pilocarpine iontophoresis, which stimulates sweat production.
  • The sweat is collected and analyzed for chloride content.
  • Interpretation:
    • Chloride >60 mmol/L in children and adults is diagnostic of CF.
    • 30-59 mmol/L is borderline and requires further testing.
    • <30 mmol/L is generally considered normal.
  • This elevation occurs due to defective chloride reabsorption in sweat ducts. On the other hand, chloride levels are decreased in pancreatic secretions in CF.
  • Additional diagnostic tools include:
    • Genetic testing for common mutations like F508del.
    • Nasal potential difference (NPD) measurement to assess CFTR function.
    • Fecal elastase to evaluate pancreatic function.
    • Chest imaging to assess pulmonary involvement.
    • Serum electrolytes may show hyponatremic, hypochloremic, hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis due to salt loss (known as contraction alkalosis).
    • Transepithelial Intestinal and Rectal Biopsies: These can be used to directly evaluate CFTR function, though they are generally reserved for research or challenging cases.

Explanation of other options:

Phenylketonuria (Option A): Caused by a deficiency of phenylalanine hydroxylase. Diagnosed by plasma phenylalanine measurement, not sweat chloride.

Gaucher's disease (Option C): A lysosomal storage disorder due to β-glucocerebrosidase deficiency. Diagnosis is made by enzyme assays and genetic testing, not sweat chloride levels.

Osteogenesis imperfecta (Option D): A disorder of type I collagen synthesis, diagnosed by genetic testing or collagen studies, not sweat chloride analysis.

Reference:

https://www.researchgate.net/publication/5507809_Cystic_fibrosis_in_adults_Diagnostic_and_therapeutic_aspects

https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/medicine-and-dentistry/cystic-fibrosis

questions.text: A 55-year-old chronic alcoholic presents with unintentional weight loss. Laboratory findings reveal serum alkaline phosphatase (ALP) of 240 IU/L, alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) of 600 ng/ml, and normal AST and ALT levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Markedly elevated AFP with raised ALP and normal transaminases in a chronic alcoholic suggests hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC).

  • HCC is a primary liver malignancy, especially common in patients with chronic liver disease such as alcoholism.
  • A markedly elevated alpha-fetoprotein (AFP >400-500 ng/ml) is highly suggestive of HCC.
  • The patient's normal AST/ALT with elevated ALP indicates a hepatobiliary malignancy rather than inflammatory liver disease.
  • Tumor markers in HCC:
    • AFP >20 ng/ml is seen in ~70% of cases.
    • PIVKA-II (Protein Induced by Vitamin K Absence or Antagonism-II) may also be elevated.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Screening: Ultrasound (USG) for high-risk individuals.
    • Definitive imaging: Triple-phase CT scan is preferred.
      • Arterial phase: HCC shows arterial hyperenhancement.
      • Portal venous phase: Washout begins.
      • Delayed phase: Lesion appears hypodense due to venous washout - a classic feature of HCC.
  • Risk factors for HCC:
    • Cirrhosis, chronic alcohol use, HBV/HCV infections, NAFLD, aflatoxin exposure, anabolic steroids, and several genetic/metabolic disorders (e.g., Wilson's disease, α1-antitrypsin deficiency, porphyria cutanea tarda).

Explanation of other options:

Hepatic adenoma (Option A): Typically occurs in young women using oral contraceptives and does not elevate AFP.

Cholangiocarcinoma (Option B): May raise ALP but not AFP; associated with bile duct origin.

Alcoholic hepatitis (Option D): Usually shows elevated AST > ALT, not normal transaminases or elevated AFP.

questions.text: Infection with Clonorchis sinensis is linked to an increased risk of developing which type of cancer?
questions.solution:
Clonorchis sinensis is a liver fluke that infects the biliary ducts, leading to chronic inflammation, epithelial hyperplasia, and fibrosis, which increase the risk of cholangiocarcinoma (bile duct cancer).

Cholangiocarcinoma: It is an aggressive adenocarcinoma of the bile ducts, commonly presenting as obstructive jaundice.

Risk Factors

  • Biliary and Liver Conditions:
    • Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC)
    • Choledochal cyst
    • Hepatolithiasis
    • Caroli's disease
  • Infections:
    • Clonorchis sinensis infestation
    • Hepatitis B and C (risk factors for intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma)
  • Genetic Conditions:
    • Lynch syndrome II
  • Other Conditions:
    • Multiple biliary papillomatosis
    • Previous biliary-enteric anastomosis
  • Toxins:
    • Thorotrast
    • Nitrosamines
    • Dioxin

Types based on its location

Clinical Features

  • Primary Presentation:
    • Painless obstructive jaundice of short duration
  • Liver Changes:
    • Palpable liver, which may be smooth and soft (hydrohepatotic) or hard and nodular (secondaries)
  • Other Symptoms:
    • Weight loss and anorexia (typical and significant)
  • Gender Prevalence:
    • More common in men (1.5:1)

Explanation for other options:

Cervical cancer (Option A): Cervical cancer is primarily caused by persistent HPV (Human Papillomavirus) infection, not Clonorchis sinensis.

Gastric carcinoma (Option C): Chronic infection with Helicobacter pylori is a major risk factor for gastric carcinoma, but Clonorchis sinensis is not involved in gastric cancer development.

Bladder carcinoma (Option D): Schistosoma haematobium, not Clonorchis sinensis, is associated with bladder carcinoma, particularly squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder, due to chronic inflammation and irritation.

Reference:

  1. Types of cholangiocarcinoma

questions.text: A patient is brought to the OPD by his wife, who reports that he has difficulty expressing emotions and is not participating in daily activities. On clinical examination, the patient shows resting tremors and rigidity. Considering the likely diagnosis, which part of the brain is most likely affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Basal ganglia degeneration, particularly in the substantia nigra, leads to the classic motor symptoms of Parkinson's disease including resting tremors and rigidity.

  • The patient's symptoms-difficulty expressing emotions, reduced participation in daily activities, along with resting tremors and rigidity-are classic features of Parkinson's disease, a neurodegenerative disorder primarily involving the basal ganglia.
  • More specifically, the substantia nigra pars compacta, a component of the basal ganglia, undergoes dopaminergic neuron degeneration, leading to dopamine deficiency in the striatal pathways.
  • This disrupts the balance of the direct and indirect motor pathways, resulting in motor symptoms like bradykinesia, resting tremors, rigidity, and later, postural instability.
  • Additionally, non-motor features such as emotional blunting and apathy are linked to dysfunction in the limbic circuits of the basal ganglia.
  • Key features of Parkinson's disease:
    • Rigidity: Resistance to passive limb movement ("lead-pipe" or "cogwheel").
    • Resting tremor: Classically described as "pill-rolling" tremor.
    • Bradykinesia: General slowness of voluntary movement.
    • Postural instability: Late features causing impaired balance and frequent falls.

Explanation of other options:

Hippocampus (Option B): Involved mainly in memory consolidation and spatial learning; not associated with motor features like tremor or rigidity.

Cerebellum (Option C): Lesions cause intention tremor, ataxia, and dysmetria-not the resting tremor or rigidity seen in Parkinson's disease.

Premotor cortex (Option D): Responsible for motor planning and initiation. Lesions here may cause apraxia but are not the primary site of pathology in Parkinson's disease.

Brain Lesions Locations and their Consequences:

Reference:

https://journals.plos.org/ploscompbiol/article?id=10.1371/journal.pcbi.1000408

https://academic.oup.com/brain/article/138/10/3061/2468715

questions.text: A patient presents with features of chronic pancreatitis, including recurrent attacks, and is found to have a 10 mm dilated pancreatic duct with intraductal calculi. Which of the following is the surgery of choice?
questions.solution:
Longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy is the procedure of choice in chronic pancreatitis with a significantly dilated duct (>7 mm) and intraductal stones to relieve obstruction and pain.

  • In chronic pancreatitis with a dilated pancreatic duct (≥7 mm) and intraductal calculi, the preferred surgical approach is Longitudinal Pancreaticojejunostomy (LPJ), also known as the Puestow procedure.
  • This technique involves opening the pancreatic duct along its length and anastomosing it to a loop of jejunum, thereby decompressing the duct and facilitating drainage of secretions and stones.
  • Rationale for LPJ:
    • Indicated when the main pancreatic duct is ≥7 mm with obstruction or stones.
    • Relieves pain caused by ductal hypertension.
    • Preserves pancreatic parenchyma.
    • Especially effective in patients with large duct disease.
  • Management overview of Chronic Pancreatitis:
    • Medical Management:
      • Pain management: Analgesics, enzyme supplementation (reduce pancreatic stimulation).
      • Diet: Low-fat, high-protein, high-carbohydrate diet.
      • Micronutrients: Supplementation of fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E, K), vitamin B12, selenium, methionine, vitamin C, and E.
      • Enzyme supplementation: Reduces steatorrhea and may relieve pain.
      • Diabetes management: Often required due to islet cell damage.
    • Endoscopic Interventions:
      • ERCP with stenting or sphincterotomy: For patients with strictures or papillary stenosis but not first-line for large duct calculi.
    • Surgical Interventions:
      • LPJ (Puestow Procedure): For dilated duct with intraductal stones - surgery of choice in this case.
      • Frey Procedure: Combines LPJ with coring of pancreatic head, suitable when disease affects the head.
      • Beger Procedure or Pancreaticoduodenectomy (Whipple): Used when there is a mass lesion in the head.
      • Distal Pancreatectomy: For isolated tail disease.
      • Total Pancreatectomy: Reserved for diffuse disease and intractable pain.
  • For a patient with recurrent attacks of chronic pancreatitis, 10 mm dilated pancreatic duct, and intraductal calculi, the best surgical treatment is Longitudinal Pancreaticojejunostomy, as it directly decompresses the dilated duct and relieves obstruction.

Explanation of other options:

Pancreaticoduodenectomy (Option A): Major resection indicated for malignancies or mass lesions in the pancreatic head, not the treatment of choice for large duct chronic pancreatitis without a head mass.

ERCP and sphincterotomy (Option C): Useful in strictures or papillary stenosis, but less effective for large duct disease with calculi; also not long-term curative.

Coring of the pancreas head (Option D): Frey's procedure, indicated when there is disease in the head of pancreas; not preferred when the main duct is diffusely dilated with stones and no dominant head disease.

questions.text: A 45-year-old HIV-positive male presents with persistent cough and weight loss. He has skin lesions described as umbilicated papules and nodules on the face, trunk, and upper extremities. Chest X-ray reveals multiple bilateral nodular infiltrates. His sputum CBNAAT for tuberculosis is negative, and his CD4 count is low. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Disseminated histoplasmosis commonly presents with systemic symptoms, pulmonary infiltrates, and skin lesions in immunocompromised individuals, particularly those with HIV and low CD4 counts.

  • Histoplasma capsulatum, a dimorphic fungus, causes disseminated histoplasmosis in immunocompromised patients, especially those with CD4+ counts <200/μL.
  • Infection is acquired via inhalation of microconidia from bird or bat droppings.
  • In such patients, the yeast forms multiply within macrophages and spread systemically.
  • Clinical features of progressive disseminated histoplasmosis (PDH) include fever, weight loss, hepatosplenomegaly, pancytopenia, diffuse interstitial or reticulonodular pulmonary infiltrates, and characteristic skin lesions (papules, plaques, ulcers, sometimes umbilicated in ~10% cases).
  • Diagnosis involves urine or serum antigen testing, fungal cultures, and histopathological identification of yeast within macrophages.
  • Treatment: Liposomal amphotericin B is used for induction in severe cases, followed by oral itraconazole maintenance for ≥12 months.

Explanation of other options:

HIV with disseminated cryptococcosis (Option B): Cryptococcosis usually presents with meningeal involvement; the absence of neurological signs and predominant lung and skin involvement makes this less likely.

HIV with molluscum contagiosum (Option C): While the patient has umbilicated papules, molluscum contagiosum does not explain systemic symptoms or lung infiltrates.

HIV with tuberculosis (Option D): Although TB is common in HIV, a negative sputum CBNAAT and bilateral nodular infiltrates without typical granulomatous findings reduce its likelihood.

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3687172/

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3969680/

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman undergoes a diagnostic mammogram for a palpable breast lump. Imaging reveals a BIRADS-5 lesion. A core needle biopsy confirms invasive ductal carcinoma. Which of the following findings, if present, would be considered a good prognostic factor for this lesion?
questions.solution:
Estrogen receptor (ER) positivity indicates hormone sensitivity and is associated with a more favorable prognosis and treatment response.

  • BIRADS-5 lesion on breast imaging is highly suspicious for malignancy, with a >95% likelihood of cancer.
  • Once a breast carcinoma is confirmed, the prognosis depends on several tumor biology markers and patient-related factors.
  • ER (Estrogen Receptor) positivity is a favorable prognostic marker.
  • Tumors that express ER (and/or PR) are typically less aggressive, have slower growth, and respond well to hormonal therapies like tamoxifen or aromatase inhibitors.
  • These patients tend to have better long-term survival outcomes.
  • In contrast, markers such as BRCA mutations, p53 overexpression, and high Ki-67 are usually associated with more aggressive disease and poorer outcomes.

Explanation of other options:

p53 positive (Option B): Mutations or overexpression of the tumor suppressor gene p53 are associated with genomic instability and aggressive tumor behavior, correlating with poor outcomes.

High Ki-67 (Option D): Ki-67 is a cell proliferation marker. A high index suggests rapid tumor growth, which typically indicates a worse prognosis, although in some aggressive cancers it may predict chemosensitivity.

questions.text: A patient presents with a chronic dry cough, fever, and weight loss. He was diagnosed with HIV six months ago but has not been consistently taking his medications. Gomori methenamine silver (GMS) staining of bronchoalveolar lavage shows organisms with a "crushed ping-pong ball" appearance. What is the most likely causative pathogen?
questions.solution:
Pneumocystis jirovecii is an opportunistic fungal pathogen that causes Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP), especially in HIV/AIDS patients with CD4 counts <200 cells/µL.

  • The Gomori methenamine silver (GMS) stain reveals round, crushed ping-pong ball-like cysts, which are characteristic of P. jirovecii.

Pneumocystis jirovecii

Cause and Transmission:

  • Opportunistic Pathogen:
    • Primarily affects immunocompromised individuals (e.g., HIV/AIDS patients with CD4+ counts <200 cells/mm³).
  • Colonisation in Healthy Individuals:
    • Common in healthy lungs; most children are exposed by age 4.
    • Reactivation in adults is possible from childhood exposure or new infections.
  • Airborne Transmission:
    • Spreads through person-to-person contact, especially in hospital settings.
    • Colonised individuals exhale the organism, contaminating the environment.
  • Reinfection vs. Reactivation:
    • Both reinfection with new strains and reactivation of dormant infection are possible causes of recurrent PCP.
  • Environmental Reservoir:
    • Exact environmental source unknown, but the organism has been found in air samples near infected patients.

Clinical Features:

  • General Symptoms
    • Fever
    • Nonproductive cough
    • Dyspnea (shortness of breath)
    • Tachypnea (rapid breathing)

Explanation for other options:

Paracoccidioides brasiliensis (Option A): Paracoccidioides brasiliensis causes paracoccidioidomycosis, commonly found in South America. The yeast form appears as pilot wheel (captain's wheel) structures on staining, not ping-pong ball-like cysts.

Histoplasma capsulatum (Option B): Histoplasma capsulatum causes histoplasmosis, which may present with disseminated infection in AIDS patients. The yeast form appears as intracellular budding yeast within macrophages on GMS stain, not a crushed ping-pong ball appearance.

Coccidioides immitis (Option C): Coccidioides immitis causes coccidioidomycosis (Valley fever) and forms spherules containing endospores, not crushed ping-pong ball structures.

Reference:

  1. The Pathogenesis and Diagnosis of Pneumocystis jiroveci Pneumonia - PMC
  2. Pneumocystis Pneumonia in Human Immunodeficiency Virus-infected Adults and Adolescents: Current Concepts and Future Directions - PMC

questions.text: A male patient presented to the emergency room with seizures. He has a history of fever, headache, and confusion. An MRI brain was done, and it showed inflammation involving the bitemporal lobes. What is the most likely aetiology for this presentation?
questions.solution:
HSV encephalitis classically involves the bitemporal lobes and presents with fever, seizures, confusion, and behavioural changes.

Explanation of other options:

Cytomegalovirus (Option A): Typically seen in immunocompromised individuals; MRI shows periventricular calcifications and ventricular enlargement, not bitemporal lobe involvement.

Toxoplasma gondii (Option B): Common in immunocompromised hosts; presents with multiple ring-enhancing lesions in the basal ganglia or corticomedullary junction, not the temporal lobes.

Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Option D): TB meningitis or encephalitis presents with diffuse cortical involvement and basal exudates; bitemporal localisation is not characteristic.

Reference:Radiopaedia: Tuberculous Encephalopathy

questions.text: A primigravida presents to you with anemia early in her pregnancy. She is 7 weeks pregnant, as confirmed by ultrasound. Her haemoglobin level is 9 g/dL. When should iron supplements be started for her?
questions.solution:
In anaemic pregnant women, oral iron therapy should be initiated as early as possible, ideally from 8 to 10 weeks of gestation.

  • This primigravida is 7 weeks pregnant and has a haemoglobin level of 9 g/dL, indicating moderate anemia.
  • According to anaemia management protocols, treatment should be initiated early using oral iron and folic acid supplementation (2 tablets of 60 mg elemental iron + 500 mcg folic acid).
  • For women with pre-existing anaemia, iron supplementation must be started as early as possible-between 8 to 10 weeks-to correct anaemia, prevent further haemoglobin decline, and support fetal development.
  • Delaying treatment increases the risk of adverse maternal and fetal outcomes.

Explanation of other options:

10 to 12 weeks (Option A): Early second trimester initiation is acceptable for non-anaemic women as prophylaxis, but not for those already anaemic.

After 14 weeks (Option C): Delaying therapy in an anaemic woman risks further haemoglobin decline and fetal compromise.

After 20 weeks (Option D): Initiating treatment this late may lead to severe anaemia complications in both mother and fetus.

Reference: https://www.nhm.gov.in/images/pdf/Nutrition/AMB-guidelines/anaemia-Mukt-Bharat-Operational-Guidelines-FINAL.pdf

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC5885006/#CR35

https://www.who.int/data/nutrition/nlis/info/antenatal-iron-supplementation

questions.text: A pregnant woman comes to the Gynaecology OPD with a positive urine pregnancy test (UPT). She already has twins delivered via normal vaginal delivery in a previous pregnancy. Which of the following is the correct representation of her obstetric score?
questions.solution:
Twin delivery counts as a single parity event, so with one previous twin delivery and a current pregnancy, the obstetric score is G2P1.

  • The obstetric score system includes Gravida (G) for the number of total pregnancies (including the current one) and Parity (P) for the number of pregnancies carried beyond the period of viability (≥28 weeks in India), regardless of the number of babies born.
  • In this scenario:
    • The woman is currently pregnant (1 gravida)
    • She had one prior pregnancy which resulted in twin live births through a normal vaginal delivery
    • Twin pregnancy counts as ONE in both gravida and parity
    • Thus:
      • Gravida = 2 (previous twin pregnancy + current pregnancy)
      • Parity = 1 (because the twin delivery counts as one delivery event)
      • Hence, her obstetric score is G2P1.

Reference: https://nhm.hp.gov.in/storage/app/media/uploaded-files/mtp-amendment-act2021.pdf

choices.text: Subacute combined degeneration of the cord

questions.text: A male patient presents with sensory loss and limb weakness for 3 months. He also has angular stomatitis. On examination, there is loss of proprioception and vibration sensation, UMN-type weakness in the lower limbs, and absent ankle reflexes. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Vitamin B12 deficiency causes subacute combined degeneration with posterior column and corticospinal tract involvement, explaining the mixed sensory and UMN findings.

Subacute Combined Degeneration of the Cord (SACD)

  • Neurological disorder due to vitamin B12 deficiency, causing demyelination of the posterior columns and lateral corticospinal tracts.
  • Etiology
    • Vitamin B12 Deficiency:
      • Pernicious anemia.
      • Gastrectomy or ileal resection.
      • Diphyllobothrium latum infestation.
      • Long-term use of metformin or PPIs.
  • Affected Areas
    • Posterior columns: Loss of proprioception and vibration sense.
    • Lateral corticospinal tracts: Spasticity and UMN-type weakness.
  • Clinical Features
    • Sensory Symptoms:
      • Loss of proprioception and vibration sense: Begins in lower limbs, may progress to upper limbs.
      • Sensory ataxia: Positive Romberg's test (difficulty standing with eyes closed).
      • Paresthesia: Tingling or numbness in extremities, typically in a glove-and-stocking distribution.
    • Motor Symptoms:
      • Upper motor neuron signs: Weakness, spasticity, and hyperreflexia.
      • Spastic weakness: Due to lateral corticospinal tract involvement.
      • Absent ankle reflex: A key finding, coexisting with UMN signs due to concurrent peripheral neuropathy
  • Signs:
    • Lhermitte's Sign: Electric shock-like sensation down the spine on neck flexion.
    • Angular stomatitis
    • Optic neuropathy
  • Non-neurological Features:
    • Megaloblastic anemia: fatigue, pallor, glossitis, and jaundice.
  • Psychiatric Symptoms:
    • Irritability, dementia, psychosis.
    • Depression and memory loss.
  • Treatment
    • Vitamin B12 Replacement:
      • IM cyanocobalamin or hydroxocobalamin.
      • Oral B12 for maintenance.
    • Address underlying causes (e.g., anemia, parasitic infestation).

Explanation of other options:

Extradural cord compression (Option A): Presents with localized back pain, radicular symptoms, asymmetric deficits, and early bladder/bowel dysfunction. It doesn't explain angular stomatitis or symmetrical sensory loss.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (Option B): ALS involves UMN and LMN signs without sensory involvement. Sensory deficits and angular stomatitis rule this out.

Multiple sclerosis (Option C): MS presents with optic neuritis, sensory changes, and gait issues, often with remissions. However, angular stomatitis and absent ankle reflex with UMN signs are not typical features.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with sudden, severe chest pain radiating to the neck and interscapular region. On examination, his blood pressure is 110/90 mmHg in the right upper limb and 160/100 mmHg in the left upper limb. Chest X-ray reveals a widened mediastinum. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Acute aortic dissection presents with tearing chest pain radiating to the back and unequal limb blood pressures, with widened mediastinum on X-ray.

  • Acute aortic dissection results from a tear in the intimal layer of the aorta, allowing blood to enter the media and create a false lumen.
  • This can compromise perfusion to branch vessels, explaining the asymmetrical blood pressure in the upper limbs.
  • Clinically, it presents with sudden, severe, tearing chest pain that may radiate to the back, particularly the interscapular region.
  • Chest X-ray may reveal a widened mediastinum, and in some cases, a left-sided pleural effusion may be seen.
  • DeBakey Classification(Based on the pattern of dissection):
    • Type I : Both ascending and descending aorta are involved
    • Type II : Only the ascending aorta is involved
    • Type III : Only the descending aorta is involved
  • Stanford Classification(Based on whether the ascending aorta is involved in aortic dissection):
    • Type A: Involves ascending aorta (includes DeBakey I & II) - requires surgical management.
    • Type B: Involves descending aorta only (DeBakey III) - often managed medically unless complications arise.
  • Investigations:
    • CT angiography is the investigation of choice in stable patients.
    • Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) is preferred in unstable patients.
    • MRI may be used if CT is inconclusive.

Explanation of other options:

Acute coronary syndrome (Option A): Presents with central chest pain radiating to the arm/jaw, often with sweating. Does not cause blood pressure differences between limbs or mediastinal widening.

Acute pulmonary embolism (Option B): Causes sudden-onset dyspnea, chest pain, tachycardia. Widened mediastinum and BP discrepancy are not typical features.

Esophageal rupture (Option D): Usually follows forceful vomiting (e.g., Boerhaave's syndrome), presenting with chest pain and mediastinal emphysema, not typically with widened mediastinum or asymmetric BP.

questions.text: A child presents with fever and a rash that begins on the face, particularly behind the ears, cheeks, and buccal mucosa, and then spreads to the rest of the body. On examination, characteristic Koplik's spots are seen on the buccal mucosa.
questions.solution:
Koplik's spots along with a descending maculopapular rash and prodromal symptoms confirm the diagnosis of measles.

  • Measles (rubeola) is a highly contagious viral illness caused by an RNA virus of the Paramyxoviridae family.
  • It typically affects children, especially those who are unvaccinated.
  • The classic clinical course involves:
    • Prodrome (3-4 days): High fever, cough, coryza (runny nose), and conjunctivitis-collectively known as the 3 C's.
    • Koplik's spots: These are pathognomonic and appear on the 2nd or 3rd day of illness. They are tiny bluish-white spots with a red halo, typically found on the buccal mucosa opposite the lower molars.
    • Rash (exanthem): Appears on the 4th day of illness, starting behind the ears and spreading to the face, trunk, and limbs in a cephalocaudal pattern. The rash is erythematous, maculopapular, and often confluent.
    • Course: The rash fades in the order it appeared, leaving behind brownish discoloration and fine desquamation.
  • Measles is transmitted via droplet nuclei from respiratory secretions and is contagious from 3 days before to 4 days after the onset of rash.
  • Management is mainly supportive, with antipyretics, hydration, and vitamin A supplementation.

Explanation of other options:

Rubella (Option B): Rubella also causes a maculopapular rash that begins on the face and spreads, but it is milder, non-confluent, and often associated with postauricular and occipital lymphadenopathy. Forchheimer spots (rose-colored spots on the soft palate) may be seen, not Koplik's spots.

Varicella (Option C): Caused by the varicella-zoster virus, it presents with a pruritic rash appearing in crops at different stages (macules → papules → vesicles → crusts), typically starting on the trunk. Koplik's spots are not seen in varicella.

Mumps (Option D): Caused by a paramyxovirus, mumps presents with parotitis, fever, and sometimes orchitis or meningitis. A rash is uncommon, and Koplik's spots are absent.

questions.text: A 27-year-old pregnant woman, G3P2L2, presents at 36 weeks and 6 days of gestation. She has had two prior normal vaginal deliveries. On ultrasound, the fetus is in transverse lie. The liquor volume is adequate, and placenta appears normal. There are no maternal or fetal risk factors. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
External cephalic version (ECV) is the appropriate next step in a term transverse lie if there are no contraindications.

  • In cases of transverse lie at term (≥36 weeks), external cephalic version (ECV) is considered the first-line management if there are no contraindications.
  • The goal of ECV is to manually turn the fetus to a cephalic position to facilitate vaginal delivery and avoid a cesarean section.
  • This woman is G3P2L2, and her history of normal vaginal deliveries further increases the chances of successful ECV.
  • Adequate amniotic fluid and a normal placenta also make her a good candidate.
  • Timing:
    • ECV is typically attempted at ≥36 weeks in multiparous women (as here) and ≥37 weeks in primigravida, to reduce risk of spontaneous reversion or complications.
  • If ECV fails or is contraindicated, cesarean section becomes the delivery of choice due to the risks of labor in transverse lie (e.g. cord prolapse, obstructed labor).

Explanation of other options:

Cesarean section (Option A): While it may be required if ECV fails or is contraindicated, it is not the first step in a stable term transverse lie with favorable conditions.

Expectant management (Option C): Not appropriate in transverse lie at term due to the risk of complications like cord prolapse or obstructed labor.

Induction of labour (Option D): Contraindicated in transverse lie, as the presenting part is not engaged and labor induction can lead to complications.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents with complaints of chest pain, palpitations, and shortness of breath. On examination, a mid-diastolic murmur is heard, and a prominent 'a' wave is noted in the jugular venous pulse (JVP). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A mid-diastolic murmur with a prominent 'a' wave in JVP points towards tricuspid stenosis, due to impaired right atrial emptying and elevated right atrial pressure.

  • Tricuspid stenosis (TS) is characterized by narrowing of the tricuspid valve, leading to obstruction of blood flow from the right atrium to the right ventricle during diastole.
  • This results in elevated right atrial pressure, producing a prominent 'a' wave in JVP, due to forceful atrial contraction against a stenotic valve.
  • The mid-diastolic murmur is typically heard best at the lower left sternal border or over the xiphoid and is accentuated during inspiration (Carvallo's sign), due to increased venous return to the right heart.
  • Other features include right atrial enlargement, evident as tall, peaked P waves in inferior leads (II, III, aVF) on ECG.
  • Hepatomegaly, ascites, and peripheral edema may also be present in advanced cases.

Types of Murmurs:

questions.text: A sewage worker presents with a 5-day history of abdominal pain, jaundice, conjunctival suffusion, and hematuria. Which investigation is most appropriate to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The microscopic agglutination test (MAT) is the gold standard test for diagnosing Leptospirosis, as the given symptoms are attributed to Leptospira infection.

  • It detects Leptospira-specific antibodies by agglutination of live leptospiral antigens.
  • It is highly sensitive and specific for confirming leptospiral infection.

Explanation for other options:

Widal test (Option A): The Widal test is used for typhoid fever (Salmonella typhi) and is not useful for diagnosing Leptospirosis.

Weil-Felix reaction (Option C): Weil-Felix is a serological test for Rickettsial infections and is not specific for Leptospirosis.

Paul-Bunnell test (Option D): The Paul-Bunnell test is used to detect heterophile antibodies in infectious mononucleosis (caused by Epstein-Barr virus) and has no role in diagnosing Leptospirosis.

Key Takeaway:

Reference:Leptospirosis - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf

questions.text: A patient arrives with pain in the right upper abdomen. One week ago, the patient experienced a bout of diarrhoea. An abdominal CT scan shows a solitary liver abscess measuring approximately 25 cubic centimetres. What should be the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
A small, uncomplicated liver abscess (≤5 cm or ~25 cc) in a stable patient is initially managed with medical therapy using broad-spectrum antibiotics.

  • Liver abscesses are commonly of pyogenic or amoebic origin.
  • In this case, the history of preceding diarrhoea and solitary liver abscess suggests a likely amoebic or secondary pyogenic abscess.
  • For abscesses that are small (≤5 cm or ≤30 cc), medical management is the first line, especially if the patient is stable and there are no features of rupture, sepsis, or multiloculated abscess.
  • Medical therapy involves:
    • Empiric broad-spectrum antibiotics for pyogenic abscesses (e.g., 3rd gen cephalosporins + metronidazole).
    • Metronidazole is also the drug of choice for amoebic abscesses.
  • Clinical and radiological monitoring is done.
  • Intervention (like percutaneous drainage) is only considered if:
    • There is no improvement within 48-72 hours.
    • The abscess is large (>5 cm), multiloculated, or about to rupture.
    • The patient is clinically deteriorating.

Explanation of other options:

PAIR (Option A): Puncture-Aspiration-Injection-Reaspiration is primarily used for hydatid cysts of the liver, not for pyogenic or amoebic abscesses.

Surgery (Option B): Reserved for complicated abscesses, such as those with rupture, inaccessible for percutaneous drainage, or secondary to intra-abdominal pathology (e.g., appendicitis). Not first-line for a small, uncomplicated abscess.

Percutaneous drainage (Option D): Indicated in larger abscesses (>5 cm) or when no response to medical therapy. For a 25 cc abscess, drainage is not routinely required unless there is clinical deterioration.

questions.text: A woman presents to you at 36 weeks of gestation with complaints of breathlessness and excessive abdominal distension. Fetal movements are normal. On examination, fetal parts are not easily felt, and fetal heartbeat is heard but muffled. Her symphysis-fundal height is 41 cm. Her abdomen is tense but not tender. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Polyhydramnios is characterized by excessive amniotic fluid, leading to a tense abdomen, increased fundal height, and difficulty palpating fetal parts.

  • The clinical features-excessive abdominal distension, increased symphysis-fundal height (41 cm at 36 weeks), muffled fetal heart sounds, and difficulty feeling fetal parts-are classic signs of polyhydramnios, which is the excessive accumulation of amniotic fluid.
  • Polyhydramnios can occur due to multiple fetal, maternal, or placental causes.
  • In women without diabetes or hypertension, fetal anomalies (like anencephaly or esophageal atresia) account for approximately 50% of cases.
  • Mechanisms include:
    • Leakage from fetal meninges in neural tube defects
    • Absent or impaired fetal swallowing
    • Increased fetal urine output due to suppressed ADH
  • Classification based on Amniotic Fluid Index (AFI):
    • Mild: 25-29.9 cm
    • Moderate: 30-34.9 cm
    • Severe: ≥35 cm
  • Etiologies of polyhydramnios:
    • Fetal causes: Anomalies (anencephaly, esophageal atresia), twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome, hydrops fetalis
    • Maternal causes: Diabetes mellitus, cardiac disease, renal disorders
    • Placental causes: Chorioangioma

Explanation of other options:

Abruptio placenta (Option A): Refers to premature separation of the placenta, presenting with painful vaginal bleeding, abdominal pain, and a firm, tender uterus-not seen here.

Hydrocephalus of fetus (Option B): Causes enlarged fetal head and may complicate delivery, but does not typically present with generalized abdominal distension and increased fundal height to this extent.

Fetal-maternal ascites (Option D): Involves fluid accumulation in fetal compartments (hydrops fetalis), but would usually present with additional findings like fetal edema, pleural/ascitic effusion, and skin changes.

choices.text: Antigen detection in the stool sample

questions.text: Which laboratory test is commonly used to confirm the diagnosis of rotavirus-induced diarrhoea?
questions.solution:
Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) and latex agglutination tests are commonly used to detect rotavirus antigen (VP6 protein) in stool samples. This is the most sensitive and specific test for diagnosing rotavirus infection.

Sandwich ELISA Procedure:

  1. Coating: Coat microtiter wells with goat anti-rotavirus antibody; add sample and incubate (overnight at 4°C or 2 hours at 37°C).
  2. Detection Antibody: Add enzyme-labelled anti-rotavirus antibody (e.g., with alkaline phosphatase) and incubate.
  3. Substrate Addition: Add para-nitrophenyl phosphate; enzyme activity causes a colour change if rotavirus is present.
  4. Interpretation: Yellow colour development confirms a positive test; the ELISA reader provides quantitative colour readings.

Explanation for other options:

Antigen detection in blood (Option B): Rotavirus primarily affects the gastrointestinal tract and does not cause significant viremia; therefore, detecting antigens in blood is not a standard diagnostic method.

Antibody detection in serum (Option C): While serology can detect past exposure to rotavirus, it is not useful for acute diagnosis, as antibodies appear later in the infection.

Light microscopy of stool specimen (Option D): Routine light microscopy does not detect rotavirus, as the virus is too small to be seen. However, electron microscopy can visualise viral particles but is not routinely used due to cost and expertise requirements.

Reference:Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with confusion and ataxia one week after experiencing trauma. He has a significant history of chronic alcohol use, with his last drink two weeks ago. A CT scan reveals the following findings. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
CT scan reveals a crescent-shaped collection of blood following the contours of the brain and crossing suture lines. A crescent-shaped hemorrhage on CT that crosses suture lines is characteristic of subdural hematoma, commonly due to bridging vein rupture.

  • Subdural hemorrhage (SDH) typically results from tearing of the bridging veins that traverse between the brain surface and the dural sinuses.
  • It is often seen in elderly or alcoholic patients following minor trauma due to cerebral atrophy, which stretches the veins.
  • CT scan shows a crescent-shaped hyperdense collection that conforms to the shape of the brain and crosses suture lines.
  • In this patient with a history of alcohol dependence and recent trauma, the delayed onset of symptoms like confusion and ataxia along with CT findings are highly suggestive of a subdural hematoma.
  • SDH can be acute, subacute, or chronic, and the management ranges from conservative treatment in stable cases to surgical intervention (burr hole drainage or craniotomy) in symptomatic or enlarging hematomas.

Explanation of other options:

Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage (Option C): Involves bleeding within the brain tissue, often due to hypertension, cerebral amyloid angiopathy, or trauma. CT shows focal areas of hemorrhage within the brain substance.

Subarachnoid hemorrhage (Option D): Characterized by sudden severe "thunderclap" headache and blood in subarachnoid cisterns and sulci on CT, not as a crescent-shaped hematoma.

questions.text: A 3-week-old infant presents with a cough and sore throat. The mother reports that the infant develops a paroxysm of cough followed by apnea. The total leukocyte count is >50,000 cells/μL. Which of the following drugs will you prescribe for this patient?
questions.solution:
Azithromycin is the first-line treatment for pertussis in all age groups, including infants under 1 month.

  • The clinical presentation of paroxysmal cough, apnea, and marked leukocytosis (>50,000 cells/μL) in a 3-week-old infant is highly suggestive of pertussis (whooping cough), a respiratory infection caused by Bordetella pertussis.
  • The illness progresses in three stages:
    • Catarrhal stage (1-2 weeks): mild URI symptoms
    • Paroxysmal stage (2-6 weeks): paroxysmal coughing with characteristic "whoop", post-tussive vomiting, and apnea in infants
    • Convalescent stage (1-4 weeks): gradual recovery
  • Pertussis can be dangerous in infants and may lead to pulmonary hypertension, cardiogenic shock, hemorrhage, seizures, and malnutrition.
  • Azithromycin is the drug of choice across all age groups due to its safety and efficacy.
  • It eradicates the bacteria from the nasopharynx and helps reduce the risk of transmission.
  • In infants <1 month old, erythromycin and clarithromycin are contraindicated because of the risk of infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS).
  • Cotrimoxazole is also contraindicated in infants <2 months due to the risk of kernicterus.
  • Early treatment, preferably in the catarrhal stage, improves outcomes and reduces infectivity.
  • Infants with confirmed or suspected pertussis should also be isolated for at least 5 days after starting antibiotics.
  • Preventive measures include the DTaP vaccine for infants and Tdap vaccination during pregnancy (ideally between 27-36 weeks) to confer passive immunity to the newborn.

Explanation of other options:

Amoxicillin (Option B): Not effective against Bordetella pertussis; it targets gram-positive organisms, not the gram-negative coccobacilli responsible for pertussis.

Cotrimoxazole (Option C): Though it is an alternative in older children or adults allergic to macrolides, it is contraindicated in infants <2 months due to the risk of kernicterus.

Clarithromycin (Option D): Also effective against B. pertussis, but contraindicated in infants <1 month due to the risk of infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS).

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK519008/

questions.text: A patient who is a known case of hypertension on multiple antihypertensive medications came to the OPD. His ECG finding is given below. Which of the following drugs is responsible for the ECG finding?
questions.solution:
Spironolactone can cause hyperkalemia, which presents on ECG as tall, peaked T waves.

  • The ECG finding of tall, peaked T waves is a classic sign of hyperkalemia.
  • Among the given options, spironolactone is the most likely culprit because it is a potassium-sparing diuretic.
  • It acts by blocking aldosterone receptors in the distal tubule and collecting duct, thereby inhibiting sodium reabsorption and reducing potassium excretion.
  • This leads to potassium retention, raising serum potassium levels and causing hyperkalemia.
  • ECG changes in hyperkalemia progress with severity:
    • Serum Potassium (mEq/L) ECG Changes
    • 5.5-6.5 Tall, peaked T waves
    • 6.5-7.5 Loss of P waves
    • 7.0-8.0 Widened QRS complex
    • >8.0 Sine wave pattern

Explanation of other options:

Prazosin (Option A): Alpha-1 blocker used in hypertension; not associated with hyperkalemia.

Metoprolol (Option B): Beta-blocker; does not usually cause hyperkalemia, though rare cases exist in renal dysfunction.

Hydrochlorothiazide (Option C): Thiazide diuretic that promotes potassium loss, leading to hypokalemia rather than hyperkalemia.
