Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6205312/

choices.text: Repeated radical surgery every 24 hours may be required to adequately manage this condition
This is a case of Meleney's gangrene
The condition is caused by β-hemolytic streptococcus and may sometimes be polymicrobial
Hyperbaric oxygen has no role in the treatment of this condition

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true regarding the provided medical condition?
questions.solution:
Hyperbaric oxygen therapy is beneficial in managing necrotizing infections like Meleney's gangrene and not contraindicated.

  • Meleney's gangrene is a form of necrotizing fasciitis, a rapidly progressive soft-tissue infection that involves synergistic polymicrobial activity, often with Group A β-hemolytic Streptococcus and anaerobes or facultative anaerobes such as Staphylococcus, E. coli, and Bacteroides. (Option B,C ruled out)
  • It typically affects post-surgical or immunocompromised patients, especially in the perineal or lower limb regions.
  • Common locations: Lower extremities in over 60% of cases.
  • Predisposing conditions include:
    • Diabetes mellitus
    • Smoking
    • Penetrating trauma (e.g., bites, abrasions)
    • Pressure sores
    • Immunosuppression
    • Intravenous drug abuse
    • Perineal infections (e.g., perianal abscess, Bartholin's cyst)
    • Skin infections (e.g., boils)
  • Clinical features:
    • Early signs:
      • Oedema extending beyond visible erythema
      • "Woody" or hard texture in subcutaneous tissues
      • Difficulty distinguishing fascial planes and muscles on palpation
      • Disproportionate pain compared to the affected area
      • Skin vesicles and soft-tissue crepitus
    • Absence of lymphangitis is typical.
    • Progression: Rapid onset of fever, tachycardia, and rapid progression to septic shock.
    • Radiological findings: Air in the tissues may be visible on radiographs, although urgent treatment should not be delayed for imaging.
  • Management requires:
    • Urgent surgical debridement of necrotic tissue-often repeated every 24 hours until only healthy tissue remains. (Option A ruled out)
    • Broad-spectrum IV antibiotics.
    • Supportive care, including fluid resuscitation and hemodynamic monitoring.
    • Hyperbaric oxygen therapy (HBO) is a useful adjunct as it enhances oxygen delivery to hypoxic tissues, inhibits anaerobic bacterial proliferation, boosts neutrophil activity, and aids in wound healing. Therefore, saying it "has no role" is incorrect.

questions.text: A 78-year-old woman presents with a progressive decline in daily activity. She gives a history of convulsions and visual hallucinations. She does not talk to anyone and keeps looking at the sky. Pathological examination shows the presence of Lewy bodies within the neurons. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Lewy bodies in neurons along with progressive motor and cognitive decline are hallmark features of Parkinson's disease.

  • Parkinson's disease is a neurodegenerative disorder marked by the loss of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra.
  • A key pathological feature is the presence of Lewy bodies-eosinophilic, intracytoplasmic inclusions primarily composed of alpha-synuclein.
  • Patients typically present with motor symptoms like bradykinesia, rigidity, resting tremor, and postural instability.
  • In later stages, non-motor symptoms such as cognitive decline, visual hallucinations, sleep disturbances, and behavioral changes can occur-consistent with this patient's clinical presentation.
  • Convulsions are rare but can be seen in late-stage disease or in Parkinson's disease dementia.
  • Management involves dopaminergic therapies like levodopa/carbidopa, dopamine agonists, and MAO-B inhibitors.

Reference:

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC5771416/

https://www.nia.nih.gov/health/alzheimers-and-dementia/understanding-different-types-dementia

questions.text: A female presents to the emergency department with 6 weeks of amenorrhea, slight vaginal bleeding, and mild lower abdominal pain. Her urine pregnancy test is weakly positive. Serum β-hCG is 2800 IU/L. Transvaginal ultrasound reveals a left adnexal mass measuring 3 × 2.5 cm. She is hemodynamically stable and has no signs of rupture. What is the likely management?
questions.solution:
Single-dose methotrexate is the preferred treatment in a stable patient with unruptured ectopic pregnancy, β-hCG < 3000 IU/L, and mass < 4 cm.

  • In a hemodynamically stable patient with an unruptured ectopic pregnancy and favorable prognostic factors-such as serum β-hCG < 3000 IU/L, an adnexal mass < 4 cm, and absence of fetal cardiac activity-medical management with single-dose methotrexate (MTX) is the first-line treatment.
  • Methotrexate inhibits rapidly dividing trophoblastic cells, allowing non-surgical resolution.
  • This approach avoids operative risks and preserves future fertility.
  • Close follow-up with serial β-hCG measurements is essential to ensure treatment success.
  • If levels fail to decline appropriately, additional doses or surgical intervention may be required.

Explanation of other options:

Oral methotrexate (Option A): Oral route is not recommended for ectopic pregnancy due to unreliable absorption and effectiveness; intramuscular injection is the standard.

Serial methotrexate + leucovorin rescue (Option C): Used in cases where β-hCG is higher, the mass is larger, or cardiac activity is present. It's more toxic and requires intensive monitoring; not preferred in mild cases.

questions.text: A patient presents with swelling in the groin region and is diagnosed with a direct inguinal hernia. Weakness in which of the following structures is most likely responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Weakness of the conjoint tendon weakens the medial posterior wall of the inguinal canal, predisposing to a direct inguinal hernia.

  • The conjoint tendon is formed by the fusion of the internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles and reinforces the medial portion of the posterior wall of the inguinal canal.
  • A direct inguinal hernia protrudes through Hesselbach's triangle, an area bounded by the inferior epigastric vessels, lateral border of rectus abdominis, and inguinal ligament.
  • Weakness of the conjoint tendon allows abdominal contents to herniate directly through the abdominal wall in this triangle, resulting in a direct inguinal hernia.

Explanation of other options:

Pectineal ligament (Option A): This forms part of the floor of the inguinal canal but is not directly involved in the pathogenesis of direct inguinal hernias.

Reflected part of inguinal ligament (Option C): While it contributes to the anterior wall of the canal, it is not primarily responsible for hernia formation.

Lacunar ligament (Option D): Though it supports the canal medially, it is not involved in the weakness that causes direct inguinal hernias.

questions.text: A boy presents with fever and chills. A rapid diagnostic test detects the HRP-2 antigen. Which Plasmodium species is most likely responsible for the infection?
questions.solution:
The Histidine-Rich Protein 2 (HRP-2) antigen is specific to P. falciparum and is widely used in rapid diagnostic tests (RDTs) for malaria.

  • This antigen is produced by the parasite and remains in circulation for several days after treatment, making it useful for detection but sometimes leading to false positives in recent infections.

Explanation for other options:

Plasmodium malariae (Option B): P. malariae is not detected by HRP-2-based tests, as it lacks this antigen. Instead, it is diagnosed via microscopy or PCR.

Plasmodium vivax (Option C): P. vivax is typically detected using lactate dehydrogenase (pLDH)-based RDTs, not HRP-2 tests. HRP-2 does not reliably detect P. vivax infections.

Plasmodium ovale (Option D): Like P. vivax, P. ovale lacks HRP-2 and is not detected by HRP-2-based rapid tests. Its diagnosis depends on microscopy or PCR.

Key Takeaway:

choices.text: Excessive venous pooling at the feet

questions.text: A woman presents to you at 36 weeks of gestation with complaints of feeling lightheadedness and dizziness when she lies on her back. She says she feels alright if she lies on her side or when she walks. What is the most likely reason behind this?
questions.solution:
The gravid uterus at term compresses the inferior vena cava when supine, reducing venous return and causing supine hypotensive syndrome.

  • This patient's symptoms are classic for supine hypotensive syndrome, which occurs in late pregnancy (typically third trimester) due to mechanical compression of the inferior vena cava (IVC) and partially the aorta by the enlarged uterus when lying flat.
  • This compression decreases venous return to the heart, reduces preload, and consequently drops cardiac output and blood pressure.
  • Clinically, this presents as dizziness, lightheadedness, nausea, and even syncope in the supine position.
  • It is promptly relieved by turning the patient to the left lateral decubitus position, which shifts the uterus away from the IVC.
  • This phenomenon is important to recognize because it affects maternal hemodynamics and can also compromise uteroplacental perfusion.

Explanation of other options:

Increased intracranial pressure (Option A): Symptoms of increased ICP include headache, vomiting, and altered mental status, not posture-dependent dizziness relieved by side-lying; this is not consistent with the clinical presentation.

Heavy meals (Option C): Postprandial hypotension occurs after meals and not specifically in the supine position; symptoms here are position-dependent, not meal-related.

Excessive venous pooling at the feet (Option D): While common in pregnancy, this causes swelling and discomfort in the lower limbs, not dizziness when lying flat.

choices.text: DDAVP for 2 weeks and then discontinue
Upsetting of receptors, so no treatment required

questions.text: A patient presents to the medical OPD with complaints of polyuria. He has a history of total hypophysectomy. His serum sodium is 155 mEq/L, and urine osmolality is 200 mOsm/kg. What is definitive management?
questions.solution:
Lifelong desmopressin (DDAVP) is the definitive treatment for central diabetes insipidus following total hypophysectomy.

  • This patient has central diabetes insipidus (DI), a condition resulting from decreased vasopressin (ADH) secretion due to complete removal of the pituitary gland.
  • Clinical features include polyuria, hypernatremia (Na+ = 155 mEq/L), and low urine osmolality (200 mOsm/kg), all indicating impaired water reabsorption.
  • The definitive treatment is lifelong DDAVP (desmopressin), a synthetic ADH analog that restores water retention and corrects electrolyte imbalance.

Explanation of other options:

DDAVP for 2 weeks and then discontinue (Option A): Inappropriate, as hypophysectomy causes permanent ADH deficiency.

Upsetting of receptors, so no treatment required (Option C): Incorrect; central DI involves hormone deficiency, not receptor issues.

Thiazides for 2 weeks (Option D): Used in nephrogenic DI, not effective in central DI where ADH is lacking.

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK470458/

choices.text: Candidal infection of the fingers due to continuous exposure to water
Continuous exposure to cement and concrete
Continuous exposure to drills and machines

questions.text: A construction worker presents to the OPD with complaints of white fingers. He has been working in the cement and concrete industry and has spent 20 years using heavy machinery drills and polishing wood and furniture. What is the most likely etiology for this condition?
questions.solution:
Prolonged use of vibrating tools leads to Hand-Arm Vibration Syndrome (HAVS), a known occupational cause of secondary Raynaud's phenomenon or "vibration white finger."

  • The patient's description of "white fingers" in the setting of long-term use of vibrating tools-such as drills and wood polishers-is classic for Hand-Arm Vibration Syndrome (HAVS), also known as Vibration-Induced White Finger (VWF).
  • This is a form of secondary Raynaud's phenomenon triggered by repetitive exposure to vibration from handheld tools, commonly seen in construction workers, carpenters, and machinists.
  • Pathophysiology:
    • Repeated vibration causes damage to the digital blood vessels and nerves, resulting in vasospasm and reduced perfusion.
    • During cold exposure or even stress, the affected fingers may turn pale or white due to ischemia, then bluish (cyanosis), and finally red (reperfusion), mimicking classic Raynaud's phases.
  • Raynaud's Syndrome (Secondary):
    • Occurs due to an underlying cause (like collagen vascular disease or occupational hazard)
    • More severe than Raynaud's disease
    • May lead to digital ulcers or gangrene in chronic cases
    • Poor response to sympathectomy
    • Prevention is key: complete avoidance of vibrating tools
  • Treatment options include:
    • Calcium channel blockers (e.g., nifedipine)
    • Vasodilators
    • Steroids (in autoimmune causes)
    • Behavioral modifications

Explanation of other options:

Candidal infection of the fingers due to continuous exposure to water (Option A): Candida infections may affect wet hands but typically cause erythema and fissures, not vasospastic blanching of fingers.

Exposure to thinners and paints (Option B): Thinners can cause skin irritation or dermatitis, but they are not associated with vascular spasms or Raynaud-like symptoms.

Continuous exposure to cement and concrete (Option C): Cement exposure may lead to contact dermatitis or chemical burns, not episodic digital ischemia and color changes seen in vibration white finger.

choices.text: Produces non-lactose fermenting colonies on MacConkey agar.
Exhibits satellitism around Staphylococcus aureus colonies.
It exhibits alpha hemolysis on sheep blood agar.

questions.text: A child presents with high-grade fever, multiple seizures, headache, and neck stiffness. Cerebrospinal fluid analysis shows low glucose, elevated protein, and numerous polymorphonuclear cells. CSF culture reveals pleomorphic gram-negative bacilli. Which of the following statements is true regarding the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The pleomorphic gram-negative bacilli in CSF culture suggest Haemophilus influenzae, a major cause of bacterial meningitis in children. The statement true regarding H. influenzae is that it exhibits satellitism around Staphylococcus aureus colonies.

  • influenzae requires Factor X (hemin) and Factor V (NAD) for growth.
  • Staphylococcus aureus releases NAD, promoting the growth of H. influenzae around its colonies, a phenomenon known as satellitism.
  • The type b capsular polysaccharide (polyribosylribitol phosphate or PRP) is the most virulent serotype, particularly in unvaccinated children under 5 years old, often causing invasive diseases like meningitis.

Clinical features:

  • Meningitis: Fever, irritability, neck stiffness
  • Other invasive diseases: Epiglottitis, pneumonia, septic arthritis
  • Nontypeable strains often cause mucosal infections like otitis media, sinusitis

Diagnosis:

  • CSF analysis in meningitis: elevated protein, low glucose, pleocytosis
  • Gram stain: small gram-negative coccobacilli
  • Culture on chocolate agar
  • Antigen detection tests (latex agglutination) for rapid diagnosis
  • PCR for definitive identification and serotyping

Treatment:

  • Empiric therapy: Third-generation cephalosporins (ceftriaxone or cefotaxime)
  • Alternative: Chloramphenicol (if cephalosporin allergy)
  • Duration: Usually 10 days for meningitis

Explanation for other options:

It is bacitracin sensitive (Option A): Bacitracin sensitivity is a characteristic of Haemophilus ducreyi, not Haemophilus influenzae.

Produces non-lactose fermenting colonies on MacConkey agar (Option B): H. influenzae does not grow on MacConkey agar, as it requires Factor X (hemin) and Factor V (NAD), which are absent in this medium.

It exhibits alpha hemolysis on sheep blood agar (Option D): H. influenzae does not hemolyze red blood cells, whereas Streptococcus pneumoniae (another common cause of meningitis) exhibits alpha hemolysis on sheep blood agar.

questions.text: A 65-year-old chronic smoker came to the medicine outpatient department with complaints of upper chest discomfort and drooping of an eyelid. He also complained of pain radiating to the upper arm and a tingling sensation in the 4th and 5th digits of his right hand. The chest X-ray is given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The classic triad of shoulder pain, Horner's syndrome, and arm symptoms suggests a Pancoast tumor involving the apex of the lung.

  • A Pancoast tumor (superior sulcus tumor) is a non-small cell lung carcinoma (usually squamous or adenocarcinoma) that arises at the lung apex, commonly in smokers.
  • It invades surrounding structures such as the brachial plexus and sympathetic chain, leading to:
    • Shoulder/arm pain (C8-T2 involvement)
    • Horner's syndrome (ptosis, miosis, anhidrosis)
      • Ptosis (drooping eyelid)
      • Miosis (pupil constriction)
      • Anhidrosis (loss of sweating on the affected side)
    • Hand weakness and tingling in the ulnar distribution (C8-T1 nerve roots)
  • Diagnosis:
    • Chest X-ray: Apical mass
    • MRI (Investigation of Choice): Defines local invasion
    • Biopsy: For histological confirmation
    • PET scan: For metastasis workup
  • Management:
    • Radiotherapy (pre-op), surgery (e.g., lobectomy), and chemotherapy depending on resectability.

Explanation of other options:

Superior vena cava obstruction (Option B): Causes facial/upper limb swelling, not ptosis or brachial plexus symptoms; more associated with anterior mediastinal masses.

Upper lobe pneumonia (Option C): May cause chest pain and consolidation on imaging but lacks neuro signs like ptosis or arm tingling.

Aspergilloma (Option D): Occurs in pre-existing lung cavities (post-TB), presents with hemoptysis or cough, not Horner's syndrome or brachial plexopathy.

questions.text: A partogram of a woman who is in labor is shown below. Oxytocin infusion is already given. How will you manage the condition?
questions.solution:
The partogram indicates prolonged labor with features suggestive of cephalopelvic disproportion and fetal distress, warranting an emergency Cesarean section.

  • The partogram reveals that labor has crossed the alert line, showing prolonged labor despite oxytocin augmentation.
  • Key findings include full cervical dilation, station at 3+, moulding 2+, meconium-stained liquor, and a fall in fetal heart rate - all suggestive of cephalopelvic disproportion (CPD) with fetal distress.
  • Since oxytocin has already been administered and uterine contractions are adequate, further augmentation is not beneficial.
  • The presence of fetal distress and obstructed labor necessitates an emergency Cesarean section to prevent complications.

Explanation of other options:

Forceps-assisted delivery (Option A): Requires specific indications like prolonged second stage or maternal exhaustion with low station; not suitable here due to CPD and fetal distress.

Vacuum-assisted delivery (Option B): Also not indicated in suspected CPD with fetal distress; could worsen neonatal outcomes.

Oxytocin infusion (Option C): Already administered; since there's no progress, further oxytocin is not advisable in the setting of CPD and distress.

Reference:

https://iris.who.int/bitstream/handle/10665/58903/WHO_FHE_MSM_93.8.pdf;jsessionid=14CEE7621A01932987688BA52AFE5736?sequence=1

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC9652267/

questions.text: A woman comes with complaints of pain and swelling in the perianal area. She also has complaints of difficulty in walking and sitting. She gives a history of multiple sexual partners. On examination, tender swelling is seen with redness on the labia, as shown in the image given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A painful, red, and tender swelling on the labia with difficulty sitting or walking indicates a Bartholin abscess.

  • Bartholin abscess is a complication of Bartholin cyst due to infection and presents as a red, tender, and painful swelling in the posterior aspect of the labia majora.
  • The Bartholin glands are situated bilaterally at the posterior vaginal introitus and secrete mucus to lubricate the vagina.
  • Blockage of the gland duct leads to cyst formation, and if infected, results in abscess formation.
  • Key Features Suggestive of Bartholin Abscess:
    • Painful, erythematous, tender swelling in labia
    • Pain worsened by walking, sitting, or sexual intercourse (dyspareunia)
    • Labial asymmetry
    • Associated with local redness and sometimes fluctuation
    • Typically located in the inferior aspect of the labia majora near the 4 o'clock or 8 o'clock positions
  • Common causative organisms: E. coli, anaerobes, and polymicrobial flora
  • Management includes: Incision and drainage, word catheter placement, marsupialisation, or gland excision in recurrent cases.

Explanation of other options:

Chlamydial infection (Option A): Usually presents with vaginal discharge, pelvic pain, or urethritis, not a localized tender swelling on the labia.

Genital tuberculosis (Option C): Typically causes pelvic pain, infertility, and menstrual irregularities; labial swelling is not a common presentation.

Herpes infection (Option D): Characteristically causes painful grouped vesicles or shallow ulcers; not associated with a fluctuant tender labial swelling as seen here.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with a rectal polyp and painless rectal bleeding. Histopathological examination reveals enlarged and inflamed glands filled with mucin. The child is diagnosed with a juvenile rectal polyp. Which of the following best describes the polyp in this case?
questions.solution:
Juvenile rectal polyps are hamartomatous growths most commonly seen in children under 5 years of age.

  • Juvenile rectal polyps are benign, hamartomatous growths, typically presenting in young children under the age of 5.
  • The hallmark clinical feature is painless rectal bleeding, often discovered incidentally or during evaluation for per rectal bleeding.
  • Histologically, these polyps exhibit dilated, mucus-filled glands lined by inflamed epithelium and surrounded by a lamina propria rich in inflammatory cells.
  • Though usually solitary, multiple polyps may be seen in juvenile polyposis syndrome, a condition that can be associated with mutations in genes like SMAD2, SMAD4, and BMPR1A.
  • These syndromic cases may also show extra-intestinal features such as digital clubbing and vascular malformations.
  • While juvenile polyps are benign, syndromic forms can carry a slightly increased risk of malignancy over time, especially if multiple or dysplastic polyps are present.

Explanation of other options:

Adenoma (Option A): Adenomas are benign neoplastic polyps that arise from glandular epithelium and are considered pre-malignant. While common in adults, they are rare in children and not the histological pattern seen in juvenile polyps.

Choristoma (Option B): Choristomas are ectopic normal tissue in abnormal locations, like pancreatic tissue in the stomach. They are not associated with juvenile polyps, which are overgrowths of normal colonic tissue.

Carcinoma (Option D): Carcinomas are malignant tumors derived from epithelial cells. They are exceptionally rare in children, especially under age 5, and do not match the benign histological findings of a juvenile polyp.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient presents with acute pain and swelling of the left great toe. There is no history of trauma. Synovial fluid analysis shows raised leukocytes. Lab investigations show normal serum uric acid levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Acute gout is the most likely diagnosis due to the classic presentation of podagra, even with normal serum uric acid levels during an acute flare.

  • This patient presents with acute monoarthritis of the first metatarsophalangeal (MTP) joint (known as podagra), which is highly characteristic of acute gout-a condition caused by the deposition of monosodium urate (MSU) crystals in joints.
  • Although serum uric acid is often elevated in gout, normal uric acid levels do not rule out gout during an acute attack.

Gout

  • Gout is an inflammatory arthritis caused by MSU crystal deposition in joints and soft tissues due to hyperuricemia.
  • However, the uric acid levels may be normal during flares due to crystal precipitation into the joint.
  • Etiology of Gout:
    • Primary Gout:
      • Genetic defects in purine metabolism
      • Decreased renal excretion of uric acid
    • Secondary Gout:
      • Chronic kidney disease, malignancy, or increased cell turnover (e.g., tumor lysis)
      • Medications: Diuretics, low-dose aspirin
      • Diet: Alcohol, red meat, seafood-especially relevant here as the patient is a chronic alcoholic
  • Pathophysiology:
    • Hyperuricemia leads to precipitation of MSU crystals in joints.
    • These crystals trigger activation of NLRP3 inflammasome in macrophages → release of IL-1β, causing intense inflammation.
  • Clinical Features of Gout:
    • Asymptomatic hyperuricemia may be present without symptoms.
    • Acute Gout Attack: Sudden onset of joint pain, swelling, erythema, and warmth; especially at night.
      • Most commonly affects the first MTP joint (podagra).
    • Intercritical gout: Symptom-free intervals between flares
    • Chronic tophaceous gout: Formation of tophi, chalky urate deposits in joints and soft tissues.
  • Diagnosis of Gout:
    • Synovial Fluid Analysis:
      • Gold standard for diagnosis
      • Presence of needle-shaped, negatively birefringent MSU crystals under polarized light microscopy
    • Serum Uric Acid:
      • Often >6.8 mg/dL, but may be normal during an acute attack.
  • Imaging Findings:
    • X-ray: Punched-out erosions in chronic gout
    • Ultrasound: Double-contour sign
    • Dual-energy CT: Detects urate deposits
    • Martel sign: Erosions with sclerotic margins and overhanging edges
  • Management of Gout:
    • Acute Attack:
      • Colchicine: 0.6 mg TID (adjust in renal impairment)
      • NSAIDs: Indomethacin, naproxen (avoid in CKD)
      • Glucocorticoids: Used if NSAIDs/colchicine contraindicated
      • Canakinumab: IL-1β inhibitor in resistant cases
      • Ice therapy: Adjunctive anti-inflammatory
    • Post-Attack Management:
      • Goal: Serum uric acid < 5-6 mg/dL
      • Allopurinol: First-line xanthine oxidase inhibitor
      • Febuxostat: Alternative when allopurinol is contraindicated
      • Probenecid/Sulfinpyrazone: Uricosuric agents (avoid in renal dysfunction)
      • Pegloticase: Refractory cases
      • Lifestyle: Avoid alcohol, red meat, seafood

Explanation of other options:

Pseudogout (Option A): Caused by calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate (CPPD) crystal deposition, typically affects knee, wrist, elbow, and shoulder rather than the big toe. Crystals are rhomboid-shaped and positively birefringent under polarized light.

Reactive Arthritis (Option C): A post-infectious arthritis typically following GI or GU infections, and classically presents with the triad: arthritis, urethritis, and conjunctivitis. It does not fit this monoarticular toe presentation.

Septic Arthritis (Option D): Usually involves larger joints like knee or hip, not typically the toe. Synovial fluid would show very high WBCs, purulent fluid, and may grow bacteria on culture. Fever is commonly present, which is absent here.

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK546606/

Anakinra - LiverTox - NCBI Bookshelf

Colchicine - StatPearls - NCBI Bo

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a sudden, severe headache described as "the worst headache of her life." Her blood pressure is 160/100 mmHg. A non-contrast CT scan of the brain reveals a subarachnoid hemorrhage. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Angiography is the definitive next step to identify the source of bleeding, typically a ruptured aneurysm, in subarachnoid hemorrhage.

  • In the setting of a confirmed subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) on CT scan, cerebral angiography-most commonly digital subtraction angiography (DSA)-is the next crucial step.
  • This allows identification of the bleeding source, typically a ruptured cerebral aneurysm, and helps plan for definitive treatment via surgical clipping or endovascular coiling.
  • While supportive care is also important, such as blood pressure control and preventing complications like vasospasm, localizing the aneurysm is a priority before proceeding to any definitive intervention.
  • Once the aneurysm is identified, treatment decisions are made depending on the location, size, and accessibility of the aneurysm, along with the patient's neurologic status.

Subarachnoid Hemorrhage:

  • Causes:
    • Most common: Trauma
    • Ruptured Aneurysm: Most commonly located in the Circle of Willis.
    • Arteriovenous Malformation (AVM)
    • Perimesencephalic SAH: Bleeding is confined to the basal cisterns due to venous bleeding and is associated with a better prognosis.
  • Risk factors:
    • Female sex
    • Hypertension
    • Smoking & Cocaine use
    • Genetic disorders (e.g., adult polycystic kidney disease, Marfan syndrome)
  • Symptoms:
    • Thunderclap Headache: Sudden and severe headache.
    • Associated with Seizures (10%), Unresponsiveness (50%) and Vomiting (70%)
  • Diagnosis:
    • CT Scan: First-line imaging, effective within 12 hours of onset, and its sensitivity decreases after one week.
    • Fisher Grading for SAH on CT:
    • Lumbar Puncture: Used if CT is negative but SAH is suspected.
    • Digital Subtraction Angiography (DSA): Gold standard for visualising aneurysms.
  • Management:
    • Surgical or endovascular intervention and addressing complications such as vasospasm and electrolyte imbalances.
    • Early and effective treatment is crucial for improving outcomes.

Explanation of other options:

Nimodipine (Option A): A calcium channel blocker used to prevent delayed cerebral ischemia due to vasospasm after SAH, but not the initial or most urgent step after diagnosis.

Surgery (Option C): Although surgical intervention is often necessary, angiography must precede it to precisely locate the aneurysm and decide whether surgery or endovascular coiling is appropriate.

Fibrinolytic therapy (Option D): Contraindicated in SAH; it increases the risk of worsening intracranial bleeding and is used for ischemic strokes, not hemorrhagic ones.

questions.text: Identify the given condition:
questions.solution:
Trophic ulcers are neuropathic ulcers caused by sensory loss, often seen in diabetics, and are typically painless with punched-out edges in pressure areas.

  • Trophic ulcers, also known as neuropathic ulcers, occur due to loss of protective sensation, especially in the feet of patients with peripheral neuropathy-commonly from diabetes mellitus.
  • Because the patient does not feel pain, repeated trauma and pressure over bony prominences (e.g., metatarsal heads, heel) go unnoticed, leading to ulcer formation.
  • These ulcers typically:
    • Are painless
    • Have a punched-out appearance
    • Occur over weight-bearing areas
    • Are surrounded by callused skin
    • Show delayed healing due to impaired tissue perfusion and repeated trauma
  • In this case, the combination of diabetes, painless ulcer, pressure location, callus, and sensory loss is classic for a trophic (neuropathic) ulcer.

Types of Ulcers:


Reference:

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC3036466/

questions.text: A man presents with complaints of dysuria and urethral discharge following unprotected sexual intercourse. Gram staining of the purulent discharge is provided in the image. What is the treatment of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
The presence of Gram-negative diplococci in purulent urethral discharge suggests Neisseria gonorrhoeae, a common cause of gonococcal urethritis.

  • First-line treatment recommended by WHO is a single dose of intramuscular Ceftriaxone (500 mg) + oral Azithromycin (1 g) to cover both gonorrhea and possible Chlamydia trachomatis co-infection.

Explanation for other options:

Erythromycin (Option A): Erythromycin is not effective against gonorrhea and is primarily used for Chlamydia infections in neonates (ophthalmia neonatorum prophylaxis).

Ciprofloxacin + Azithromycin (Option B): Fluoroquinolone resistance is widespread in N. gonorrhoeae, making ciprofloxacin no longer recommended for treatment.

Penicillin G (Option D): Penicillin-resistant N. gonorrhoeae strains are common, leading to the discontinuation of penicillin-based therapy.

Reference:

Urethritis - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf

questions.text: Please determine the medical condition related to the image provided.
questions.solution:
Marfan syndrome commonly causes mitral valve prolapse and mitral regurgitation due to connective tissue abnormalities.

  • The image and clinical features suggest Marfan Syndrome, a connective tissue disorder inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern due to FBN1 gene mutation on chromosome 15, leading to abnormal fibrillin-1 protein.
  • This weakens connective tissue, particularly affecting the cardiovascular, ocular, and musculoskeletal systems.
  • Cardiac manifestations include aortic root dilation, aortic dissection, mitral valve prolapse, and mitral regurgitation-the latter being the most common cardiac complication.
  • Mitral regurgitation occurs due to valve floppiness and improper closure, causing backflow of blood into the left atrium during systole.
  • Key features of Marfan Syndrome:
    • Facial/Ocular: Long face, high-arched palate, ectopia lentis (superotemporal), myopia.
    • Musculoskeletal: Tall stature, arachnodactyly, pectus excavatum/carinatum, scoliosis, positive thumb (Steinberg) and wrist (Walker-Murdoch) signs.
    • Cardiovascular: Aortic root dilation, dissection (most common cause of death), mitral regurgitation.
    • Diagnosis: Based on Ghent criteria, supported by genetic testing and echocardiography.
      • Major criteria:
        • Aortic root dilation.
        • Ectopia lentis.
        • Skeletal features (e.g., arachnodactyly, scoliosis).
        • Family history of Marfan syndrome.
      • Minor criteria:
        • Joint hypermobility, myopia, high palate.
        • Genetic testing for FBN1 mutation confirms diagnosis
    • Management: Beta-blockers/ARBs, regular imaging, surgical repair of aortic root or mitral valve if needed.

Explanation of other options:

Aortic Stenosis (Option B):Typically due to calcific degeneration or congenital bicuspid valve; not a classic feature of Marfan syndrome.

Aortic Regurgitation (Option C): Can occur in Marfan's due to aortic dilation, but mitral regurgitation is more common and primary in early stages.

Mitral Stenosis (Option D): Usually post-rheumatic in origin and unrelated to connective tissue disorders like Marfan's.

choices.text: Detection of microfilariae in the blood smear

questions.text: In a patient presenting with fever and a positive filarial antigen test, what should be the next appropriate step in management?
questions.solution:
A filarial antigen test is highly sensitive but does not differentiate between active and past infections. So, the next step is to confirm the presence of microfilariae in a peripheral blood smear, preferably collected at night (due to nocturnal periodicity of Wuchereriabancrofti).

  • Thick and thin smears with Giemsa or Wright's stain are used to visualise microfilariae.

Explanation for other options:

Bone marrow biopsy (Option A): Filarial infections affect the lymphatic system and do not require a bone marrow biopsy.

DEC provocation test (Option B): The Diethylcarbamazine (DEC) provocation test was historically used to stimulate microfilariae circulation, but it is rarely used today due to the availability of antigen detection tests.

Ultrasound of the scrotum (Option D): Ultrasound of the scrotum (for "Filarial Dance Sign" - movement of microfilariae in dilated lymphatic channels) is useful if scrotal involvement or hydrocele is present, but it is not the first-line confirmatory test.

Reference:

  1. Positivity of Antigen Tests Used for Diagnosis of Lymphatic Filariasis in Individuals Without Wuchereriabancrofti Infection but with High Loa loa Microfilaremia

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with long-standing varicose veins presents with brownish discoloration and eczema over his lower leg. According to the CEAP classification, which clinical stage does this finding correspond to?
questions.solution:
The C4a stage of CEAP classification includes skin changes such as eczema and pigmentation associated with chronic venous insufficiency.

  • The CEAP classification system (Clinical, Etiological, Anatomical, and Pathophysiological) is used for grading chronic venous disorders.
  • Under the Clinical classification, C4a includes pigmentation and venous eczema, which result from chronic venous hypertension leading to hemosiderin deposition and inflammation.
  • These changes indicate progression from uncomplicated varicose veins or edema toward more severe skin complications.
  • Here is a breakdown of the Clinical component of CEAP:
    • CEAP Class Description
    • C0 No visible signs of venous disease
    • C1 Telangiectasia or reticular veins
    • C2 Varicose veins (>3 mm)
    • C3 Edema without skin changes
    • C4a Pigmentation or eczema
    • C4b Lipodermatosclerosis or atrophie blanche
    • C4c Corona phlebectatica
    • C5 Healed venous ulcer
    • C6 Active venous ulcer
  • CEAP also categorizes Etiology (Ec, Ep, Es, En), Anatomy (As, Ap, Ad, An), and Pathophysiology (Pr, Po, Pr,o, Pn) components.

Pigmentation/Eczema

LDS

Atrophic blanche

Corona phlebectatica

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK557410/

questions.text: A child is brought to the hospital with respiratory distress and biphasic stridor. The radiograph is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Acute laryngotracheobronchitis (croup) presents with biphasic stridor and a characteristic "steeple sign" on X-ray due to subglottic narrowing.

  • Laryngotracheobronchitis (Croup) is a viral infection of the glottic and subglottic regions of the airway.
  • Causative agents:
    • Most common: Parainfluenza viruses (types 1, 2, and 3) - ~75% of cases.
    • Other viruses:
      • Influenza A and B
      • Adenovirus
      • Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV)
      • Measles virus
  • Common in children aged 3 months to 5 years.
  • Peak incidence: 2nd year of life.
  • Initial Symptoms (last 1-3 days before airway obstruction)
    • Upper respiratory tract infection signs:
      • Rhinorrhea
      • Pharyngitis
      • Mild cough
      • Low-grade fever
    • Progressive symptoms:
      • Barking (seal-like) cough
      • Hoarseness
      • Inspiratory stridor
      • Fever (up to 39-40°C, or may be absent)
      • Child prefers sitting upright
      • Symptoms worse at night, recur over days, and resolve in a week
  • Physical examination findings:
    • Hoarse voice
    • Coryza
    • Mild-to-moderate pharyngeal inflammation
    • Slightly increased respiratory rate
    • Hypoxia/low SpO2 in severe airway obstruction
  • Diagnosis:
    • Clinical diagnosis based on history and exam
    • X-ray (PA neck): Steeple sign (subglottic narrowing)
  • Treatment:
    • Main goals: Airway management and hypoxia control
    • Mild Croup: Single dose of oral dexamethasone (0.6 mg/kg; 0.15 mg/kg may also be effective)
    • Moderate to Severe Croup
      • Nebulized racemic epinephrine + dexamethasone
      • Used in stridor at rest, respiratory distress, or hypoxia
      • May prevent need for intubation
    • Corticosteroids
      • Reduce laryngeal mucosal edema
      • Beneficial even in mild cases
    • Antibiotics: Not indicated (viral etiology)

Explanation of other options:

Acute epiglottitis (Option A): Presents acutely with high fever, drooling, dysphagia, and toxic appearance. The child often sits in a "tripod" position. Radiograph shows the thumb sign due to swollen epiglottis.

Foreign body aspiration (Option C): Sudden onset of cough, gagging, wheeze, or unilateral decreased breath sounds-not typically biphasic stridor. Chest X-ray may show air trapping or radiopaque objects.

Laryngomalacia (Option D): A congenital anomaly with chronic inspiratory stridor starting in early infancy, worsens with crying or feeding. Diagnosis is made by laryngoscopy, showing an omega-shaped epiglottis.

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK441873/

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK431070/

choices.text: Absence of ipsilateral lower limb proprioception
Absence of fine motor movement of fingers
Absence of contralateral lower limb proprioception

questions.text: In a patient with a cervical spine injury from a road traffic accident, a fracture fragment is found to have impinged on the lateral portion of the dorsal column tract. What clinical findings are most likely to be observed in this case?
questions.solution:
The dorsal column tract of the spinal cord is responsible for proprioception, vibration sensation, and fine touch. The clinical findings likely observed in this case will be the absence of ipsilateral arm proprioception.

Dorsal column-medial lemniscal pathway:

questions.text: A 42-year-old patient with known HIV infection has passed away, and the body is submitted for post-mortem examination. Which autopsy method is most appropriate in this case?
questions.solution:
Rokitansky's technique is used in infectious diseases (HIV, Hepatitis, COVID-19).

Methods of Autopsy:

1. Virchow's Method (M/C)

  • One-by-one organ removal. (Option C ruled out)
  • Fast and easy.
  • Typically used for general autopsies.

2. Ghon's/en-Block Method

  • Targeted organ removal (Cervical, Thoracic, Abdominal, Pelvic blocks). (Option A ruled out)
  • Organ relations remain intact.
  • Thoracic block for chest-related issues, pelvic block for sexual assaults.
  • Useful when preserving inter-organ relationships.

3. Lettule's/en-Masses/Evisceration (Option B ruled out)

  • Large masses of organs removed together (C+T+A+P).
  • Complete viscera removal.
  • Blood vessels and vascular supply are intact.
  • Suitable for minor bleeding cases.

4. Rokitansky/In-situ Method (Option D)

  • Inside dissection.
  • Used in infectious diseases (HIV, Hepatitis, COVID-19).
  • Highly transmissible diseases.
  • Also used for infants <1 year to minimise contamination risk.

Reference:

An Introduction to Autopsy Technique, sample

questions.text: The anomaly demonstrated in the image is due to a developmental defect in which of the following pharyngeal arch arteries?
questions.solution:
The condition shown in the image is Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA), a congenital heart defect where the ductus arteriosus (a fetal blood vessel connecting the pulmonary artery to the aorta) fails to close after birth.

  • The ductus arteriosus is derived from the left 6th pharyngeal arch artery.

questions.text: The image provided corresponds to which type of refractive error?
questions.solution:
Astigmatism is a refractive error caused by an irregular shape of the cornea or lens, leading to blurred or distorted vision.

  • This results in multiple focal points instead of a single point of focus on the retina.
  • The image shows irregular, blurry, distorted vision or varying focal points and is typically associated with astigmatism, where light entering the eye is refracted unevenly.

Astigmatism

  • A refractive error where the eye's refraction varies across different meridians.
  • As a result, light rays entering the eye do not converge to a single point, but instead form focal lines.

Explanation for other options:

Presbyopia (Option A): This is an age-related condition where the eye's ability to focus on near objects decreases, typically around age 40. It causes difficulty in reading or seeing close objects, but it's not associated with distorted vision like astigmatism.

Hypermetropia (Option C) (Farsightedness): In hypermetropia, distant objects are seen clearly, but near objects appear blurry. This is due to a shorter eyeball or less curved cornea, not irregular refraction.

Myopia (Option D) (Nearsightedness): In myopia, nearby objects are seen clearly, but distant objects appear blurry, typically due to a longer eyeball or steeper cornea. It does not cause distorted vision as seen in astigmatism.

Reference:

  1. Astigmatism

questions.text: An infant is brought in with complaints of excessive tearing, photophobia, and blepharospasm. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
True Congenital Glaucoma is characterised by elevated intraocular pressure present during intrauterine life, resulting in ocular enlargement at birth.

  • The presence of Haab's striae, early onset, enlarged corneas, and the classic triad of symptoms (watering, photophobia, and blepharospasm) are all consistent with newborn glaucoma.

Explanation for other options:

Congenital Cataract (Option B): Causes a cloudy lens and poor vision, but doesn't typically cause excessive tearing, light sensitivity, or blepharospasm.

Congenital Dacryocystitis (Option C): Leads to tearing and discharge from a blocked tear duct but doesn't cause light sensitivity or blepharospasm.

Ophthalmia Neonatorum (Option D): Involves eye redness and discharge due to infection at birth, but doesn't cause light sensitivity or spasms.

questions.text: An infant presents with hepatosplenomegaly and thrombocytopenia. Neuroimaging with CT shows periventricular calcifications. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Periventricular calcifications with hepatosplenomegaly and thrombocytopenia are hallmark features of congenital CMV infection.

  • Congenital CMV infection is the most common congenital viral infection and occurs via in utero transmission, especially during primary maternal infection.
  • The transmission risk increases with gestational age, though the severity is higher in early infection.
  • Approximately 90% of infected infants are asymptomatic, while 10% show symptomatic features, including:
    • Hepatosplenomegaly
    • Petechiae or purpura (blueberry muffin appearance)
    • Jaundice (direct hyperbilirubinemia)
    • Microcephaly
    • Intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR)
    • Chorioretinitis
    • Periventricular calcifications on CT, which are pathognomonic
    • Sensorineural hearing loss is the most common long-term complication
  • Diagnosis requires confirmation within the first 2-3 weeks of life using PCR for CMV DNA in urine or saliva.
    • IgG is not diagnostic due to maternal antibody transfer; IgM is unreliable alone.
  • Management includes:
    • Ganciclovir (IV) for symptomatic neonates, particularly those with CNS involvement.
    • Regular follow-up with hearing assessments, developmental screening, and vision monitoring.

Causes of Blueberry Muffin Rash:

Explanation of other options:

Congenital rubella syndrome (Option A): Characterized by the classic triad of sensorineural deafness, cataracts, and congenital heart defects (notably PDA). Also features salt-and-pepper retinopathy, not periventricular calcification.

Congenital herpes simplex virus infection (Option B): Manifests with vesicular skin lesions, chorioretinitis, and microcephaly/hydranencephaly. CT may show diffuse cerebral involvement, not specifically periventricular calcification.

Congenital toxoplasmosis (Option C): Presents with the triad of chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and intracerebral calcifications. Unlike CMV, calcifications in toxoplasmosis are diffuse and random, not periventricular.

Reference:

https://www.researchgate.net/figure/Causes-of-blueberry-muffin-rash_tbl1_353975855

questions.text: A 20-year-old female presents with complete dysphagia after ingestion of a cleaning agent containing 90% sodium hydroxide. What is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
Feeding jejunostomy provides nutritional support by bypassing the severely damaged esophagus during the acute phase of caustic injury.

  • Ingestion of strong alkalis like sodium hydroxide leads to caustic esophageal injury due to liquefative necrosis, saponification, and vascular thrombosis, resulting in extensive fibrosis and stricture formation.
  • In cases with complete dysphagia or full-thickness necrosis, early surgical nutritional support is crucial.
  • A feeding jejunostomy is the most appropriate initial step to ensure enteral nutrition while bypassing the esophagus, giving it time to heal and avoiding further complications such as perforation.
  • Corrosive esophageal injuries are graded:
    • 1st-degree burns: Only mucosal damage; oral feeds resumed after 48 hrs if painless swallowing returns.
    • 2nd/3rd-degree burns: Require fluid resuscitation, IV antibiotics, PPIs, steroids, and nutritional support via jejunostomy.
  • In severe cases with full-thickness necrosis, resection and cervical esophagostomy with jejunostomy may be necessary.
  • Long-term complications include stricture formation, managed by endoscopic dilatation (Savary-Gilliard, Eder-Puestow, or balloon dilators).
  • Surgical bypass or colonic transposition may be needed later if multiple strictures develop or the stomach is also involved.

Explanation of other options:

Esophagojejunostomy (Option A): Reserved for definitive reconstructive procedures after stabilization; not appropriate as the initial step in acute caustic injury.

Stent placement (Option B): Considered in strictures after healing; contraindicated in acute severe burns due to risk of perforation.

Gastrojejunostomy (Option D): Not indicated in esophageal injury; used when the stomach or pylorus is obstructed, commonly in corrosive acid injury affecting the antrum.

questions.text: Which of the following adult structures arises from the embryonic structure indicated in the image?
questions.solution:
The marked structure is the allantois, a hindgut diverticulum. It forms the urachus during fetal development, connecting the bladder apex to the umbilicus, which later degenerates into the median umbilical ligament. This ligament runs along the midline of the abdominal wall.

Meckel's diverticulum (Option C): This arises from the vitelline duct, not the urachus.

Reference:

Urachal remnant causing umbilical in-drawing during micturition - PMC

questions.text: A young boy is brought to the outpatient clinic with complaints of fatigue, muscle cramps, and episodes of low blood sugar after physical activity such as playing. These symptoms resolve with rest. Biochemical analysis reveals reduced serum glucose and lactate levels following exertion. What is the most probable underlying disorder?
questions.solution:
McArdle's Disease, or Glycogen Storage Disease Type V, is caused by a deficiency in the enzyme muscle phosphorylase. This enzyme is essential for glycogen breakdown in muscle cells.

  • Patients with McArdle's disease typically present with exercise intolerance, muscle cramps, and myoglobinuria after strenuous activity.

Explanation for other options:

Hers' Disease or Glycogen Storage Disease Type VI (Option B): It results from a deficiency in liver phosphorylase. While it does cause hepatomegaly and mild hypoglycemia, the symptoms are generally milder.

Cori Disease (Option C): This condition involves a deficiency in the debranching enzyme, leading to mild hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly seen at infancy, limited dextrin accumulation and muscle weakness.

Andersen disease (Option D): This condition involves a deficiency in the Glycogen branching enzyme, leading to hepatosplenomegaly and death before age 5 due to heart or liver failure

Key Takeaway:

Reference:

  1. Glycogen storage disease type III - NIH Genetic Testing Registry (GTR) - NCBI
  2. Anderson-Fabry disease management:
  3. Anderson's Disease

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with nonaxial proptosis of the left eye. He reports a remote history of a road traffic accident that occurred 15 years ago. Based on the findings in the accompanying CT scan, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis based on clinical features and CT is frontal mucocele.

  • A mucocele is a cyst-like structure that forms when the lining of a sinus cavity becomes inflamed or blocked.
  • When a mucocele forms in the frontal sinus, it can cause proptosis (bulging) of the eye.
  • This commonly occurs as a result of obstruction to the frontal ostium due to chronic disease of the frontal recess or due to postsurgical/ traumatic fibrosis, causing blockage.
  • Symptoms of a frontal mucocele include:
    • Proptosis (bulging) of the eye
    • Headache or facial pain
    • Vision changes or double vision
    • Nasal congestion or discharge
    • Sinus pressure or pain
    • Swelling or tenderness in the forehead

Explanation for other options:

Frontal meningioma (Option B):

  • A meningioma is a tumour that arises from the lining of the brain or spinal cord.
  • When a meningioma forms in the front of the head, it can cause eye proptosis.
  • However, meningiomas are relatively uncommon in young adults, and a history of trauma may not be associated with developing a meningioma.

Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (Option C):

  • Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is a rare and benign tumour, typically in adolescent males.
  • It arises from the back of the nose or upper throat and can cause eye proptosis as it grows.
  • However, the history of trauma 15 years prior is not usually associated with developing a juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma.

Pseudotumor of the orbit (Option D):

  • Pseudotumor of the orbit, also known as an idiopathic orbital inflammatory syndrome, is a condition in which the tissues around the eye become inflamed and swollen, causing eye proptosis.
  • The cause of the pseudotumor of the orbit is unknown, but it is thought to be related to an abnormal immune response.
  • While a history of trauma is not typically associated with developing pseudotumor of the orbit, the condition can occur at any age.

questions.text: A family whose diet primarily consists of polished rice is at risk of developing which of the following combinations of vitamin deficiency and the associated enzyme dysfunction?
questions.solution:
Thiamine deficiency-transketolase dysfunction is associated with a primary diet containing polished rice.

  • The Aleurone layer of cereals (food grains) is a rich source of thiamine.
  • Therefore, whole wheat flour and unpolished hand-pound rice have better nutritional value than completely polished refined foods.
  • When the grains are polished, the aleurone layer is usually removed.

Biochemical parameters:

  • Thiamine deficiency affects the enzyme transketolase, which is involved in the pentose phosphate pathway.
    • Measuring transketolase activity in red blood cells is a specific test for thiamine deficiency and can confirm the diagnosis.
    • Erythrocyte transketolase activity is reduced; this is the earliest manifestation seen, even before clinical disturbances.
  • Recommended Daily Allowance of Thiamine is 1-1.5 mg/day.

Explanation for other options:

Riboflavin-glutathione reductase (Option A): Riboflavin (vitamin B2) deficiency affects glutathione reductase, an enzyme involved in maintaining cellular redox balance by regenerating reduced glutathione. Polished rice is not specifically deficient in riboflavin, so this combination is unlikely.

Thiamine-transaminase (Option C): Transaminases (e.g., ALT, AST) are not thiamine-dependent enzymes; they require pyridoxal phosphate (vitamin B6) as a cofactor.

Riboflavin-transketolase (Option D): Transketolase is dependent on thiamine, not riboflavin. Riboflavin deficiency primarily affects flavoprotein enzymes such as glutathione reductase or succinate dehydrogenase.

Key Takeaway:

questions.text: The provided histological image most likely represents which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
The structure of the histological image given is of the kidney showing a glomerulus by proximal convoluted tubules (PCT), and distal convoluted tubules (DCT).

Glomerulus:

  • The glomerulus is a network of capillaries located at the beginning of a nephron in the kidney.
  • Histologically, it appears as a round, densely cellular structure surrounded by a Bowman's capsule.
  • It contains capillary loops, mesangial cells, and podocytes.
  • The structure in the image shows tightly packed cells and capillaries, characteristic of a renal glomerulus.

Explanation for other options:

Reference:

Histology, Nephron - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant presents to the pediatric OPD with complaints of persistent jaundice and pale (clay-colored) stools. On examination, hepatomegaly is noted. Laboratory investigations show conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, and liver biopsy reveals periductal proliferation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Biliary atresia presents in infancy with conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, clay-colored stools, and shows periductal proliferation on liver biopsy.

  • Biliary atresia is a progressive fibro-obliterative disease of the extrahepatic biliary tree, often presenting in the first 2-6 weeks of life.
  • The key clinical features include:
    • Persistent jaundice
    • Acholic (clay-colored) stools
    • Dark urine
  • The histological hallmark is periductal fibrosis and bile duct proliferation, seen on liver biopsy.
  • Types:
    • Perinatal type (70%): No associated anomalies
    • BASM syndrome (15%): Includes Biliary atresia, Asplenia/polysplenia, Situs inversus, and other anomalies
    • Other syndromic associations (15%): Choledochal cysts, renal malformations
  • Investigations:
    • LFTs: Elevated conjugated bilirubin and cholestatic enzymes (ALP, GGT, 5'-nucleotidase)
    • Ultrasound: Absent gallbladder, "triangular cord sign"
    • HIDA scan: No tracer excretion despite phenobarbitone priming
    • Liver biopsy: Gold standard, shows periductal fibrosis and bile duct proliferation
    • Exploratory laparotomy with intraoperative cholangiogram: Confirmatory test
  • Management:
    • Kasai portoenterostomy (hepaticojejunostomy) within 8 weeks
    • Definitive treatment: Liver transplant

Explanation of other options:

Crigler-Najjar syndrome (Option A): Caused by glucuronyl transferase deficiency → results in unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. No periductal changes on biopsy.

Rotor syndrome (Option B): Caused by defects in hepatic organic anion transporters (SLCO1B1/1B3) → mild conjugated hyperbilirubinemia with normal liver histology.

Dubin-Johnson syndrome (Option C): Mutation in MRP2 gene → benign conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. The liver appears black grossly due to pigment deposition, but no bile duct proliferation.

Reference:

https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/liverextrahepaticbiliaryatresia.html

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents with reduced clarity of distant vision but reports no longer needing glasses for near work. Based on the ocular examination image, what is the term used to describe this refractive change?
questions.solution:
Based on the ocular examination image and findings, the term used to describe this refractive change is Index myopia.

  • Myopia(shortsightedness) is a refractive error where parallel rays of light from distant objects focus in front of the retina when the eye's accommodation is relaxed.
  • Index myopiais a condition that often occurs in older individuals, typically associated with age-related changes in the lens. As we age, the lens of the eye becomes denser and less flexible, which can lead to myopia (nearsightedness) in some cases.
  • The patient has reduced distant vision(a hallmark of myopia) but no longer needs glasses for near vision, which suggests that the lens has become more myopic (thicker or more curved) and is compensating for the near vision loss that typically occurs with presbyopia.
  • Index myopia is usually caused by the increase in refractive index of the lens with age, making it more myopic, particularly for distance vision.

Explanation for other options:

Axial myopia (Option B): Caused by an elongated eyeball. This typically leads to myopia from birth or early in life and doesn't relate to the lens changes seen with ageing.

Curvatural myopia (Option C): Caused by a change in the curvature of the cornea, which affects the focusing power of the eye. It's not related to the age-related changes in the lens.

Positional myopia (Option D): Refers to a refractive error caused by the position of the eye or the viewing distance (e.g., looking through different parts of the lens or an unusual gaze position). It's not linked to ageing lens changes like index myopia.

Reference: Defining and Classifying Myopia

questions.text: An elderly man presents for a routine check-up. Laboratory results reveal a markedly elevated total leukocyte count. Peripheral smear findings are shown in the provided image. What should be the next appropriate step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
An elderly male with a high total leukocyte count (TLC) and the presence of smudge cells on the peripheral smear is likely to have Chronic Lymphocytic Leukaemia (CLL).

The next appropriate step for confirming the diagnosis is flow cytometry, which analyses cell surface markers and helps identify abnormal lymphocytes characteristic of CLL.


Explanation for other options:

Stem cell transplantation (Option A): This is not the first-line treatment for CLL. It is typically considered in more advanced or refractory cases, but the initial approach for most patients involves observation or targeted therapy.

Bone marrow biopsy (Option B): Although bone marrow biopsy can help in finding the extent of infiltration, it is not the first choice for diagnosing CLL. Flow cytometry usually confirms the diagnosis, which is more specific for CLL.

High-dose chemotherapy (Option D) is generally not the first treatment for CLL. Most patients with early-stage CLL are observed without immediate chemotherapy. Treatment is usually initiated if there are symptoms or complications, and targeted therapies are often used instead of high-dose chemotherapy.

questions.text: A patient being treated with haloperidol and thioridazine shows inadequate response. A new medication is added, after which the patient develops hyperglycemia, weight gain, and excessive salivation. Which drug was most likely introduced?
questions.solution:
Clozapine is prescribed for treatment-resistant schizophrenia and is particularly effective in patients who do not respond to other antipsychotic medications. However, it is associated with increased appetite (blocking the 5-HT2C receptor), which can lead to weight gain, hyperglycemia, and abnormal lipid levels.



Explanation for other options:

Aripiprazole (Option B) is an atypical antipsychotic approved for schizophrenia, autism in children under 7 years old, and unipolar depression. It can also treat acute mania and is used for maintenance treatment in bipolar disorder, and is associated with the least weight gain.

Brexpiprazole (Option C) is a derivative of aripiprazole, approved for schizophrenia and adjunctive depression treatment, with lower D2 receptor agonist efficacy and stronger 5HT1A partial agonist effects.

Ziprasidone (Option D) is an antipsychotic with low weight gain risk, extremely high 5HT2c affinity, and poor affinity for H1 histamine receptors.

questions.text: Arrhythmia refers to an abnormality in the heart's rhythm. Effective and timely treatment is essential. One therapeutic approach involves modulation or blockade of specific ion channels. Prolongation of refractoriness in cardiac tissue is primarily achieved through the modulation of which ion channel?
questions.solution:
Amiodarone is a drug that prolongs the refractoriness of K+ channels. Thus depresses the ectopic activity and reduces the discrepancy between normal and reentry path. Sotalol and dofetilide have similar actions.

Explanation for other options:

Quinidine (Option A): It can slow down INa with minimal prolongation of refractoriness.

Nifedipine and diltiazem (Option C and D): These are calcium channel blocker drugs. They block L-type voltage-gated Ca2+ channels that can slow SA pacemaker and AV conduction.

For information: drugs that block β-adrenergic receptors, thus reducing the activation of ICaL, are propranolol, metoprolol.

Key Takeaway:

Side effects of Amiodarone -

  • System Affected are:
    • Pulmonary
    • Endocrine
    • Hepatic
    • Ocular
    • Cutaneous
  • Adverse Effect:
    • Pulmonary - Pulmonary fibrosis, interstitial pneumonitis
    • Endocrine - Hypothyroidism or hyperthyroidism (due to high iodine content)
    • Hepatic - Hepatotoxicity: elevated liver enzymes, jaundice, fatigue
    • Ocular - Corneal microdeposits, blurred vision, halos around lights
    • Cutaneous - Photosensitivity, blue-grey skin discolouration (especially on sun-exposed areas)

choices.text: Ask for a line probe assay
Wait until TB culture results to start ATT

questions.text: A 35-year-old homeless man presents with a one-month history of fever, cough, and weight loss. Although both sputum smear tests are negative, the chest X-ray findings are suggestive of tuberculosis. According to the latest NTEP guidelines, what should be the next appropriate step in management?
questions.solution:
According to the NTEP guidelines, a negative smear with positive chest X-ray findings would require a CBNAAT.

  • It is the current gold standard for the diagnosis of tuberculosis within 90 minutes.

Explanation for other options:

Repeat sputum smears (Option A): Previously, it was done, but not done after 2016. Repeat sputum smears are taken to monitor the treatment response.

Ask for line probe assay (Option C): Line probe assay is usually used for the diagnosis of the first-line antitubercular drug resistance tuberculosis, and is not indicated in this case scenario.

Wait until TB culture results to start ATT (Option D): Since it is slow-growing, it takes around 4 weeks to get the sputum culture reports. Hence, it is not ideal to depend on culture reports to start ATT.

choices.text: Left colic vein and middle colic vein
Oesophageal veins and left gastric veins

questions.text: A patient with a known history of liver cirrhosis presents with abdominal pain, jaundice, and signs of portal hypertension. Which of the following venous anastomoses is most likely to be involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
The patient has portal hypertension, which is commonly associated with liver cirrhosis.

  • Portal hypertension leads to the development of portosystemic anastomoses, which are connections between the portal vein and systemic venous circulation.
  • One significant site of such an anastomosis is between the oesophageal veins (draining into the systemic circulation via the azygos vein) andthe left gastric vein (draining into the portal vein).
  • In portal hypertension, increased pressure in the portal vein causes blood to flow through these collateral veins, leading to oesophageal varices.

Portal Hypertension: Reversal of blood flow away from the portal vein due to high pressure.

Clinical Features:

  • Splenomegaly
  • Ascites
  • Esophageal varices
  • Rectal varices
  • Caput medusae

Explanation for other options:

Left colic vein and middle colic veins (Option A): These veins are part of the portal circulation and do not form portosystemic anastomoses.

Superior and phrenic veins (Option C): These are systemic veins and do not involve the portal system.

Sigmoid and superior rectal veins (Option D): both are part of the portal circulation but don't drain into the systemic circulation; thus, anastomoses between them aren't seen in portal hypertension.

questions.text: A child is brought in with red, scaly lesions around the mouth, oral ulcers, and delayed healing of skin wounds. Which mineral deficiency is most likely responsible for these findings?
questions.solution:
The above-mentioned child with red, scaly lesions around the mouth, oral ulcers, and delayed healing of skin wounds is suggestive of Zinc deficiency.

Zinc Deficiency Manifestations:

  • Poor Wound Healing
  • Skin Lesions: Rashes, dermatitis, and hyperkeratosis.
  • Alopecia.
  • Impaired Spermatogenesis.
  • Immune Dysfunction: Decreased T and B lymphocyte counts; impaired macrophage function.
  • Neurological Effects: Depression, dementia, and other psychiatric disorders.
    1. Zinc also forms plaques with amyloid in Alzheimer's disease.
  • Acrodermatitis Enteropathica: A genetic condition characterised by:
    1. Inflammation around the mouth, nose, and fingers.
    2. Diarrhea
    3. Hair loss.
    4. Ophthalmoplegia and hypogonadism.

Explanation for other options:

Iron deficiency (Option A): Iron deficiency typically causes symptoms like pallor, fatigue, and glossitis but does not result in scaly patches or impaired wound healing.

Calcium deficiency (Option C): Calcium deficiency primarily affects bone health, leading to rickets in children or osteomalacia in adults. Skin or mucosal symptoms are not characteristic.

Copper deficiency (Option D): Copper deficiency can cause anaemia, neutropenia, and neurological deficits. It is associated with poor connective tissue integrity (e.g., kinky hair in Menkes disease) but does not cause scaly patches or mucosal ulcers.

Key Takeaway:

Although Zinc Deficiency doesn't cause the classic symptoms of vitamin C deficiency, like gum bleeds, the overlap in issues like impaired healing makes it a relevant differential diagnosis.

Vitamin C Deficiency Manifestations

  • Scurvy: Severe deficiency leads to scurvy, characterised by weakness, fatigue, and swollen gums.
    • Barlow's Disease Occurs in infants (6-12 months) if dietary vitamin C is inadequate, leading to similar symptoms.
  • Hemorrhagic Tendency: Abnormal collagen makes capillaries fragile, resulting in easy bruising (petechiae, ecchymoses) and internal bleeding (epistaxis, hematuria).
  • Oral Cavity Issues: Gums become painful and spongy, and teeth may be lost due to delayed wound healing.
  • Bone Weakness: Impaired osteoid formation leads to weak, easily fractured bones and possible joint haemorrhages.Anaemia: Causes microcytic, hypochromic anaemia due to blood loss, decreased iron absorption, or low tetrahydrofolate.

questions.text: The instrument displayed in the image is not likely to be used for which of the following procedures?
questions.solution:
The image shown is a tracheostomy tube, and it is not used for upper airway examination.

  • Uses of tracheostomy:
    • Airway toileting(Option A)
    • Prolonged mechanical ventilation (Option B)
    • Acute nasopharyngeal obstruction (Option C)
    • Securing the airway in facial injuries

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK555919/

questions.text: While resting in his field, a farmer suddenly experienced a sharp pain in his leg and noticed a fast-moving creature retreating. Soon after, he became drowsy and was taken to the hospital. Examination revealed persistent bleeding at the bite site, localised pain, redness, and blister formation. What is the most probable cause of these symptoms?
questions.solution:
The symptoms described, including drowsiness, pain around the wound, bleeding, and blisters, are consistent with a viper bite.

  • Viper bites often lead to profuse bleeding due to the effects of venom-induced coagulopathy.

Explanation for other options:

Cobra (Option B): Cobra bites are primarily neurotoxic, causing paralysis, respiratory distress, and potentially death if untreated. While cobras can cause pain and local swelling, they do not typically cause the extensive bleeding or blisters seen with viper bites. Cobras do not usually cause such local tissue necrosis and blistering.

Wasp bite (Option C): Wasp stings can cause pain, redness, and swelling at the sting site, but they typically do not lead to bleeding, drowsiness, or blisters. The symptoms described here are more consistent with a venomous bite from a snake rather than an insect sting.

Scorpion (Option D): While scorpion stings can cause pain, local swelling, and sometimes neurological symptoms (such as drowsiness), they typically do not cause blisters or profuse bleeding at the sting site.

Signs and symptoms:

  • Dysfunction of cranial nerve and hyperexcitability of skeletal muscles developed within hours.
  • Local: Swelling, prominent, radiating pain, paraesthesia, and hyperesthesia, which is accentuated by tapping on the affected area (Tap test)
  • Systemic effects: Restlessness, blurred vision, abnormal eye movements, profuse sweating, slurred speech, muscular fasciculations, respiratory depression and pulmonary oedema.
  • Complications: Tachycardia, hypertension, arrhythmias, hyperthermia, rhabdomyolysis and acidosis.

Key Takeaway:

Clinical features

questions.text: A patient is brought to the emergency department with multiple seizure episodes. He remains conscious between the episodes and has been using herbal remedies for treatment. During the seizures, there is noticeable arching of the back. What is the most likely underlying cause?
questions.solution:
Strychnine poisoning is characterised by seizures and muscle spasms, often causing arching of the back (opisthotonus).

  • The patient is typically conscious between episodes, and the seizures are triggered by minimal stimuli.
  • Strychnine is a potent neurotoxin that acts by blocking inhibitory neurotransmission, leading to overstimulation of the central nervous system.

Explanation for other options:

Ricinus (Option B): Ricinus, derived from the castor bean plant, contains ricin, which causes gastrointestinal symptoms, organ failure, and hemorrhagic shock. It does not typically cause seizures with back arching.

Nerium odorum (Option C): Nerium odorum (oleander) contains cardiac glycosides, which primarily affect the heart and can cause symptoms like nausea, vomiting, arrhythmias, and potentially death. Seizures and back arching are not characteristic features of oleander poisoning.

Datura (Option D): Datura contains tropane alkaloids, which cause delirium, hallucinations, and anticholinergic toxicity. Although it can cause seizures, it is not typically associated with arching of the back or the pattern of seizures described here.

Key Takeaway:

questions.text: Which of the following serves as a sensitive indicator for evaluating the availability, utilisation, and effectiveness of healthcare services within a community?
questions.solution:
The infant mortality rate is the deaths of infants less than 1 year of age in a specific year to the total number of live births in the same year.

  • It is animportant indicator of the health status of an entire population, socio-economic conditions, and the health status of infants.
  • It is a sensitive indicator to assess the availability, utilisation, and effectiveness of healthcare, usually in perinatal care.


Immunisation coverage (Option C): Proportion of infants vaccinated.

questions.text: Which antibiotics are recommended for use as prophylaxis during procedures performed on patients with underlying cardiac conditions?
questions.solution:
Cefazolin is the antibiotic of choice for procedures involving cardiac patients.

  • It is a first-generation cephalosporin that can be useful against Streptococci, S. aureus, some Proteus, E. coli, and Klebsiella.
  • It is thedrug of choice for surgical prophylaxis.

Explanation for other options:

Azithromycin (Option B) is a macrolide that inhibits bacterial protein synthesis by binding to the 50S ribosomal subunit, halting bacterial growth. It is used to treat respiratory Infections (e.g., pneumonia, bronchitis), genitourinary Infections (e.g., Chlamydia trachomatis), and infections like otitis media, pharyngitis, cellulitis, etc.

Penicillin (Option C) is a beta-lactam antibiotic that inhibits bacterial cell wall synthesis and is used to treat syphilis.

Doxycycline (Option D) is a protein synthesis inhibitor (tetracycline) that blocks the 30S mRNA-ribosome, thus inhibiting the attachment of aminoacyl-tRNA to the acceptor (A) site. It is used in infections like pleurodesis, H. pylori Infection, leprosy, plague, borrelia, etc.

Key Takeaway:

Classification of cephalosporins: They are classified into 5 generations.

choices.text: 2/3rd of Mendelian disorders are autosomal dominant
1/3rd of Mendelian disorders are autosomal recessive
Every 5th patient has an X-linked recessive disorder
Every 10th patient has a Y-linked disorder

questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly describes a Mendelian pattern of inheritance?
questions.solution:
Approximately 65% of human monogenic disorders are autosomal dominant, making this the most common Mendelian inheritance pattern.

Mendelian Disorders: (Classical inheritance)

  • Autosomal dominant
  • Autosomal recessive
  • X-linked dominant
  • X-linked recessive
  • Y-linked are extremely rare, and prevalence is much lower than 1/10.

questions.text: Which drug is contraindicated in patients with asthma when managing postpartum haemorrhage?
questions.solution:
Carboprost is contraindicated in women with asthma when treating postpartum haemorrhage.

  • A derivative of prostaglandin F2α and the correct dosage for managing PPH is 250 μg IM, repeated every 15-90 minutes, up to 8 doses.
  • Side effects:Diarrhoea, hypertension, vomiting, fever, flushing, tachycardia
  • Contraindications:asthma, pulmonary hypertension, suspected amniotic fluid embolism, and certain renal, liver, and cardiac conditions.

Explanation for other options:

Oxytocin (Option B) is a hormone secreted by the posterior pituitary alongside arginine vasopressin. It is the drug of choice for managing postpartum haemorrhage.

Dinoprostone (Option C) is a prostaglandin E2 analogue (PGE2) and the drug of choice for cervical ripening (vaginal use). It is also utilised for labour induction and medical abortion.

Methyl ergometrine (Option D) is an ergot alkaloid that acts on the myometrium, inducing strong and frequent uterine contractions, which lead to uterine spasms. It is used in the management of postpartum haemorrhage.

Key Takeaway:

Postpartum haemorrhage (PPH)

  • Life-threatening childbirth complications require prompt management.
  • Pharmacological intervention is often necessary to control bleeding
  • Indicated drugs include oxytocin, misoprostol, methylergonovine, and tranexamic acid, but carboprost is contraindicated in bronchial asthma.
  • Contraindicated drugs: Prostaglandin E1 analogues (e.g., alprostadil, epoprostenol) due to severe hypotension risk, and ergotamine derivatives (e.g., ergonovine, methylergometrine) in hypertension/pre-eclampsia due to hypertension risk.

questions.text: A 30-week primigravida presents with complaints of night blindness and reports avoiding specific fruits during pregnancy out of fear they might cause miscarriage. Who is primarily responsible for providing her with appropriate counselling and information in this situation?
questions.solution:
Although all of the above can do this job, the single best answer is ASHA Worker.
