  • The pregnant woman is likely to be suffering fromVitamin A deficiency due to poor intake of foods rich in vitamin A.
  • The primary duty of the ASHA worker is to go for home visits and to counsel regarding sanitation, nutrition, living conditions, and family welfare services.
  • She helps in mobilising the community to access health care facilities available at the PHC/Anganwadi/sub-centre.

Explanation for other options:

ANM (Option A): ANM ensures thorough training of the ASHA worker.

AWW (Option B): They are part-time workers. She undergoes training for 4 months in various sectors like health, nutrition, and child development.

Trained birth attendant (Option D): They ensure safe delivery, monitor maternal and fetal well-being, promote a positive birthing experience by reducing stress and anxiety during labour, promote exclusive breastfeeding, and are trained to identify and rectify any labour complications.

choices.text: N-acetyl cysteine to replenish glutathione stores
Glucagon to control bradycardia and hypoglycemia
Give sodium bicarbonate to alkalize urine

questions.text: A young woman presents to the emergency department after ingesting approximately 100 aspirin tablets. What is the most appropriate next step in her management?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is a case of aspirin toxicity in which the primary treatment is to give sodium bicarbonate to alkalize the urine.

  • It is an antiplatelet medication that irreversibly inhibits COX-1, thereby preventing platelet aggregation.
  • Aspirin stimulates the brain's respiratory centre, causing hyperventilation (↓CO2 levels) and respiratory alkalosis.
  • The kidneys excrete more bicarbonate to counteract respiratory alkalosis, resulting in compensatory metabolic acidosis.High doses of aspirin can disrupt oxidative phosphorylation and kidney function, exacerbating metabolic acidosis.

Dosage and Toxicity:

  • Therapeutic Dose: 3-5 g/day can cause mild chronic toxicity (salicylism).
  • Toxic Dose: Acute ingestion of 10-30 g in adults can be lethal, with much lower doses (4 mL of methyl salicylate) posing a significant risk in children

Clinical presentation:

  • Salicylism: Headache, dizziness, tinnitus, reversible hearing and vision impairment, drowsiness, vomiting, hyperventilation, electrolyte imbalance
  • Severe toxicity: Dehydration, high tone deafness, confusion, petechial haemorrhages, hyperpyrexia, seizures, hypoglycemia, psychosis, coma

Management: Treatment is supportive and includes gastric lavage, correction of metabolic acidosis, vitamin K supplements and urinary alkalinisation with intravenous sodium bicarbonate to enhance salicylate excretion. In severe cases, hemodialysis may be necessary.


Explanation for other options:

N-acetyl cysteine to replenish glutathione stores (Option A) is not indicated in the management of aspirin overdose. It is used as an antidote for acetaminophen overdose, which can cause liver toxicity by depleting glutathione stores. Aspirin overdose does not cause glutathione depletion, so N-acetylcysteine is not useful in this situation.

Pralidoxime (Option B) is not indicated in the management of aspirin overdose. Pralidoxime is an antidote for organophosphate poisoning, which can cause cholinergic toxicity by inhibiting acetylcholinesterase activity. Aspirin overdose does not cause cholinergic toxicity, so this option is not used here.

Glucagon to control bradycardia and hypoglycemia (Option C): Glucagon is not indicated in the management of aspirin overdose. Glucagon is used as an antidote to beta-blocker toxicity.

Key Takeaway:

  • High-dose aspirin causes respiratory alkalosis (stimulates the brain's respiratory centre) & metabolic acidosis (Increases bicarbonate excretion and disrupts oxidative phosphorylation)
  • Management of aspirin toxicity: Urinary alkalinisation with intravenous sodium bicarbonate and vitamin K supplements, and in severe cases, hemodialysis may be necessary.

questions.text: A study is being conducted to evaluate the link between aniline dye exposure and the development of bladder cancer in industrial workers with more than 20 years of employment. One group includes workers directly handling the dye, while the other consists of office staff with no direct exposure. Employment duration is obtained from existing records. What type of study design does this represent?
questions.solution:
A retrospective cohort study is a combination of a prospective cohort study and a case-control study.

  • The researcher goes back in time and selects study groups from existing past medical records and traces them forward.
  • In this case, records of the aniline dye handlers were noted to study the close association with bladder cancer.

Retrospective Cohort Study

  • Start studying at present
  • Move backwards (retrospectively) and use historical data
  • Based on historical data, divide study participants into exposed and non-exposed groups.
  • Ex: Based on the Medical College Register of 2010, divide students into exposed and non-exposed groups
  • Determine outcomes (diseased and non-diseased rates) at the time the study begins.
  • They produce faster results than prospective cohort studies.
  • It has been used for the study of lung carcinoma in uranium miners, arsenic in carcinogenesis, angiosarcoma of the liver, and radiation exposure in physicians.

Explanation for other options:

Prospective cohort study (Option B):

  • In this study, the disease had not yet occurred when the investigation started.
  • The investigation starts from the present and proceeds to the future.
  • A few examples are studies on smoking and lung cancer, studies of oral contraceptives and health.

Case-control study (Option C):

  • It starts with the disease and, hence, it proceeds from effect to cause.
  • Quicker results are noticed.
  • It is suitable for the study of rare diseases and is relatively cheap.

Intervention and response (Option D):

  • It is also called an experimental study.
  • Intervention and response involve direct control over the study, unlike observational cohort studies.

choices.text: Causing a miscarriage with the consent of the mother
Causing a miscarriage without the consent of the mother
Death of the mother by an act done with the intent to cause miscarriage
Causing the death of the quick unborn child by an act amounting to culpable homicide

questions.text: Section 314 of the Indian Penal Code pertains to which of the following legal issues?
questions.solution:
Section 314 IPC: Death caused by an act done with the intent to cause miscarriage, if the act is done without the woman's consent. Now it corresponds to BNS 90.

Reference

  1. THE INDIAN PENAL CODE ARRANGEMENT OF SECTIONS-CHAPTER I CHAPTER II (Page 8)
  2. CORRESPONDENCE TABLE and COMPARISON SUMMARY OF THE BHARTATIYA NYAYA SANHITA, 2023 (BNS) to THE INDIAN PENAL CODE, 1860 (IPC)

questions.text: Parents report that their infant's urine turns dark when left standing. Which metabolic disorder is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Alkaptonuria is characterised by black urine upon standing due to the oxidation and polymerisation of homogentisic acid (HGA).

Explanation for other options:

Phenylketonuria (Option A): Caused by phenylalanine hydroxylase deficiency, leading to the accumulation of phenylalanine. Symptoms include intellectual disability, seizures, and a musty odour, but no black urine.

Homocystinuria (Option C): Due to cystathionine beta-synthase deficiency. Presents with lens dislocation, thromboembolism, and developmental delay, but not black urine.

Maple Syrup Urine Disease (Option D): Results from branched-chain alpha-keto acid dehydrogenase deficiency. Urine has a characteristic sweet odour but does not turn black on standing.

Reference:

  1. Alkaptonuria - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf

questions.text: The marked structure in the image arises from the development of which of the following embryological components?
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the image corresponds to the deep inguinal ring, a key anatomical feature of the inguinal canal.

  • The deep inguinal ring is an opening in the fascia transversalis, located just above the midpoint of the inguinal ligament. This defect allows the passage of the spermatic cord in males and the round ligament of the uterus in females.

questions.text: A 55-year-old individual presents with hoarseness and dysphagia and is subsequently diagnosed with laryngeal carcinoma. Surgical treatment is performed, and a post-operative image is provided. Based on the clinical background and image findings, which surgical procedure was most likely carried out?
questions.solution:
A total laryngectomy is a surgical procedure in which the entire larynx is removed.

  • This procedure is typically performed in advanced laryngeal cancer cases that have not responded to other treatments, such as radiation therapy or chemotherapy.
  • During a total laryngectomy, the trachea is rerouted to the front of the neck to create an opening called a stoma, which serves as the new airway.
  • This procedure has significant implications for speech and swallowing, and patients typically require extensive rehabilitation to learn new communication and eating methods.

Indications for total laryngectomy:

  • a. T4a with thyroid cartilage invasion.
  • b. Stage 3 and 4 patients who cannot tolerate chemotherapy.
  • c. Stage 3 and 4 recurrent tumours
  • d. Bilateral arytenoid involvement.

Explanation for other options:

Partial laryngectomy (Option A): A partial laryngectomy is a surgical procedure in which only a part of the larynx is removed, leaving the rest of the organ intact.

Percutaneous tracheostomy (Option B): Percutaneous tracheostomy is a minimally invasive procedure where a tube is inserted into the trachea via a small neck incision. It's commonly used for temporary or permanent airway support in conditions like obstructive sleep apnea or chronic respiratory failure, but it's not suitable for treating laryngeal cancer.

Standard tracheostomy (Option C): A standard tracheostomy involves creating a neck incision to access the trachea, commonly used for temporary or permanent airway support in breathing difficulties. However, it's typically avoided in laryngeal cancer cases as it doesn't address the cancerous tissue in the larynx.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with difficulty walking and pain in the perianal region. A specimen taken from the perianal area, when tested, produces yellow, needle-shaped rhombic crystals upon reaction with picric acid. What test was performed?
questions.solution:
The above scenario is suggestive of the Barberio test, indicated by the presence of yellow needle-shaped crystals.

  • The Barberio test specifically detects Spermine, a compound derived from the prostate, and is used to identify seminal fluid.

Explanation for other options:

Teichmann test (Option C): This test detects haemoglobin or blood, not seminal fluid.

Acid phosphatase test (Option D): The Acid phosphatase test is used to detect the presence of prostatic fluid in sexual assault cases. It does not produce needle-shaped rhombic crystals with picric acid.

Reference:

  1. Acid phosphatases - PMC

questions.text: A 23-year-old male patient presents with a swelling in the midline of his neck that shifts when he swallows or sticks out his tongue. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A thyroglossal cyst presents as a midline neck swelling that moves with swallowing and tongue protrusion due to its embryological attachment.

  • A thyroglossal cyst arises from the persistence of the thyroglossal duct, an embryological remnant that connects the foramen cecum to the thyroid gland.
  • It typically presents as a midline neck mass that characteristically moves with deglutition and tongue protrusion-due to its anatomical relation with the hyoid bone.
  • The most common site is just below the hyoid (subhyoid region), though it may occur anywhere along the duct's course.
  • The definitive treatment is the Sistrunk procedure, which includes removal of the cyst, the tract, and the central portion of the hyoid bone to prevent recurrence.
  • Incision and drainage are contraindicated, as they may lead to thyroglossal fistula formation, which is always acquired and never congenital.

Explanation of other options:

Brachial cyst (Option A): Typically located laterally along the anterior border of the sternocleidomastoid muscle, not in the midline.

Plunging ranula (Option C): A mucous retention cyst from the sublingual gland, located in the floor of the mouth and lateral in position; does not move with swallowing or tongue movement.

Dermoid cyst (Option D): A congenital midline lesion, but it generally does not move with swallowing or tongue protrusion, distinguishing it from a thyroglossal cyst.

questions.text: A child presents with swelling of the feet, inflammation at the corners of the mouth, and an enlarged heart on examination. Which vitamin deficiency is most likely responsible for these findings?
questions.solution:
Pedal oedema and cardiomegaly indicate heart failure, commonly associated with wet beriberi, caused by thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency.

  • Cheilosis (cracking at the corners of the mouth): Can occur in various nutritional deficiencies, but in this case, the systemic symptoms point toward thiamine deficiency.

Explanation for other options:

Riboflavin (Option A): Riboflavin (vitamin B2) deficiency causes cheilosis, glossitis, and angular stomatitis but does not lead to cardiomegaly or oedema.

Pyridoxine (Option C): Pyridoxine (vitamin B6) deficiency can cause cheilosis and glossitis but is not associated with cardiac manifestations like cardiomegaly or oedema.

Niacin (Option D): Niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency causes pellagra, characterised by the "3 Ds" - dermatitis, diarrhoea, and dementia. Cardiomegaly and pedal oedema are not features.

questions.text: A child presents with complaints of bone pain and an enlarged liver and spleen. Bone marrow aspirate and trephine biopsy reveal characteristic findings as shown. Which enzyme deficiency is most likely responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Gaucher's disease is characterised by the accumulation of glucosylceramide in RBCs and platelet membranes due to a deficiency in the enzyme beta-glucosidase (glucocerebrosidase), leading to anaemia, hepatosplenomegaly, and thrombocytopenia. Bone marrow biopsy shows macrophages with a characteristic "wrinkled paper" appearance.

Gaucher's disease:

  • Lysosomal storage disease
  • Defective enzyme: Glucocerebrosidase (β-Glucosidase)
  • Defect in metabolism: Accumulation of cerebroside (Glucosylceramide) in RBCs and platelet membranes. (Option B)
  • Pathophysiology: Abnormal RBCs and platelets are engulfed by macrophages, leading to accumulation inside macrophages, causing a wrinkled paper appearance.

Alpha 1,4-glucosidase (Option D): Deficiency of alpha 1,4-glucosidase (acid maltase) results in Pompe disease, which is associated with glycogen accumulation, hypotonia, cardiomegaly, and muscle weakness, rather than hepatosplenomegaly and bone pain.

Reference:

  1. Gaucher Disease - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf
  2. Image: https://www.tau.ac.il/medicine/tau-only/webpath/hemehtml/heme057.htm

questions.text: Damage at which of the marked locations in the image would most likely result in an inability to dorsiflex the foot?
questions.solution: The injury to the common fibular nerve causes failure of dorsiflexion; thus, the marked structure 3, i.e. neck of the fibula, is the right answer.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman visits the STI clinic with complaints of minimal vaginal discharge. Speculum examination reveals cervical erosions. Which syndromic management kit is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
The probable diagnosis would be a sexually transmitted infection.

  • There are 7 colour-coded STD kits.
  • Kit 1- Grey is given for urethral discharge, cervicitis, and anorectal discharge.

questions.text: A patient with bronchial asthma on inhaled corticosteroids presents with white, patchy lesions on the tongue and buccal mucosa. Which medication is appropriate for treating this condition?
questions.solution:
The condition characterised by patchy lesions on the tongue and buccal mucosa resulting from the use of inhaled steroids is oral thrush, which can be treated with Clotrimazole.

  • Clotrimazole is a topical antifungal medication (imidazole) that effectively penetrates the skin layers to treat superficial fungal infections.
  • Mechanism of action: Inhibits the 14 alpha demethylase enzyme (CYP), which converts lanosterol into ergosterol cell membrane, hence decreasing cell membrane synthesis.
  • All azoles are metabolised by the CYP2C19 enzyme.
  • It is commonly used in the treatment of conditions such as oral thrush, tinea, and candidiasis.

Explanation for other options:

Griseofulvin (Option B) acts by inhibiting microtubules within fungal cells, thereby disrupting mitosis. It is the drug of choice for superficial fungal infections, such as tinea. However, it can cause side effects, including headache, neuritis, hepatitis, photosensitivity, and a disulfiram-like reaction.

Terbinafine (Option C) is an allylamine antifungal that inhibits squalene epoxidase, reducing ergosterol synthesis and disrupting cell membrane integrity. It is the drug of choice for onychomycosis (fungal nail infections), tinea capitis (scalp ringworm), and extensive fungal lesions.

Flucytosine (Option D) acts as an inhibitor of thymidylate synthase and is a narrow-spectrum fungistatic agent effective against Cryptococcus neoformans and chromoblastomycosis.

questions.text: A chronic smoker with a 20-year history of working in a cement factory is diagnosed with mesothelioma. What is the most likely causative agent for this condition?
questions.solution:
Mesothelioma is primarily caused by exposure to asbestos fibres, which is a known risk factor for this type of cancer.

  • Long-term exposure to asbestos, especially in industries such as cement factories, is the most common occupational cause of mesothelioma.
  • Asbestos exposure is a well-established risk factor for developing laryngeal, ovarian, colon, lung, and pleural cancers.
  • Lung mesothelioma is a more specific tumour associated with asbestos exposure. It is common, but it is less prevalent than Adenocarcinoma.

Explanation for other options:

Silicosis (Option A) is caused by the inhalation of silica dust, commonly seen in industries such as mining and construction. While silica exposure can lead to lung fibrosis, it is not a direct cause of mesothelioma.

Coal worker pneumoconiosis (Option C), also known as black lung disease, results from the inhalation of coal dust. This condition affects the lungs but is not linked to mesothelioma.

Bagassosis (Option D) is caused by the inhalation of mouldy sugarcane dust and can lead to lung disease, but it is not associated with mesothelioma.

Key Takeaway:

  • Adenocarcinoma of the lung is the most common malignancy associated with asbestos exposure.
  • Mesothelioma is the most specific malignancy due to asbestos exposure.

Reference:

  1. Asbestosis - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf

questions.text: A 20-year-old male is found to have a golden-brown ring at the periphery of the cornea during eye examination. Which investigation is most appropriate to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Serum ceruloplasmin is the most appropriate to confirm the diagnosis of Wilson's disease with the golden ring on the cornea.

  • The golden ring on the cornea seen in this 20-year-old male is characteristic of Kayser-Fleischer rings, which are typically associated with Wilson's disease.
  • Wilson's disease is a genetic disorder of copper metabolism that leads to copper accumulation in various tissues, including the liver, brain, and cornea.
  • Kayser-Fleischer rings are copper deposits that form in the Descemet membrane of the cornea, appearing as a golden or greenish ring on slit-lamp examination.

Wilson's disease

  • Deficiency of ceruloplasmin leads to abnormal copper deposition in tissues.
  • Symptoms:
    • Liver disease
    • Basal ganglia dysfunction (movement disorders)
    • Psychiatric disturbances
  • Ocular Signs:
    • Kayser-Fleischer ring: Brownish-yellow golden copper deposits in the corneal Descemet membrane, visible on gonioscopy.
    • Sunflower cataract: Anterior capsular cataract in some patients.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Kayser-Fleischer rings were detected on gonioscopy.
    • Serum Ceruloplasmin levels
  • Treatment: Penicillamine therapy can reduce copper deposits and improve symptoms.

Explanation for other options:

Alpha-1-antitrypsin (Option A): This is a protein associated with lung and liver diseases (like emphysema and cirrhosis), but it is not related to copper metabolism or Wilson's disease.

Alpha-fetoprotein (Option B): This is a tumour marker, often elevated in certain cancers or during pregnancy, but not associated with Wilson's disease or corneal findings.

Serum iron (Option C): Elevated iron levels are associated with hemochromatosis or iron overload disorders, not with Wilson's disease.

Reference:

  1. Wilson Disease - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf

questions.text: A young patient presents with a 5-day history of fever along with hypotension, tachycardia, tachypnea, and altered mental status. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated WBC count, increased neutrophil percentage, and raised serum creatinine. The intern decides to use the quick Sequential Organ Failure Assessment (qSOFA) score to assess prognosis and predict hospitalization duration. Which of the following are components of the qSOFA score?
questions.solution:
qSOFA score includes systolic blood pressure ≤100 mmHg, respiratory rate ≥22/min, and altered mental status (GCS).

  • The qSOFA score is a bedside clinical tool used to identify patients with suspected infection at risk for poor outcomes like sepsis.
  • It includes three parameters:
    • Systolic Blood Pressure (SBP) ≤100 mmHg
    • Respiratory Rate (RR) ≥22/min
    • Altered mental status, assessed via Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)
  • Meeting ≥2 of these 3 criteria indicates a higher risk of sepsis and the need for urgent evaluation and management.
  • Unlike full SOFA scoring, qSOFA does not require lab investigations, making it practical for initial bedside assessment.

Explanation of other options:

BP, RR, and CBC (Option A): CBC is not part of qSOFA; only SBP, RR, and GCS are used.

Creatinine, PR, and BP (Option B): Creatinine and pulse rate (PR) are part of full SOFA, not qSOFA.

RR, Body temperature, and PR (Option C): Body temperature and pulse rate are not qSOFA criteria.

questions.text: A patient with gout was prescribed a medication aimed at decreasing uric acid production. Which drug was most likely prescribed?
questions.solution:
Allopurinol is an inhibitor of xanthine oxidase (XO) used in decreasing uric acid production.

  • Both allopurinol and its primary metabolite, oxypurinol (alloxanthine), reduce urate production by inhibiting XO, the enzyme that converts xanthine to uric acid.
  • Allopurinol competitively inhibits XO at low concentrations and is a non-competitive inhibitor at high concentrations.
  • It is the drug of choice for the treatment of chronic gout.
  • Other uses of allopurinol:
    • Tumour lysis syndrome
    • Lesch-Nyhan syndrome
    • Post-transplant patients

Explanation for other options:

Probenecid (Option A) is a uricosuric agent that acts by increasing uric acid's excretion in the urine.

Colchicine (Option B) is an anti-inflammatory medication commonly used to treat acute gout attacks, but it doesn't affect uric acid levels.

Diclofenac (Option C) is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that can also be used to manage gout symptoms but does not inhibit uric acid synthesis.

choices.text: Years lost due to premature death
Years lost to poor quality of life

questions.text: What does the metric "years of potential life lost" primarily measure?
questions.solution:
Years of potential life lost due to premature death.

  • Example: If a 30-year-old dies, they potentially lose 45 years of life (assuming a life expectancy of 75).
  • YPLL is a mortality indicator, less sensitive in developed nations with better disease control.

Years lost to morbidity (Option A): YPLL refers to premature death, not morbidity.

questions.text: The image depicts the synthesis pathway of angiotensin II and the role of neprilysin, with arrows pointing to the ACE and neprilysin enzymes. Which drug exerts its action by inhibiting both of these enzymes?
questions.solution:
Omapatrilat is a dual inhibitor of Neprilysin and Angiotensin-Converting Enzyme (ACE), as mentioned above.

  • This dual inhibition leads to increased levels of bradykinin, a peptide that can cause vasodilation and increased vascular permeability.
  • The accumulation of bradykinin is associated with a higher risk of severe angioedema, which is a serious and potentially life-threatening side effect.

Explanation for other options:

Sacubitril (Option A) is an ARNI (Angiotensin Receptor-Neprilysin Inhibitor) used in heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF), having side effects such as hypotension, hyperkalemia, renal impairment, and angioedema.

Losartan (Option C) is an Angiotensin Receptor Blocker (ARB) that functions as a competitive antagonist and inverse agonist at AT1 receptors. Additionally, it has an antiplatelet effect by blocking thromboxane A2 receptors and demonstrates uricosuric properties, which could be advantageous for managing gout.

Nesiritide (Option D) is a recombinant human BNP (B-type Natriuretic Peptide) that acts by increasing the levels of cyclic GMP, promoting vasodilation and natriuresis. It does not act on RAAS or NEP pathways.

questions.text: In a village, many farmers exhibit a crossed gait and require a stick for support while standing and walking. Their diet primarily consists of rice and pulses, attributed to low agricultural yield. Supplementation with which vitamin could have helped prevent this condition?
questions.solution:
The people in this scenario are likely to be suffering from Neurolathyrism. As a method of prevention, the diet should be supplemented with Vitamin C (500-1000 mg/day for 1 week).

Lathyrism:

questions.text: A child presents with cola-colored urine, elevated blood pressure, and periorbital oedema. Laboratory investigations show a serum creatinine level of 2.5 mg/dL, which increases to 4.5 mg/dL over three weeks despite therapy. Based on this clinical course, which finding is most likely to be seen on electron microscopy?
questions.solution:
Subepithelial deposits are characteristic of PSGN in electron microscopy.

  • The clinical presentation, including cola-coloured urine, hypertension, oedema, and rising creatinine levels, is highly suggestive of acute glomerulonephritis, particularly post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN).



Explanation for other options:

Given the worsening renal function (rising creatinine levels) over time and the risk of progression to Rapidly Progressive Glomerulonephritis (RPGN), a finding of crescent formation (Option C) in the glomeruli would be expected, but it is a histopathological finding & not an electron microscope finding.

Subendothelial deposits (Option A) are typically seen in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) or membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN), not in post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN).

Mesangial deposits (Option D) are often seen in conditions like IgA nephropathy, membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN), or diabetic nephropathy, but not typically in PSGN.

questions.text: A patient presents with sudden onset of hematemesis. She has a history of arthritis for which she takes aspirin, consumes alcohol occasionally, and also reports sporadic abdominal pain. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Peptic ulcer is the most likely diagnosis due to the presence of risk factors like aspirin use, alcohol intake, and abdominal pain.

  • Peptic ulcers, occurring in the stomach or duodenum, are a common cause of upper gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding and typically present with hematemesis.
  • In this case, the patient's history of aspirin use (a known ulcerogenic NSAID), occasional alcohol consumption (which irritates the gastric mucosa), and episodic abdominal pain all support the diagnosis of a peptic ulcer.
  • These factors compromise the gastric mucosal barrier and increase the risk of ulcer formation and bleeding.
  • Most common artery involved in bleeding ulcers:
    • Duodenal ulcer - Gastroduodenal artery
    • Gastric ulcer - Left gastric artery

Causes of Upper GI Bleed:


Reference:Upper Gastrointestinal Bleeding - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf.

Oesophagitis

questions.text: A student experiences jaw locking during a yawn. Spasm of which muscle, attached to the articular disc of the temporomandibular joint, is most likely responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
The lateral pterygoid muscle is the only muscle attached to the articular disc of the temporomandibular joint (TMJ).

  • It plays a key role in the movement of the TMJ, particularly in opening the mouth and moving the jaw forward (protraction).

Lateral pterygoid:

  1. Attachment: The superior head of the lateral pterygoid inserts into the articular disc and the joint capsule, while the inferior head attaches to the neck of the mandible.
  2. Function: It helps in:
    • Depressing the mandible (opening the mouth).
    • Protrusion and lateral movements of the jaw.
  3. Spasmodic contraction: During excessive yawning, prolonged contraction of the lateral pterygoid can pull the articular disc and the mandible forward, potentially leading to jaw locking due to dislocation of the TMJ.

Explanation for other options:

Temporalis (Option B): This muscle primarily elevates and retracts the mandible; it has no attachment to the articular disc.

Medial pterygoid (Option C): Assists in elevation and side-to-side movements of the mandible but is not connected to the articular disc.

Masseter (Option D): A strong elevator of the mandible; also has no attachment to the articular disc.

Reference: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Mastication Muscles - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf

questions.text: In the given image, which anatomical structure is indicated by the yellow arrow?
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the image is the Fossa of Rosenmüller.

  • The Fossa of Rosenmüller is a small indentation in the lateral wall of the nasopharynx located behind the posterior opening of the nasal cavity. In an image, it may appear as a small, rounded depression in the nasopharynx tissue on either side.

Explanation for other options:

Tubal Ligation (Option B): The Tubal Tonsil is a lymphoid tissue near the Eustachian tube's opening. It is typically found in the superior aspect of the nasopharynx and may appear as a small, rounded tissue mass in an image.

Opening of the Eustachian tube (Option C): The opening of the Eustachian tube is located in the lateral wall of the nasopharynx, near the posterior border of the nasal cavity. It may appear as a small, slit-like opening in an image.

Adenoids (Option D): A rectangular mass of lymphatic tissue called the adenoids is present in the nasopharynx. The adenoids on the nasopharynx's roof and back wall are midline structures. They are a component of the Waldeyer ring, which also consists of the adenoids, palatine tonsils, and lingual tonsils. Beginning in the seventh month of pregnancy, they typically develop until they reach adulthood.

questions.text: A deceased individual is found to have a body temperature of 39°C during examination. What is the most likely explanation for this elevated postmortem temperature?
questions.solution:
Septicemia, which is a systemic infection with widespread inflammation, is a common cause of fever in both living and deceased individuals.

  • It can cause hyperthermia due to the body's inflammatory response.
  • Elevated body temperature within the first two hours after death points toward a diagnosis of Postmortem caloricity.

Postmortem Caloricity:

  • Refers to the condition where the body temperature remains elevated for the first two hours after death.
  • Causes of Postmortem Caloricity:

Note: Burns do not typically cause postmortem caloricity.

Explanation for other options:

Cyanide poisoning (Option A): Cyanide poisoning typically causes rapid death and may lead to hypothermia rather than fever. Cyanide inhibits cellular respiration, leading to metabolic acidosis, but does not usually result in a fever like septicemia.

Corrosive poisoning (Option C): Corrosive poisoning (e.g., acid or alkali ingestion) can cause significant damage to tissues, but it does not typically result in a high body temperature like 39°C. It might lead to shock and other complications, but fever is not the hallmark sign.

Intra-abdominal haemorrhage (Option D): Intra-abdominal haemorrhage typically results in hypovolemic shock due to blood loss, leading to low body temperature (hypothermia) rather than fever.

choices.text: Factors II, VII, IX, and X

questions.text: Which one of the following inactive enzymes (zymogens) depends on γ-glutamyl carboxylase for its activation?
questions.solution:
Gamma-glutamyl carboxylase is an enzyme located in the rough endoplasmic reticulum that modifies glutamate residues in vitamin K-dependent proteins, converting them to gamma-carboxyglutamate.

  • This modification is essential for their biological activity. Vitamin K acts as a co-substrate along with carbon dioxide and oxygen.
  • Factors II (Prothrombin), VII (Stable factor), IX (Christmas factor), X (Stuart-Prower factor), and Protein C depend on vitamin K for synthesis in the liver.
  • Proteins modified by this enzyme are involved in blood coagulation, inflammation, and vascular health.

Factors VIII, XI are not vitamin K dependent. (Option A, C, D ruled out)

Key Takeaway:


Reference: 2677 - Gene ResultGGCX gamma-glutamyl carboxylase [ (human)]

questions.text: A 48-year-old man presents with facial swelling, frothy urine, elevated blood pressure, and microscopic hematuria. He has a history of hepatitis B infection. Kidney biopsy shows a characteristic spike and dome appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The combination of frothy urine, hypertension, and the biopsy finding points to the diagnosis of Membranous nephropathy, which is a common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults.

  • It is often associated with hepatitis B and is characterised by the spike and dome pattern on kidney biopsy due to subepithelial immune complex deposition (primarily IgG and C3).

Membranous nephropathy:

  • M/C cause of nephrotic syndrome in elderly patients.
  • It is immune complex-mediated and can be caused by malignancy(colon, lung, melanoma), infections(malaria, hepatitis B, C, syphilis, schistosomiasis), drugs(gold, penicillamine), or autoimmune conditions(SLE).
  • In primary membranous nephropathy, antibodies primarily target the M-type phospholipase A2 receptor (PLA2R) located on the basal surface of podocytes. This triggers complement activation and subepithelial immune complex deposition, resembling Heymann nephritis lesions.
  • Other less common target antigens include THSD7A and neutral endopeptidase (CD10).
  • The presence of anti-PLA2R antibodies is crucial for diagnosing the disease.

questions.text: A female patient presents with vision loss affecting the right visual fields of both eyes. Which anatomical site is most likely involved in this lesion?
questions.solution:
The lesion described in the question is located in the left optic tract, which explains the vision loss affecting the right halves of both eyes (right homonymous hemianopia).

Visual Pathway:

  • Temporal fibres carry impulses from the Nasal field, and Nasal fibres carry the Temporal field.



Right Optic Tract (Option D)

  • Effect: Left homonymous hemianopia (left halves of both fields).
  • The vision loss given here is in the right half, not the left.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a 40-year-old male patient who has swelling that has been gradually increasing in size over the last two years, with variable consistency and complete mobility upon examination?
questions.solution:
A parotid tumor typically presents as a slow-growing, painless, mobile swelling with variable consistency, matching the clinical description.

  • The clinical scenario of a 40-year-old male with a gradually increasing swelling over two years, variable consistency, and complete mobility is characteristic of a parotid tumor, the most common salivary gland tumor.
  • These tumors often present in the preauricular region and may go unnoticed for years due to their painless nature and slow growth.
  • They are typically benign, with pleomorphic adenoma being the most common type.
  • The parotid gland is highly mobile in the preauricular region, explaining the free mobility of the tumor.
  • The variable consistency may suggest mixed cellular components seen in pleomorphic adenomas, which often have both epithelial and stromal elements.

Explanation of other options:

Dermoid cyst (Option A): Dermoid cysts are usually congenital, present at birth, and grow very slowly. They typically have a uniform consistency, unlike the variable consistency seen in this case.

  • Common sites: External angular dermoid is the most common type.
  • Symptoms: Painless, soft, smooth, and non-tender swelling.
  • Diagnosis: CT scan to rule out intracranial extension.
  • Treatment: Surgical excision

Sebaceous cyst (Option C): These are epidermoid cysts, not true sebaceous origin lesions. They usually present as a superficial skin swelling with uniform consistency and may have a central punctum (except on scalp/scrotum).

  • Content: White, cheesy, keratinous material (not sebum).
  • Characteristic: Typically non-mobile relative to deeper tissues and don't grow as slowly over years like parotid tumors.

Cervical lymph node (Option D): Cervical lymphadenopathy usually presents as firm, discrete swellings, which may be tender (especially in infections) and less mobile when compared to freely mobile tumors.

  • Etiology: Infection, malignancy, or autoimmune disease.
  • On palpation: Often firmer, less fluctuant, and more nodular than described in the stem.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic presents to the emergency department with confusion, unsteady gait, and discomfort during eye movements. Which vitamin deficiency is most likely responsible for these symptoms?
questions.solution:
The patient's symptoms of confusion, difficulty walking (cerebellar ataxia), ophthalmoplegia (painful eye movements) and abnormal eye movements (nystagmus) are classic signs of Wernicke encephalopathy, which is caused by thiamine deficiency, often seen in chronic alcoholics.


Explanation for other options:

Vitamin A deficiency (Option B): Vitamin A deficiency typically causes night blindness and xerophthalmia, not confusion, ataxia, or painful eye movements.

Vitamin D deficiency (Option C): Vitamin D deficiency leads to osteomalacia or rickets, presenting with bone pain and weakness, but not neurological symptoms.

Vitamin C deficiency (Option D): Vitamin C deficiency causes scurvy, characterised by bleeding gums, poor wound healing, and bruising, but it does not cause the neurological symptoms seen here.

Key Takeaway:


Reference:

  1. Wernicke-Korsakoff Syndrome | National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke (nih.gov)
  2. Wernicke-Korsakoff Syndrome: Practice Essentials, Background, Aetiology (medscape.com)
  3. https://radiopaedia.org/articles/wernicke-korsakoff-syndrome-2?lang=us
  4. Vitamin B12 Deficiency in alcoholics
  5. Nutritional deficiency in alcoholism
  6. Alcohol and Nutrition: B12 deficiencies

questions.text: A female patient undergoing evaluation for hearing loss demonstrates a negative Rinne test at 256 Hz and 512 Hz, but a positive result at 1024 Hz. Based on these findings, what is the most likely range of the air-bone gap in this case?
questions.solution:
In the described scenario, the Rinne test is negative at 256 Hz and 512 Hz (indicating that bone conduction is better than air conduction at these frequencies) but positive at 1024 Hz (indicating that air conduction is better than bone conduction at this frequency).

  • This pattern suggests a sensorineural hearing loss at 256 Hz and 512 Hz frequencies, and a conductive hearing loss at 1024 Hz frequency.
  • The anticipated gap between air conduction and bone conduction in this case would be in the range of 30-45 dB, indicating a moderate to moderately severe sensorineural hearing loss at 256 Hz and 512 Hz frequencies, and a mild conductive hearing loss at 1024 Hz frequency.

choices.text: Immature senile cataract and phacoemulsification with IOL

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with diabetes presents with a painless loss of vision. The accompanying image shows her ocular findings. What is the most likely diagnosis, and what would be the appropriate management?
questions.solution:
The patient is a 65-year-old diabetic woman with painless loss of vision, which points towards cataracts, a common cause of visual impairment, especially in older individuals and those with diabetes.

  • Immature senile cataract refers to the early stages of cataract formation, where the lens becomes cloudy but is not yet completely opaque. This typically leads to a gradual loss of vision without pain.
  • The standard treatment for cataracts, particularly in cases with significant visual impairment, is phacoemulsification -a surgical procedure that utilises ultrasound to break up the lens, followed by its removal and the placement of an intraocular lens (IOL) to restore clear vision.


Explanation for other options:

Zonular cataract and lensectomy (Option A): Zonular cataract is a specific type of cataract involving changes to the lens fibres and zonules (the ligaments that hold the lens in place). While lensectomy (removal of the lens) can be performed, it is typically not the preferred term for routine cataract surgery, and this condition is not as commonly associated with the age and symptoms described here.

Rosette cataract and sugar control (Option B): A rosette cataract is a rare type of cataract that forms as a star-shaped pattern, usually associated with trauma or certain diseases, but it is not typically seen in diabetic patients or with the presentation described here. Sugar control is important for diabetes management, but it doesn't directly address the cataract-related vision loss.

Sunflower cataract and lesion extraction (Option C): A sunflower cataract is typically associated with Wilson's disease, a condition characterised by copper accumulation in tissues, leading to a distinctive appearance of the cataract. The patient does not have signs of Wilson's disease, and lesion extraction would not be appropriate for a cataract.

choices.text: Chemotherapy is given along with radiation
Chemotherapy is given before radical surgery to reduce the bulk of the tumour
Chemotherapy is given after radical surgery for micrometastases

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman is diagnosed with stage 2A cervical cancer. The oncology team plans to administer chemotherapy before proceeding with radical surgery to reduce the tumour size. What is the meaning of neoadjuvant chemotherapy in this context?
questions.solution:
Neoadjuvant chemotherapy is given before surgery to shrink the tumour and improve surgical outcomes.

  • Neoadjuvant chemotherapy (NACT) is administered prior to surgical intervention to reduce the tumour burden, increase the likelihood of successful tumour removal, and assess the tumour's response to systemic treatment.
  • This approach is part of Neoadjuvant Systemic Therapy (NAST), which may also include hormonal or targeted therapy.
  • Indications of Neoadjuvant Chemotherapy include:
    • Locally advanced cancers (e.g., T3, T4, N2, N3 breast cancer)
    • Early breast cancer when downsizing is needed for breast conservation
    • HER2/neu-positive and triple-negative breast cancers
    • Premenopausal women (<50 years)
    • Axillary node-positive disease
  • Neoadjuvant targeted therapy:
    • For HER2-positive tumours >5 mm, agents like trastuzumab and pertuzumab are used.
  • Neoadjuvant hormonal therapy:
    • Given to elderly or frail patients with ER/PR-positive tumours unfit for chemotherapy, though clinical response takes 3-6 months.

Explanation of other options:

Chemotherapy is given along with radiation (Option A): This describes concurrent chemoradiation, not neoadjuvant therapy.

Chemotherapy is given during surgery (Option B): This is incorrect; chemotherapy is not typically administered intraoperatively.

Chemotherapy is given after radical surgery for micrometastases (Option D): This describes adjuvant chemotherapy, not neoadjuvant.

choices.text: A) Due to the opening of Na+ and closure of fast K+ channels
Due to the slow but prolonged opening of Ca2+ channels
Due to the closure of Na+and the opening of slow K+ channels

questions.text: What is the true statement regarding the segment marked in red on the myocardial action potential curve?
questions.solution: The red mark on the myocardial action potential curve represents phase 2, the plateau phase of the cardiac action potential, which is due to the slow but prolonged opening of Ca2+ channels

questions.text: A study followed individuals from childhood to adulthood and found that those with lower blood pressure as children continued to have lower blood pressure as adults, while those with higher childhood blood pressure maintained higher levels into adulthood. Which concept best explains this observation?
questions.solution:
The blood pressure of an individual is tracked from childhood to adulthood in the tracking phenomenon of blood pressure.

  • This is a very useful tool in the early diagnosis of hypertension, even among adolescents/ young adults.
  • If a person is hypotensive in childhood, they remain hypotensive in adulthood.
  • If a person is hypertensive in childhood, they remain hypertensive in adulthood.
  • This phenomenon of persistence of the rank order of blood pressure has been described as tracking.

Tracking of blood pressure

Explanation for other options:

Rules of Halves (Option A):

The concept of the "Rule of Halves" in hypertension management illustrates that:

  • Approximately 50% of individuals with hypertension are aware of their condition.
  • Among those aware, only about 50% receive treatment.
  • Out of those receiving treatment, approximately 50% have their blood pressure adequately controlled.

Stepwise approach (Option C): is a systematic, multi-step method designed to collect noncommunicable disease risk factor data at the population level using a questionnaire, physical assessments, and biochemical tests.

Primordial approach (Option D):

  • Focuses on preventing the emergence of risk factors in the first place.
  • Targets social, economic, and environmental conditions that contribute to disease.
  • Focuses on preventing risk factors before they develop (e.g., lifestyle interventions in childhood to prevent hypertension in adulthood).
  • This does not describe the observation in the question.

questions.text: A cancer patient receiving chemotherapy experienced a drop in platelet count during the previous treatment cycle. At what point should intervention be administered to prevent or manage this condition in future cycles?
questions.solution:
Oprelvekin (IL-11) is a medication used to stimulate platelet production in patients who have undergone chemotherapy.

  • It works by stimulating the production of megakaryocytes, which are the cells that produce platelets.
  • It is approved for use in patients with chemotherapy-induced thrombocytopenia (CIT), a condition characterised by a low platelet count caused by chemotherapy.

Explanation for other options:

Filgrastim (Option B) is a medication used to stimulate the production of white blood cells in patients undergoing chemotherapy. It works by stimulating the bone marrow to produce more white blood cells, which can help to prevent infections. While low platelet counts can be a side effect of chemotherapy, filgrastim is not indicated for treating thrombocytopenia.

Erythropoietin (Option C) is a medication that stimulates red blood cell production in patients with anaemia. It is not indicated for the treatment of thrombocytopenia.

Amifostine (Option D) is a medication used to protect healthy cells from the toxic effects of chemotherapy. It does not stimulate the production of platelets and is not indicated for the treatment of thrombocytopenia.

Key Takeaway:

questions.text: A 4-year-old child is brought in with complaints of easy fatigability and episodes of excessive hunger between meals, which improve after eating. On examination, the liver shows the absence of glycogen stores. Which enzyme is most likely deficient in this child?
questions.solution:
Glycogen synthase is the enzyme most likely deficient in this child.

  • Easy fatigability: Indicates impaired energy storage or mobilisation.
  • Increased hunger relieved by food: Suggests inability to maintain blood glucose levels between meals.
  • Absence of glycogen in the liver: Points to a defect in glycogen synthesis, specifically in glycogen synthase, the key enzyme responsible for glycogen formation.
  • Deficiency leads to glycogen storage disease type 0 (GSD 0).

Explanation for other options:

Reference:

Management of glycogen storage disease

choices.text: Investing layer of deep cervical fascia

questions.text: A patient reports pain and swelling just below the left ear. Inflammation or involvement of which of the following anatomical structures is the most probable cause of the discomfort?
questions.solution:
The greater auricular nerve, originating from the cervical plexus, innervates the skin around the ear, angle of the mandible, and parotid region.

  • It runs superficially along the neck and over the sternocleidomastoid muscle, making it prone to injury or irritation, leading to pain and swelling.
  • Pain and swelling under the left ear lobule could indicate involvement of this nerve, possibly due to inflammation or compression.

The External Ear consists of two main parts:

  • Pinna (Auricle)
  • External Auditory Meatus

questions.text: A child is brought in with developmental delay, bone pain, and difficulty walking. Fundus examination reveals a cherry-red spot, and there is no evidence of organomegaly. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In this scenario, the clinical features and fundoscopic image showing a cherry red spot in the macula are consistent with the diagnosis of Tay-Sachs disease.

  • It is an inborn error of metabolism due to the failure of degradation of gangliosides, which is caused by a deficiency in the enzyme hexosaminidase A.

Lipid Storage Diseases (Sphingolipidoses):

  • They are a group of lysosomal storage diseases.

Hurler syndrome (Option C) presents with developmental delay, coarse facial features, corneal clouding, and organomegaly. It is not associated with a cherry-red spot or lack of organomegaly, making it an unlikely diagnosis in this scenario.

Key Takeaway:

Reference:

  1. Tay-Sachs Disease - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf

choices.text: The telmisartan dose should be reduced in renal failure but not in hepatic failure.
The irbesartan dose should be reduced in case of mild to moderate hepatic failure and renal failure.
Candesartan dose should be reduced in mild to moderate liver failure, but not in renal failure.
Losartan acts as a thromboxane A2 antagonist and inhibits platelet aggregation.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct?
questions.solution:
Losartan is an angiotensin II receptor antagonist that blocks the binding of angiotensin II to the AT1 receptor subtype, leading to the dilation of blood vessels and reduced blood pressure.

  • It also blocks thromboxane A2 receptors and has some platelet antiaggregatory properties.

Explanation for other options:

Telmisartan dose should be reduced in renal failure but not in hepatic failure (Option A): Telmisartan is primarily eliminated by the liver and metabolised by the cytochrome P450 system. In case of hepatic impairment, the dose of telmisartan should be reduced. The dose does not need to be reduced in renal failure.

Irbesartan dose should be reduced in case of mild to moderate hepatic failure and renal failure (Option B): Irbesartan is metabolised by the liver and excreted by the kidneys. In case of mild to moderate hepatic impairment or renal impairment, the dose should be reduced.

Candesartan dose should be reduced in mild to moderate liver failure, but not in renal failure (Option C): Candesartan is mainly eliminated through the liver and excreted through the bile. In case of mild to moderate liver failure, the dose of candesartan should be reduced, but no dose adjustment is required in renal failure.

questions.text: A child presents with hair thinning and scaly skin on the scalp. On further enquiry, it is revealed that she regularly consumes raw eggs. These symptoms are most likely due to a deficiency of which vitamin?
questions.solution:
Biotin (vitamin B7) is a water-soluble vitamin essential for carboxylation reactions in metabolism, including fatty acid synthesis and gluconeogenesis. It is crucial for maintaining healthy hair, skin, and nails.

Effect of Raw Egg Consumption:

  • Raw egg whites contain avidin, a protein that binds to biotin with high affinity, preventing its absorption in the gut.
  • Chronic consumption of raw eggs can lead to biotin deficiency, causing:
    • Thinning of hair (alopecia).
    • Scaling of the scalp and other skin lesions.
    • Neurological symptoms like depression, lethargy, and paresthesia (in severe cases).

Explanation for other options:

Niacin (Option A): Niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency causes pellagra, characterised by the "3 Ds": dermatitis, diarrhoea, and dementia. Hair thinning and scalp scaling are not typical features.

Pyridoxine (Option B): Pyridoxine (vitamin B6) deficiency can cause seborrheic dermatitis, irritability, and peripheral neuropathy, but it is not specifically linked to raw egg consumption.

Thiamine (Option D): Thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency leads to beriberi or Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, which primarily affects the cardiovascular and nervous systems, not hair or scalp health.

choices.text: Tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve
Auricular branch of the vagus nerve

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with throat pain, fever, and earache. He is diagnosed with recurrent tonsillitis. Which cranial nerve is most likely responsible for the referred ear pain in this case?
questions.solution:
The glossopharyngeal nerve provides sensory and motor innervation to the tongue, pharynx, and middle ear.

  • The tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve, also known as Jacobson's nerve, provides sensory innervation to the middle ear cavity and the eustachian tube.
  • In cases of middle ear infections or inflammation, such as those associated with tonsillitis, stimulation of this nerve can cause pain in the ear.

Explanation for other options:

Greater auricular nerve (Option B):

  • The greater auricular nerve is a sensory nerve that arises from the cervical plexus and provides innervation to the skin on the side of the head and neck, including the area around the ear. It is not typically involved in ear pain associated with tonsillitis.

Auriculotemporal nerve (Option C):

  • The auriculotemporal nerve is a branch of the trigeminal nerve and provides sensory innervation to the skin of the temporal region, including the area in front of the ear. It is not typically involved in ear pain associated with tonsillitis.

Auricular branch of the vagus nerve (Option D):

  • The auricular branch of the vagus nerve is a sensory nerve that arises from the vagus nerve and provides innervation to the skin of the ear canal and outer ear. However, it is not typically involved in ear pain associated with tonsillitis.

questions.text: A patient receiving digoxin develops side effects such as nausea and vomiting. His serum digoxin concentration is found to be 4 ng/mL, while the therapeutic range is up to 1 ng/mL. Given that digoxin has a half-life of 40 hours, how long will it take before the drug can be safely restarted?
questions.solution:
It will take 80 hours before the drug can be safely restarted.

The Plasma half-life (t½) of a drug is the time taken for its plasma concentration to be reduced to half of its original value.

  • In the scenario, the digoxin serum concentration of 4 ng/ml is significantly above the therapeutic range.

Starting at 4 ng/mL, it would take:

  • 1 half-life (40 hrs) → 2 ng/mL
  • 2 half-lives (80 hrs) → 1 ng/mL (within therapeutic range)

Since the therapeutic range is ≤1 ng/mL, the drug can be safely restarted after 80 hours.

  • Therefore, we should wait at least 80 hours before resuming treatment, considering digoxin's half-life of 40 hours.

questions.text: A child presents with intermittent jaundice and splenomegaly. There is a family history of similar symptoms in an older sibling. Peripheral blood smear findings are provided. What is the most appropriate diagnostic test to confirm this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and peripheral smear showing spherocytes most likely suggest a diagnosis of hereditary spherocytosis.

The osmotic fragility test is used to diagnose hereditary spherocytosis, as spherocytes are more fragile and lyse in hypotonic solutions.

  • Hereditary spherocytosis (HS) is an inherited disorder caused by intrinsic defects in the red cell membrane skeleton that render red cells spheroid, less deformable, and vulnerable to splenic sequestration and destruction.
  • It has an autosomal dominantinheritance(75%) characterised by ankyrin mutation and an autosomal recessive inheritance characterised by spectrin mutation.

  • The most specific morphologic finding is spherocytosis: Dark-staining (hyperchromic) spherocytes lacking the central zone of pallor.
  • Other features include reticulocytosis.
  • The characteristic clinical features areanaemia, splenomegaly, jaundice, and an increased risk of gallstones.
  • Severity ranges from asymptomatic to severe hemolytic anaemia requiring transfusions.
  • Early complications include neonatal jaundice and hemolytic crises.
  • Late complications include gallstones and, rarely, iron overload.

questions.text: A child presents with abnormal behaviour, fever, and reduced urine output following the consumption of an unidentified fruit. What is the likely causative factor, and what is the appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
The scenario involves a child who consumed an unknown fruit and subsequently developed fever and decreased urine output, suggesting Datura Poisoning. The antidote for this condition is physostigmine.

  • Datura contains hyoscine (scopolamine), hyoscyamine and traces of atropine
  • Mechanism of Action: Initially, it stimulates the higher centres of the brain and then activates the motor centres. Later, it leads to depression of the vital centres in the medulla, resulting in paralysis.
  • Clinical features:
    • Dryness of the mouth and throat
    • Dysphagia
    • Difficulty in talking
    • Hoarseness of voice
    • Flushed face
    • Pupil dilatation
    • Photophobia + Diplopia
    • Agitation and restlessness
    • Delirium
    • Urinary retention
    • Dry and hot skin
    • Exfoliation of the skin may occur
  • Patients can end up in a coma, or death can occur due to respiratory paralysis.
  • Treatment
    • Gastrointestinal decontamination: Administer activated charcoal to absorb toxins. Use a cathartic if indicated.
    • Antidote: Administer Physostigmine 1-2 mg IV slowly, repeating as necessary based on symptom response.
    • Symptomatic treatment: Consider Pilocarpine 5 mg subcutaneously for severe anticholinergic effects.
    • Supportive care: Monitor vital signs and address any respiratory or cardiovascular issues.

questions.text: An African child presents with a jaw mass. Biopsy of the lesion reveals the findings shown in the provided image. Cytogenetic analysis identifies a t(8;14) translocation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The "starry sky" appearance and t(8;14) translocation are characteristic of Burkitt lymphoma, a high-grade B-cell lymphoma.

  • The translocation involves the MYC gene on chromosome 8, leading to uncontrolled cell proliferation.
  • All forms of Burkitt's lymphoma (Endemic, Sporadic, and HIV associated) are associated with such translocations.
  • The most common translocations are t (8:2), t(8:14), and t(8:22)
  • Burkitt's lymphoma is a highly aggressive B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma associated with the translocations of the MYC gene on chromosome 8, t(8:14).
  • It has three primary subtypes:
    1. Endemic Burkitt's lymphoma: Commonly affects children in malaria-endemic areas of Africa, often presenting with tumours in the jaw or facial bones.
    2. Sporadic Burkitt's lymphoma: More frequently seen in non-endemic regions and usually involving theileocaecal region and peritoneum
    3. Immunodeficiency-associated Burkitt's lymphoma: Found in patients with conditions such as HIV/AIDS or other forms of immunodeficiency.

Key Takeaway:

Burkitt's lymphoma has three primary subtypes, and almost all cases of Burkitt lymphoma are latently infected with Epstein-Barr virus (EBV)

a. 100% of endemic cases

b. 20% of sporadic cases

c. 25% of HIV-associated cases

questions.text: A patient with a history of myocardial infarction and ventricular arrhythmias has been on long-term treatment. He now presents with fatigue, shortness of breath, weight gain, and signs of pulmonary fibrosis. Which medication is most likely responsible for these findings?
questions.solution:
Amiodarone, a potassium channel blocker and class 3 anti-arrhythmic drug, is used to treat both atrial and ventricular fibrillation. It may cause side effects such as fatigue, dyspnea, weight gain, and, with prolonged use, pulmonary fibrosis.

Explanation for other options:

Atenolol (Option B) is a beta-blocker used for managing hypertension, stable heart failure, post-myocardial infarction (to prevent sudden cardiac death), and the prevention of left ventricular hypertrophy. Side effects include fatigue, reduced libido, cognitive issues, nightmares, bradycardia, hypotension, rebound hypertension, aggravated ischemia, angina, MI, and increased triglycerides/LDL.

Aspirin (Option C) is an antiplatelet medication that irreversibly inhibits COX-1, thereby preventing platelet aggregation. It is the drug of choice for myocardial infarction (MI), stroke, and Buerger's disease.

Spironolactone (Option D)is a potassium-sparing diuretic that either inhibits sodium channels in the distal nephron or blocks aldosterone receptors. It is used to treat heart failure and hyperaldosteronism. Side effects include hyperkalemia and gynecomastia.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with fever, fatigue, and signs of left ventricular dysfunction. An endomyocardial biopsy image is provided. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a child with complaints of fever, fatigue & LV dysfunction & biopsy showing lymphocytic infiltration is suggestive of Lymphocytic myocarditis, an inflammatory condition of the heart muscle characterised by the infiltration of lymphocytes, which are immune cells involved in viral or autoimmune responses.

  • Etiology:
    • Viral infections (e.g., enteroviruses, adenoviruses)
    • Postviral reactions
    • Autoimmune diseases (e.g., systemic lupus erythematosus, rheumatoid arthritis)
    • Idiopathic cases (unknown cause)
  • Pathological finding:
    • Lymphocytic infiltration: Predominantly, lymphocytes infiltrate the myocardium, especially in the left ventricle.
    • Myocyte necrosis: The inflammation leads to the death of myocardial cells.
    • Fibrosis: Chronic cases may develop fibrosis and scarring in the heart tissue.
    • Dilated cardiomyopathy: Severe cases can lead to heart enlargement and dysfunction.
  • Prognosis: The prognosis depends on the underlying cause, extent of myocardial damage, and response to treatment. Viral myocarditis can resolve with supportive care, but severe cases may lead to heart failure or require a heart transplant. Chronic forms may lead to dilated cardiomyopathy.

Reference:

Acute lymphocytic myocarditis - PMC
