questions.text: An outbreak of fever accompanied by headache has occurred in a boys' hostel, with affected individuals later developing pleomorphic rashes that spare the palms and soles. What should be the next best step in managing the suspected cases?
questions.solution: The probable diagnosis, in this case, is chicken pox, also called varicella, which is caused by the Varicella zoster virus. So, control measures include isolation of the child for 6 days after the onset of rashes, and disinfecting all materials that are contaminated by nasal or throat secretions.

questions.text: A chronic smoker undergoing nicotine replacement therapy was also prescribed clonidine for smoking cessation. After abruptly discontinuing clonidine, he developed a headache. What is the most likely explanation for this symptom?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the patient stopped taking clonidine tablets and now presents with a headache (a common symptom of rebound hypertension). Discontinuation of clonidine can cause rebound hypertension due to decreased alpha-2 adrenergic receptor activity, leading to increased sympathetic outflow and a subsequent rise in blood pressure.

Clonidine:

  • It is a centrally acting alpha-2 adrenergic receptor agonist commonly used to manage hypertension, opioid withdrawal, and smoking cessation.
  • When used for smoking cessation, it helps to reduce the withdrawal symptoms associated with nicotine addiction, such as cravings, anxiety, and irritability.
  • One of the side effects of clonidine therapy is rebound hypertension, which can occur when the drug is abruptly discontinued as alpha 1 receptors are upregulated.
  • Rebound hypertension is characterised by a sudden and significant increase in blood pressure, which can cause symptoms such as headache, dizziness, and confusion.

Explanation for other options:

Postural hypotension (Option A) is characterised by a sudden drop in blood pressure upon standing up, which can cause dizziness and fainting. This is not the cause of the headache in this scenario, as per the patient's symptoms.

Receptor downregulation (Option B) is a phenomenon in which the number of receptors on the cell surface decreases in response to an increase in the stimulation of receptors. This is not the cause of the headache in this scenario, as the upregulation of receptors leads to rebound hypertension.

Receptor hypersensitivity (Option C) is a condition in which the receptors on the cell surface become more sensitive to the ligand, which can result in an exaggerated response to the drug. This is not the cause of the headache in this scenario, as hypersensitivity of the receptors would not result in rebound hypertension or headache.

Key Takeaway:

questions.text: A young patient presents with a significant retroperitoneal haemorrhage and reports episodes of knee joint swelling following strenuous physical activity. There is no history of mucosal bleeding. Which coagulation factor deficiency is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.solution:
The patient's symptoms (large retroperitoneal haemorrhage and knee swelling) suggest haemophilia, which is typically caused by deficiencies in Factor VIII (Haemophilia A) or Factor IX (Haemophilia B).

  • This condition is characterised by spontaneous or trauma-induced joint and muscle bleeds but not mucosal bleeding, which is distinct from von Willebrand disease or platelet dysfunction.
  • Haemophilia C is due to factor 11 deficiency, an autosomal recessive condition. Bleeding episodes are generally milder than in Haemophilia A and B.

Explanation for other options:

GP1b/IX (Option B): This is associated with Bernard-Soulier syndrome, a platelet disorder characterised by defective platelet adhesion. It leads to mucosal bleeding, which is absent in this case.

Von Willebrand factor (Option C) deficiency causes von Willebrand disease, which primarily results in mucosal bleeding (e.g., nosebleeds, gum bleeding) and not typically large retroperitoneal haemorrhages or joint bleeds.

Lupus anticoagulant (Option D): This is associated with antiphospholipid syndrome, leading to an increased risk of thrombosis (clots), not bleeding. It does not explain the bleeding symptoms described in this patient.

Key Takeaway:

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of tissue plasminogen activator (tPA)?
questions.solution:
Tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) is a naturally occurring enzyme that converts plasminogen to plasmin. Plasmin is responsible for breaking down fibrin clots in the blood, which is the mechanism of action of tPA.


Explanation for other options:

Inhibit extrinsic pathway (Option A): Tissue factor pathway inhibitor (TFPI) is the inhibitor of the extrinsic pathway of coagulation. It inhibits the formation of factor Xa and thus prevents thrombin formation.

Inhibits platelet aggregation (Option B): Antiplatelet agents like aspirin and clopidogrel inhibit platelet aggregation and prevent the formation of blood clots.

Inhibit clot formation (Option D): Anticoagulant drugs like heparin and warfarin inhibit the formation of blood clots by interfering with the coagulation cascade at different points. They do not directly break down existing clots.

questions.text: What term describes the average daily intake level of a nutrient that is adequate to meet the needs of nearly all (97-98%) healthy individuals within a specific age and gender group?
questions.solution:
Recommended Daily Allowance (RDA) is the average dietary nutrient intake sufficient to meet the nutrient requirements of nearly all (97-98%) healthy individuals in a particular life stage and gender group.

  • It is derived from the individual variability and bioavailability of the nutrients from the diet.
  • It is the level of nutrient intake that is essential to meet all dietary requirements.

Explanation for other options:

Adequate intake (Option A): It is the recommended average daily intake level based on observed or experimentally determined estimations of nutrient intake by a group of apparently healthy people, which are assumed to be adequate.

Dietary goal (Option B): 15-30 % of total daily intake should consist of fats, 10 % should be contributed by saturated fats, and 10-15% should be contributed by proteins. Salt intake should be less than 5 g/day, refined carbohydrates should be limited, and alcohol consumption should be restricted. Junk food consumption should also be restricted.

Estimated average requirement (Option C): It is the average daily nutrient intake level estimated to meet the requirements of half of the healthy individuals in a particular life stage and gender group.

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency department following organophosphate compound poisoning and is treated with intravenous atropine infusion and pralidoxime. Two hours later, the patient develops a sudden rise in body temperature. What is the most likely cause of the fever?
questions.solution:
The scenario described involves organophosphate (OP) poisoning, for which atropine and pralidoxime are used as treatment. The sudden onset of fever, in this case, is most likely a result of Atropine toxicity.

  • Atropine works by blocking the action of acetylcholine at muscarinic receptors in the body.
  • It also has other effects on the body, such as increased heart rate, pupil dilation, and dry secretions. These effects can lead to a rise in body temperature, which is known as atropine fever.
  • It is the drug of choice (DOC) for OPC and carbamate poisoning, bradycardia and AV block.

Explanation for other options:

A side effect of pralidoxime (Option B): Pralidoxime, on the other hand, is used to reactivate acetylcholinesterase, the enzyme that is inhibited by organophosphate poisoning. It can cause side effects such as headache, dizziness, and blurred vision, but it is unlikely to cause fever.

Due to organophosphate poisoning (Option C): Organophosphate poisoning can cause a range of symptoms such as muscle weakness, respiratory distress, and seizures, but it is not typically associated with fever.

Idiopathic (Option D): Idiopathic fever refers to a fever of unknown cause, which is not the case in this scenario, as the cause of the fever is likely related to atropine toxicity.

questions.text: An elderly male with a history of smoking presents with chronic cough, marked weight loss, and fatigue. Laboratory tests show elevated serum calcium levels. Lung biopsy reveals large atypical cells with hyperchromatic nuclei. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
An elderly male smoker with chronic cough, weight loss, fatigue, and elevated serum calcium likely has squamous cell carcinoma of the lung.

  • This cancer is associated with paraneoplastic hypercalcemia due to PTHrP secretion. The biopsy showing large atypical cells with hyperchromasia supports this diagnosis.
  • Smoking significantly increases the risk of squamous cell carcinoma of the lung as it has a strong association, resulting in chromosomal deletions involving tumour suppressor loci involving 3p,9p and 17p.

Squamous cell carcinoma:

Squamous Cell Carcinoma is typically found in the central regions of the lungs (Not peripheral), often originating in the major bronchi near the hilum. It can cause symptoms by obstructing the airways. Histopathologically, it is characterised by keratin pearls, intercellular bridges, and nests of malignant squamous cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm.


Location of lung carcinomas:

  • Central: Squamous cell carcinoma, Small cell carcinoma, and Bronchial carcinoids.
  • Peripheral: Adenocarcinoma and Large-cell carcinoma.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with anaemia, thrombocytopenia (platelet count of 25,000/mL), gum bleeding, and prolonged PT and aPTT. A peripheral blood smear image is provided. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
AML with t(15;17) is characteristic of acute promyelocytic leukaemia (APML), which typically presents with Auer rods on the peripheral smear. The patient also exhibits typical features like low haemoglobin, low platelet count, gum bleeding, and prolonged PT and aPTT, which are seen in this condition due to disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).

M3 AML/ Acute promyelocytic leukaemia:

  • Genetics:
    • t(15:17) translocation causes PML-RARA (retinoic acid receptor alpha) fusion protein formation.
    • Blocks promyelocyte → myelocyte maturation.
    • Diagnosis of choice: Fluorescence In Situ Hybridisation (FISH)
  • Smear findings:
    • Increased promyelocytes.
    • Auer Rods: Fused granules in promyelocytes
    • Faggot Cells: Auer rods with a crisscross pattern.
  • Laboratory:
    • Low haemoglobin and platelets.
    • > 20% blasts on peripheral and bone marrow smear
    • Stain: PAS +
    • CD markers: CD 13, 33 +
  • Complication: Disseminated intravascular coagulation; therefore, chemotherapy is not recommended.
  • Treatment:
    • ATRA (All-trans-retinoic-acid) + As₂O₍ (arsenic trioxide)
    • Best prognosis among all AML.

choices.text: Collect water from already leaking taps
Before collecting, let water flow for at least 1 minute
The water sample container is kept close to the tap to avoid spillage
Collect from a gentle stream of water to avoid splashing

questions.text: During a disease outbreak, what is the correct method for collecting a water sample for bacteriological analysis?
questions.solution:
The correct method involves collecting from a gentle stream of water to avoid splashing.

  • Before collecting a sample from a regularly used tap, let the water flow for at least 2 minutes.
  • Hold the bottle at the base with one hand.
  • Water from leaky taps is avoided.
  • Before collecting samples for taps that are not regularly used, the taps are sterilised by heating either with a blow lamp or a piece of cotton that is soaked in methylated spirit.

Sample for physical and chemical examination:

  • Collection glass: Winchester Quart bottles
  • Capacity: > 2L
  • Pre-collection: Rinse well thrice with water
  • Collection
    • Fill with water
    • Tight placement of the stopper with a piece of cloth
    • Seal the string

Sample for bacteriological examination:

  • Collection glass: Clean bottle made of neutral glass
  • Capacity: 200-250 ml
  • If the sample is likely to have chlorine, 0.1 ml of sodium thiosulfate is added before cleaning.

Transport and storage of the sample:

  • Precaution: Keep the sample on ice till it's taken for analysis.
  • Analysis: Should be done within 48 hours of collection
  • Details
    • Date and time of collection
    • Source
    • Survey findings

Explanation for other options:

Collecting water from already leaking taps (Option A) is avoided as it can contaminate the sample if the water runs outside the tap and enters the bottle.

Before collecting, let water flow for at least 1 minute (Option B): Before collecting a sample from a regularly used tap, the water flow is allowed for at least 2 minutes and not for 1 minute.

Water sample container is kept close to the tap avoid spillage (Option C): Keeping the water sample container close to the tap can cause the contaminants from the tap to pass into the water container.

questions.text: A patient presents with bleeding gums and a tendency to bruise easily. A diagnosis of scurvy is made. What is the underlying cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Scurvy is caused by a deficiency of vitamin C, which is essential for the synthesis of collagen.

  • Collagen is crucial for maintaining the structural integrity of blood vessels, skin, and connective tissues.
  • Without adequate collagen, patients develop symptoms like bleeding gums, easy bruising, and poor wound healing.

Explanation for other options:

Low calcium (Option A): Calcium is important for bone health and muscle function, but it does not directly cause the bleeding and bruising seen in scurvy.

Inhibition of clotting factors (Option C): While vitamin K deficiency can lead to clotting issues, scurvy is not related to clotting factor inhibition but rather to impaired collagen synthesis, affecting vascular integrity.

Increased keratinisation of epithelium (Option D): Keratinisation of epithelium is not a feature of scurvy.

Reference: Ascorbate requirement for hydroxylation and secretion of procollagen: relationship to inhibition of collagen synthesis in scurvy - PubMed

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic develops symptoms consistent with gouty arthritis. Which biochemical abnormality is most likely to be observed in this patient?
questions.solution:
A chronic alcoholic who develops symptoms consistent with gouty arthritis will have increased urate and lactate levels.

Increased Uric Acid (Hyperuricemia):

  • Chronic alcohol consumption is a significant contributor to hyperuricemia, a condition characterised by elevated levels of uric acid in the blood. This occurs due to:
  • Increased turnover of purines from alcohol metabolism.
  • Decreased renal excretion of uric acid as lactate competes with uric acid for excretion through the kidneys.
  • These factors increase the likelihood of uric acid crystal deposition in joints, triggering gouty arthritis.

Increased Lactate Levels (Lactic Acidosis):

  • Alcohol metabolism, particularly through the enzyme alcohol dehydrogenase, generates an increased NADH/NAD+ ratio.
  • This shift favours the conversion of pyruvate to lactate, leading to lactic acidosis.
  • Elevated lactate levels further impair the kidneys' ability to excrete uric acid, exacerbating hyperuricemia and contributing to gout attacks.

Explanation for other options:

Decreased NADH/NAD+ ratio (Option A): Alcohol metabolism increases the NADH/NAD+ ratio, which indirectly contributes to lactate production and hyperuricemia.

Increased urea and urate levels (Option B): While urate levels increase, chronic alcohol use does not typically elevate urea levels unless there is concurrent kidney damage or protein metabolism disturbances.

Increased level of alkaline phosphatase (Option D): This is associated with conditions like bone or liver disease, but is not a key feature of gouty arthritis linked to alcohol consumption.

Reference:

  1. Is lactic acid a misunderstood trigger of gout attacks for a century? - ScienceDirect
  2. Gout Symptoms, Causes & Diet Recommendations | NIAMS

questions.text: A young male patient presents with a clean, non-bleeding cut wound. He reports having completed the full course of tetanus vaccination 10 years ago. What is the most appropriate management in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Single-dose tetanus toxoid is needed for a clean cut wound with a previous booster within 10 years.

  • Thorough wound cleaning is advised, including removal of foreign bodies.

questions.text: A patient received four units of blood transfusion two hours ago and now reports chest discomfort. A chest X-ray reveals bilateral fissure thickening. What is the most likely cause of this presentation?
questions.solution:
Fluid overload is the most likely cause in this scenario. Transfusion of multiple units of blood, especially in a short period, can result in transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO), leading to symptoms like chest discomfort, shortness of breath, and bilateral fissure thickening on chest X-ray (indicative of pulmonary oedema).

Transfusion-Associated Circulatory Overload (TACO) is a common but often underrecognised complication of blood transfusions. It has become the leading cause of death related to transfusions since the risk of Transfusion-Related Acute Lung Injury (TRALI) has decreased.

  • Risk factors:
    • Advanced age
    • Renal failure
    • Pre-existing fluid overload
    • Cardiac dysfunction
    • Administration of large blood volumes
    • Rapid transfusion rates relative to the patient's hemodynamic tolerance
  • Clinical presentation:
    • Dyspnea and hypoxia
    • Bilateral, predominantly alveolar infiltrates seen on chest X-ray
    • Frequent systolic hypertension
    • Elevated brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) levels
    • Fever (in some cases)
  • Prevention:
    • Identifying high-risk patients
    • Close monitoring during transfusion
    • Slowing the transfusion rate (e.g., administering 1 unit of red blood cells over 3-4 hours)
    • Using diuretics in hemodynamically stable patients with a history of TACO
  • Treatment:
    • Stopping the transfusion immediately
    • Administering oxygen
    • Administering diuretics to alleviate symptoms and prevent further complications.

Explanation for other options:

ABO incompatibility reaction (Option A) is a severe reaction that occurs immediately after transfusion and presents with hemolysis, fever, chills, and dark urine rather than chest discomfort or pulmonary findings like bilateral fissure thickening.

Hypocalcemia (Option C) can occur after rapid blood transfusions due to the citrate in blood products, which binds calcium. However, hypocalcemia typically presents with symptoms like tetany, paresthesias, or cardiac arrhythmias rather than chest discomfort and lung findings on X-ray.

Graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) (Option D) is a rare but serious complication of blood transfusions, primarily in immunocompromised patients. It presents with skin rash, liver dysfunction, and gastrointestinal symptoms rather than chest discomfort or pulmonary oedema on X-ray.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought in with a small nodule on the sclera, as seen in the provided image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Dermoid cyst appears as a lenticular yellow tumour near the corneal margin and consists of epidermoid epithelium with sebaceous glands and hair.

  • Dermoid cyst is a congenital, often benign growth that contains skin-like structures, such as hair follicles, sweat glands, and sebaceous glands.
  • It can present as a small, firm, yellowish nodule on the sclera or conjunctiva.
  • These cysts are often located near the limbus (the junction between the cornea and sclera) and may be noticed in childhood, especially if they grow or become more noticeable over time.

A dermoid cyst may be diagnosed based on its characteristic appearance and location, and sometimes imaging or excision is needed for confirmation.


Explanation for other options:

Pterygium (Option A): A pterygium is a fibrovascular growth that extends from the conjunctiva onto the cornea, typically seen on the nasal side of the eye. It is usually triangular and may cause visual disturbance. It is not typically a nodule confined to the sclera.


Pinguecula (Option B): A yellowish, triangular patch on the conjunctiva near the limbus, typically in the elderly, associated with sun exposure and not extending onto the cornea.


Dermolipoma (Option C): A dermolipoma is a benign tumour consisting of fat and skin-like tissue. While they may be located in the eye area, they typically present as larger, softer masses, and this does not match the presentation of a small nodule on the sclera.

questions.text: Which of the following metabolic effects is characteristic of a low insulin-to-glucagon ratio?
questions.solution:
Hormone-sensitive lipase (HSL) is activated in response to a low insulin-to-glucagon ratio.

HSL breaks down stored triglycerides in adipose tissue into free fatty acids and glycerol, providing energy during fasting.

Insulin: Glucagon Bipolar Axis:

  • Insulin: Anabolic hormone promoting glycogenesis, lipogenesis, and protein synthesis.
  • Glucagon: Catabolic hormone stimulating glycogenolysis, gluconeogenesis, and lipolysis.
  • IGR:
    1. High IGR → Anabolic state, reduced glucose production.
    2. Low IGR → Catabolic state, increased glucose production.

Determinants of IGR:

  • Influenced by insulin and glucagon secretion patterns, dietary composition, and metabolic status.
  • Variability in systemic and portal concentrations complicates measurement accuracy.

Explanation for other options:

Activation of lipoprotein lipase (Option A): Lipoprotein lipase is activated by insulin, not glucagon. It facilitates triglyceride uptake from circulating lipoproteins into adipose tissue for storage, which occurs in the fed state.

Activation of glycogen synthase (Option B): Glycogen synthase is activated by insulin, promoting glycogen synthesis in the liver and muscle during the fed state.

Activation of phosphofructokinase (Option C): Phosphofructokinase (PFK) is a key enzyme in glycolysis. It is activated by insulin and suppressed during fasting (low insulin: glucagon ratio), as glycolysis is reduced in favour of gluconeogenesis.

Key Takeaway:


Reference: The Insulin: Glucagon Ratio and the Choice of Glucose-Lowering Drugs - PMC

choices.text: Fluorescein dye, with e cobalt blue filter

questions.text: Which dye and filter have been used to obtain the appearance seen in the provided image?
questions.solution:
Fluorescein dye and a cobalt blue filter have been used to obtain the appearance seen in the provided image.

Fluorescein sodium


Fluorescein penetrates poorly into the lipid layer of the corneal epithelium, and therefore, it does not stain normal cornea. Although fluorescein is a very effective stain for the diseased cornea, it is more difficult to detect fluorescein staining of the conjunctiva because of the poor scleral contrast. Fluorescein absorbs light in the blue spectrum (490 nm) and emits yellow-green light of a higher wavelength (530 nm); therefore, staining can be more readily viewed if a cobalt blue or yellow (blue-free) filter is used. This combination is particularly useful for detecting corneal defects and ulcers.

Cobalt blue filter:

Cobalt blue is a filter that is commonly used in conjunction with fluorescein stain, as it enhances the fluorescence of fluorescein, making it easier to detect corneal defects. It absorbs light in the blue spectrum (around 490 nm) and helps the fluorescein stain emit a bright yellow-green fluorescence when illuminated.

Lissamine green dye


It has a high affinity for staining dead and degenerated cells, including mucous strands. The dye appears to stain areas where there are disrupted intercellular junctions. Use of a green (red-free) filter shows the stained areas to appear black. As it is better tolerated than rose Bengal, it is the preferred dye for staining the bulbar conjunctiva.

Explanation for other options:

Lissamine green dye green filter (Option A):

  • Lissamine green stains dead or degenerated cells and mucous strands on the conjunctiva, not corneal defects.
  • A green filter is used with lissamine green because it enhances contrast, making stained areas appear black. It's not effective for fluorescein.

Lissamine green dye, cobalt blue filter (Option B):

  • Lissamine green doesn't fluoresce, so a cobalt blue filter (which works with fluorescein) won't enhance its staining.
  • Cobalt blue is useful for fluorescein fluorescence, not for lissamine green, which requires a green filter.

Fluorescein dye green filter (Option C): Fluorescein works best with a cobalt blue filter for fluorescence, not a green filter. A green filter doesn't enhance fluorescein's fluorescence, making it less effective for detecting corneal defects.

Reference: Ocular surface staining: Current concepts and techniques - PMC

questions.text: As part of the school-based immunisation schedule, which vaccine is administered to a 10-year-old child?
questions.solution:
The TT/Td vaccine is given at 10 years in the school program.

  • Pentavalent vaccine given at 6, 10, 14 weeks with boosters
  • TT boosters at 10, 16 years
  • Prevents Tetanus from Clostridium tetani
  • Tetanospasmin is a dangerous exotoxin
  • Soil is a source
  • Herd immunity ineffective
